I would only recommend this game if you have friends to play it with. Combat-wise, it used to take one punch or dive kick to knock out your opponent, which being on the opposing side would take a good 30 seconds to recover. After updates, hard blows and dive kicks seem to do almost nothing to the opponent, and when you do knock them out it still takes forever to recover. Two-handed weapons have no balance factor whatsoever, and the fact you can kill opponents with weapons alone is unacceptable. Each map, at least the Free for All maps, have their own ways of eliminating opponents, so you shouldn't have to resort to beating someone with a shovel or frying pan to death. Combat, surprisingly, is the least of my worries with this game.

I understand we're on the internet, and from time to time I come across some weird stuff and weird people, but with all the matches I've played I'm extremely appalled with the usernames and messaging that comes up on this game. I'm talking about racist, homophobic, sexist, and any other derogatory terms or phrases that come up in quick matches, and out of a handful of usernames I've had to report as inappropriate to moderation, they only got back to me on only 1 of them. While I understand that building a community is important, and every gaming community with games like these has their toxic side, they could do SO MUCH BETTER with their moderation.

What can I say that's good about the game? Well, before any updates, when I tried the tutorial the controls were easy to understand, but after the update they never went over moves that are critical to the game, like the dive kick for example. You can earn XP in Custom Matches, unlike in other games I've played with friends, so that's a plus. I like most of the outfits released for each character, although I wish I could mix and match the skins with the outfits instead of unlocking each combination separately. I wish I had anything else to say about this game on better note. I really wanna fall in love with this game, but if the player finds themselves relentlessly infuriated, I can't say this is a great game.

Like I said, this is a game meant for close friends and not for taking on complete strangers. You never know who you're gonna run into in these matches, and they could totally be using malicious behavior from playing dirty to saying something dirty. That said, even if you're playing with close friends, it wouldn't surprise me to see friendships getting shattered over a game like this because it's easy to get upset when someone is chasing you with a set of nunchucks and beating the hell out of you with them.

My personal rating for this game would be a 4/10. I see the potential and the positives, but it just gets overshadowed by the number of problems this game had before it even got released. I had a lot of hope for this game, and I hate to see most of that hope getting drowned out by anger and frustration. With that said, if you choose to spend the money to play this game, just remember...it's just a game, not your life.

I played this game about the first 2-3 weeks non-stop and i loved it. i could not stop laughing whilst playing with friends. accidentally knocking each other out or just fighting against your friends because they're on a different team was my highlight of the best things the game had to offer and i bet most people would agree. 

Now, I came back to the game about a month later and noticed that if you que up a game with more than 3 friends in your party it makes all maps 4v4 and no longer a 2v2v2v2. This ruins the game! it completely changes the pace of the game and makes it flat out boring. its slower and a lot less action is happening. i literally ended up turning on my team mates / friends and sabotaging them because i was so un-entertained. i played about 3 matches before getting so bored i just got off to play mw3. Although i see why the devs made this change. They didn't want 3 or more friends queing into a game together and teaming against other teams of 2, 
making it a 4v2v2. but i still think even if that's happening its not worth Entirely changing the pace of the game so that the 4v2v2's stopped occurring. 

I no longer think the game is fun and will uninstall after i post this, and i bet a huge portion the player base for this game has already done or are going to do the same! I almost wish i could refund and get my money back.

Not a whole lot needs to be said really about the core game itself, what you see in the screenshots and video on the store page sums it up very well, its a simple game, don't think too much about it. Just goofy looking animals beating the crap out of each other on different maps, game has a bunch of skins (Yes it has microtransactions) that you can unlock by simply playing, the microtransactions don't seem to be too bad, from what I can tell you can unlock any skin for free but it'll be roughly 70% of skins at which point you hit a road block.

It does have some flaws though, here they are.

1. You can select your server/region, that's great! Unfortunately the game often likes to completely ignore what server you have selected and instead puts you in a random server on the other side of the planet for seemingly no reason. Its frustrating and needs fixing, so far no response from the developers.

2. The achievements are bad, like REALLY bad, some achievements require you to play custom games with friends, good luck if you play this game solo, there's lots of achievements that have silly requirements like this, very poorly designed. The devs seem to think everyone plays this game in local co-op or has 8 friends to play with. Why is this an issue? Because many skins are locked behind achievements, see that skin you like? You're not getting it, awesome right?

3. Leaving game nets you a two minute time penalty from playing the game again, the developers think this is some highly competitive game, now I get the idea behind this there's just one problem, remember point one? About how the game puts you in the wrong region? Yeah well if the game does that and you leave because you don't want to play with 300 ping (What sane person does?) then enjoy the punishment.

4. The game is extremely inconsistent, say you get knocked into the icy water, one time you get in the water and literally one second later you're frozen (AKA dead) but another time it gives you like five seconds, there is zero consistency here and you're at the mercy of whether the game hates you or not. The other issue with this is that there is ZERO indication of how long you can be in these dangerous areas, the game severely lacks information for the player.

5. The camera isn't very good, its WAY too zoomed in and there are absolutely no options to change camera settings, strange because on some maps the camera likes to zoom out far, the camera is completely borked, we seriously need camera options, its bad, like real bad.

That's really it for my major flaws, other than this, game is excellent but I'm not too sure how much the developers care about the feedback, hopefully these things are addressed in the near future.

Party Animals is an absolute gem in the world of multiplayer party games, and I can't emphasize enough how much fun I've had playing this game on Steam. From the moment I dove into the wacky world of floppy animals, I was hooked, and it's been a non-stop rollercoaster of laughter and enjoyment ever since.

First and foremost, Party Animals boasts a delightful and charming visual style that's sure to put a smile on your face. The adorable, physics-based animals are incredibly expressive, and their floppy movements are as comical as they are endearing. It's impossible not to giggle as you watch your clumsy character stumble, flop, and tumble through the various game modes and environments.

The game offers an impressive array of game modes and maps, each with its own unique set of challenges and absurdity. Whether you're duking it out in melee combat, engaging in team-based antics, or attempting to overcome obstacle courses, Party Animals keeps the excitement levels cranked up to 11. The maps are creatively designed, offering a perfect blend of chaos and strategy.

What truly sets Party Animals apart is the sheer unpredictability and uncontrollable mayhem that ensues when you and your friends are thrown into the mix. The physics-based gameplay leads to hysterical and often bizarre moments that you'll be reminiscing about long after you've logged off. It's the kind of game where friendships are tested, rivalries are formed, and everyone gets a chance to bask in the glory of their ludicrous victories and defeats.

The customization options are a fantastic touch, allowing you to dress up your animals in all sorts of zany outfits, adding an extra layer of hilarity to the gameplay. It's a blast to see your friends' ridiculous fashion choices and accessories in action during the games.

The online and local multiplayer options work seamlessly, ensuring that you can enjoy the madness with friends near and far. The matchmaking system is quick, and the netcode is stable, which means you'll spend more time laughing and less time waiting.

The developers have done a stellar job of keeping Party Animals fresh with regular updates and new content, demonstrating their commitment to creating a thriving and enjoyable community around the game.

In conclusion, Party Animals on Steam is an absolute riot, a carnival of laughter, and one of the most enjoyable multiplayer party games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. If you're looking for a game to entertain your friends, family, or even strangers online, look no further. It's an unforgettable experience that guarantees a night full of belly laughs and good times. Get ready to embrace the chaos and dive into the world of Party Animals‚Äîyou won't be disappointed!

In the world of video games, there are countless options available to players seeking entertainment and excitement. However, Party Animals is not one of them. This game falls short in terms of creativity, gameplay mechanics, and overall enjoyment.

Firstly, Party Animals lacks originality. The concept of animals engaging in various party activities may seem appealing at first glance, but it quickly becomes monotonous. The game fails to introduce new challenges or innovative features that would keep players engaged for an extended period.

Moreover, the gameplay mechanics are incredibly repetitive. The tasks assigned to players are limited and quickly become predictable. Whether it's racing against other animals or engaging in simple mini-games, the lack of variety makes Party Animals a tedious experience.

In conclusion, Party Animals fails to deliver an exciting and engaging gaming experience due to its lack of originality, repetitive gameplay mechanics, and overall lackluster presentation. With so many other options available on the market today, it is difficult to recommend this game as anything more than a forgettable distraction from more immersive gaming experiences

A Fun and Laid-Back Multiplayer Experience

I feel compelled to share my thoughts on Party Animals because, despite the mixed feedback it has received, I genuinely believe it's a pretty good game. It's important to note that many of the negative reviews may be related to misconceptions about local play, as the game actually requires an online connection. However, this shouldn't overshadow the fact that Party Animals offers a decent gaming experience.

The game's core loop revolves around a series of mini-games and fight rounds in a team format, with team sizes varying between two and four players based on the random matchmaking system. The standout feature is its ragdoll combat mechanics, which some might dismiss as purely luck-based. However, with practice, it becomes apparent that the game can be highly competitive when facing skilled opponents. While luck does play a minor role, mastering skills like quick weapon pickups, accurate drop kicks, and strategic player tossing depends more on player skill and feedback.

Admittedly, the game's progression can feel repetitive over extended play sessions, making it better suited for shorter, more casual gaming sessions. The inclusion of a free battle pass system is a nice touch, and despite the presence of microtransactions, I never felt pressured to make any purchases. Most of the items available for purchase are cosmetic, and the game generously provides free players with plenty of skins and items.

Like any online multiplayer game, the Party Animals community can be a mixed bag, with elements of toxicity and competitiveness, but it also has its share of friendly and helpful players. Ultimately, I'd recommend Party Animals to anyone looking for a simple, laid-back game where you can goof around without taking things too seriously.

In conclusion, Party Animals offers a fun and enjoyable gaming experience, especially for those seeking a relaxed multiplayer environment with moments of hilarity and skill. Give it a try, and you might be pleasantly surprised by what it has to offer.

and the cosmetics are actually good. every skin looks amazing and adorable.

but for that GRINDSET MINDSET grinders like me who does the weekly xp challenges can attest to how annoying it is to get certain challenges done.
ranging from knock outs with certain weapons not tracking, to literally not getting the one gamemode you need because everyone votes for LTS, challenges can kinda be stressful.

Despite the issues on launch, Party Animals has become my go-to for arcade brawling. It's fun, exciting, and looks amazing in terms of graphics. The way that the game balances skill and luck feels reminiscent of Super Smash Bros. or Mario Kart, where while the most skilled players will have the upper hand most of the time, the underdogs always have a chance to win big. The way that the game frames each KO with a satisfying thwack and slowing of time really gives your brain a dopamine rush that lots of other games don't replicate.
The progression in the game is steady and consistent, with the "battle pass" steadily drip-feeding you with money and skins to keep you invested. I personally love how even though you can unlock most skins in the battlepass, there's still the option to unlock them early if they go on the store's rotation. While some have pointed out the lootbox/gacha mechanic that exists, its never really pushed on the player to spend money on it as there are 2 other ways to get skins without having to pay up.
If there's one thing to not like about the game, its the poor local multiplayer implementation and always-online requirements. While I don't do couch co-op a lot, many people have bought this game specifically for that and were sorely dissapointed. The split screen is lazy with it not filling up the entire display, and you can't even play on the go since you have to always be connected to the internet. I won't judge the game because of this, but I do wish that the developers would be far more open about it as well as more motivated to fix the shortcomings rather than let them be. Every other aspect of the game is perfect, and these issues just hold it back a bit.

If you're looking for a couch co op masterpiece, this isn't it. However, if you don't care about that and you love games like Gang Beasts, this is it for you. With a well designed balance between skill and luck, this is easily one of the best party games of the year.

8/10

Fun, simple, and engaging. Quick enough that you can hop into a few solo-queue matches with minimal effort and enjoy a few wins (or losses!), and varied enough that you can enjoy 6-7 matches in a row without getting bored or feeling like the gameplay is repetitive. Exceptional co-op experience, and connecting with friends is a quick and smooth process. For $20, highly recommend!

developer_response:
Hi there, it's definitely weird that your frame rate dropped since latest update. We will need your log to further analyze the issue. Please follow the steps below to get the log:

1. Quit game.
2. Right click "Party Animals", then click "Properties". Type "-log" in the "Launch Options", and close the Properties window.
3. Restart the game. Then in Steam Library, right click "Party Animals ", then "Manage", then "browse local files". In the pop-up windows, you will see log files named "2023-xx-xx_xxxxxxxxx-Laptop Name". Each game session will generate one log.
4. Try to reproduce the issue and remember the time when you encounter it. Then quit the game, and ZIP all the log files.

Please go to our website https://support.partyanimals.com/login, and create a ticket with a topic describing the issue, and the time you encounter it. Then attach the zip file to the ticket and click send.

We will get back to you as soon as we find out what's going wrong.

Thank you for supporting Party Animals!

Party Animals is one of those non-committal games for when you want to have some silly fun with friends. It takes mere minutes to get the hang of and can support up to 8 players between humans and AI. There are quite a few maps and different game modes to experience, each with their own quirks and gimmicks. Get eliminated? Don't worry! After you're defeated, you'll spectate the rest of the round and influence it by throwing objects to disrupt the remaining active players.

This game does not have a high skill cap so it's not one you can really dedicate to and enjoy if you're just out to win. Its low skill entry and accessibility make it a true party game. If you're just looking for mindless fun with friends, win or lose, Party Animals does not disappoint.

The Pros:
+ Silly, mindless fun with up to 8 friends.
+ Low skill entry means anyone can be playing in minutes.
+ Gameplay and controls are quite smooth.
+ Very stable; I've not experienced any crashes.
+ Vast multitude of cosmetics and achievements. While microtransactions exist for cosmetics and characters (which are essentially skins themselves), they are mostly optional as just playing the game grants you in-game currency over time. There are zero pay-to-win aspects.

The Cons:
- To get the most out of this game, it's best to have friends playing. While doing Quickplay will get you into matches fast, having a group of friends to laugh with while you beat the crap out of each other really amplifies what this game provides.
- Everything requires online play; there are no offline lobbies, though games can be locked and played only with AI if desired. Losing internet makes the game unplayable.
- Reportedly, leaving Quickplay matches is harshly and overly penalized, though I've not utilized Quickplay myself to elaborate further.
- Due to how fast games can be with the current map roster, gameplay can get repetitive. Playing with different groups and cycling the game modes help to alleviate this.

All-in-all, treat Party Animals as it was meant to be; as a party game to play occasionally with people, not one to no-life and "get good at." Do that, and it will bring hours of laughter and countless moments to remember. I can't recommend it enough so long as you have group(s) to play it with.

This game is fun. Even solo I still enjoy this game. I disagree with people saying its bad due to having in game purchases, as most cosmetics are obtainable through a currency you easily earn by just playing. What really bothers me are the one-sided maps such as Ichiban. 
One-sided maps such as Ichiban and Ice Breaker are downright infuriating as a majority of the time, whoever got the weapon wins the round. The poison and Ice on various maps is frustrating as there is zero way of telling if you will suffocate or freeze. Every time you get knocked off you roll the dice on whether you die or scramble back to safety.
The more overpowered weapons causing issues have already been nerfed and even with the recent changes I can't see weapon nerfs getting to the root of the problem, which is how random suffocating, getting ko'd, or freezing feel. If we could see how much health we have. Perhaps in place of the stamina drain on your name tag it shows health instead. That way you know when a situation is too dangerous instead of having life dangled in front of you only to be snatched away because a shovel hit you one too many times.

TLDR: Add a health bar.

While we're at it: 
Add 4v4 as a mode you can vote for alongside map vote and add Final Destination + Winter Cabin to queue.

Party Animals has started [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1092066449658482789/1185604089720098836/image.png?ex=659036da&is=657dc1da&hm=5fc6e151544b3a26256f5a5d2275fcc38694699a5563cf25612cc04d1816e312&] restricting the rewards you get while playing [/url], meaning they actively stop you from grinding your level rewards and cookies earned. This feels incredibly arbitrary and absolutely uncalled for, especially since this wasn't restricted previously. People should be allowed to collect rewards they are playing for.

Original review included below:

There are a myriad of issues plaguing the game which personally makes it hard to recommend buying it in its current state. I really do enjoy playing, but game bugs are frustrating and spoil the experience. However, I'm glad there is transparency about issue reporting on the [url=https://forum.partyanimals.com/t/bug] official game forums. [/url]

Party Animals is a fun team-based minigame extravaganza. Together with a team of 2-4, you hop into various minigames with silly and wonky physics to win new costumes, animals and other customization options. Across three game modes, you compete against each other on various different maps with fun little gimmicks.
If you've played CS(:S) minigames and Mario Party before, this game is definitely something fun for you!

Although the issues below can be seen as minor, the ones that I've experienced at least a multitude of times are:

[list]
    [*]Physics engine object issues such as the [url=https://storage.googleapis.com/rebos_american_hamburger_stash/iceberg.mp4] iceberg bits in Ice Breaker [/url] and [strike] [url=https://storage.googleapis.com/rebos_american_hamburger_stash/bomba_bridge.mp4] Beat-Up Bridge [/url] [url=https://storage.googleapis.com/rebos_american_hamburger_stash/another_bomba_bridge.mp4] spazzing out [/url] [/strike] resolved)
    [*]Hands / paws targeting issues such as grabbing onto players in range and  [url=https://storage.googleapis.com/rebos_american_hamburger_stash/grabbing_issues_2.mp4] climbing [/url]  [url=https://storage.googleapis.com/rebos_american_hamburger_stash/grabbing_issues.mp4] structures [/url]
    [*]Audio/visual issues such as camera in terrain clipping, [url=https://storage.googleapis.com/rebos_american_hamburger_stash/camerabug.mp4] random camera snapping [/url], game audio drop-outs, erroneous sound effects, layer synchronization and mixing
    [*]Game rewards issues such as problems gifting friends items, and tracking, redeeming off-platform game rewards
[/list]

For the average player these issues probably aren't problematic, especially if you're just looking to have fun with friends. If you're looking to unlock as many animals and customization options as possible though, issues like these can be seen as frustrating as they can hinder your efforts.
I hope that game issues will be resolved over time. I will change my review accordingly when improvements are made!

This game is okay, it's super INCONSISTENT with everything though, you can have matches where people can punch you from one side of the map to the other, all-the-while you do punches which roll off their bodies as if your fists were coated in grease. I've had people Kill (Grey screen) my character at the start of the match in ONE punch. I've drop kicked people and made direct contact only to slide off them like I were a pillow. Oh and when you knock them out for them to get back up in the blink of an eye but you get knocked out and you're down for what feels like hours.

Oh and don't get me started about the danger zones like water on the ice map where people can seemingly swim LAPS in the water without freezing; to then fully recover, only for me to dip my pinky toe in there and freeze immediately. 

when others are able to freely run in the snow on the cabin map AT NIGHT which is when you're supposed to freeze, yet I step away from the campfire to be a Popsicle immediately.  I honestly think this game is rigged in some bs way. 

If I hadn't been talked into keeping this by friends, I would have definitely refunded.

The game is very fun, but immediately unfun when you knock someone down and they get up in 2 seconds, then you get light punched and you're out in 5 seconds, thrown out of the ring in 2, and dead in 1. The game needs a knockout ring timer or some form of understanding as to why there's so much inconsistency with knockouts. This inconsistency spreads elsewhere, one second I'm tossing someone in the ice and they swim for a good 3 seconds, climb up, get knocked down in the water and are able to climb out once more, then if I get pushed off within those 3 seconds I'm froze, there are many examples of this and it makes the game very unfun when at its core it's a pretty enjoyable party game with some really fun games, but it's just too much, maybe in future updates......but I have a weird feeling that this is something that'll remain very much the same game with no major QoL changes or updates made but I'd like to be wrong and I'd like to change my review if those things happen along with it.

At first I was hesitant spending $20 on a game from a new Dev team and also seeing the negative reviews. Do NOT listen to the negative reviews. This is gang beast on steroids. No pay for skins bs (like alot of games nowadays), you unlock skins, bones and dollars so fast it actually gives you the ability to use the item shop without having to spend irl money. Playing online is really great, haven't faced any connection issues. The game mechanics are great, not perfect, but still really good. 2 minute timeout makes sense. You leave a game YOU started, you are gonna get a timeout. If you can't wait 2 mins you need to learn how to have patience. Solid game worth the $20. Split screen is a little wonky, I won't lie but this is the early 2000's with LAN parties anymore. I get the complaint but it still works. Solid game all around 8.3/10

Editing this to be at least a little bit more helpful rather than just a scrubquote:

The game is fun, absolutely, but there are two (edit, now 4) things that make it unbearable to play online for more than one or two matches at a time unless you want to play custom lobbies with a group of friends that aren't as sweaty as random people on the internet:
[olist]
    [*] [b]Lack of feedback when engaging with any of the combat mechanics.[/b] You‚Äôll struggle when throwing a punch, performing a dive kick, headbutting and when lifting someone else up, constantly, all the time. There‚Äôs no way of telling if your running punch will throw someone into the stratosphere or your character is just going to rub their hairy fist all over your opponent‚Äôs face, nor will you ever tell if your dive kick is going to connect or you‚Äôre getting KO‚Äôd by someone else‚Äôs face the second you touch them midair, or much worse, get KO'd by the floor right next to them, setting you up to get grabbed and thrown off at any arena type map. Even at full stamina, everything is just guesswork. 
Oh yeah also good luck grabbing someone with both hands first try when everyone in the lobby is trying to kick your face.

    [*] [b]A matchmaking system that throws you against anyone, anywhere, completely disregarding your set region and much less your amount of skill.[/b] I‚Äôm South American, so I set my region to that. It‚Äôs already bad we all get lumped up in servers run in the single country that doesn‚Äôt speak the same language as most of the continent does, but that‚Äôs irrelevant considering that in 1 out of 3 matches I get sent to the States anyways, with 150 to 200ms of ping, making interactions with anything close to impossible. And even if I do get a good match, I‚Äôll get my party filled with a random who just installed against 3 teams of experienced players, either that or I get to fill on 4v4 against a full premade team.

    [*] [b]Random chance things just kill you on knock down.[/b] Threw a dive kick on round start? Die. It's that simple. If someone happens to graze your head as you fly by, you could just die. Get crushed? Die deader. There's no way to prepare for this, just pray that god will not smite you this round.

    [*] [b]Matchmaking penalties leave you locked to the queue even if it didn't yet find a match.[/b] You know what's so fun of casual games? Getting locked in matches where you have to just play the same map for the 5th time, or even better, getting a matchmaking penalty for joining and leaving the queue "too quickly." If you're gonna FORCE me to play matches in maps I don't even want to play, give me a rank or something, because that's just competitive queue.
[/olist]

Party Animals is super fun to play with friends. It's great being able to team up against other parties and try to yeet the opposing team off the maps. The downside is, you may lose some friendships when your own teammates start knocking you out on accident :)

Party Animals is a fun game with creative levels and cute characters you can earn through leveling, including additional costumes that can be earned through achievements or the shop as well. So in that sense, there is a lot of variety in which a player can choose and earn through progression. 

However there is a lot of unexplained bs I find myself experiencing the longer this game exists and I play it. I'm discovering I mostly experience this on a handful of last stand maps which include Ichiban, Winter Is Coming, Wind Tunnel, and Gator Valley. Ichiban seems to suffer from irregular and varied windows in which the player will be instantly knocked out from a punch or item used by another player. Not to mention it feels I have significantly less time to jump back up out of the gas than others players do, even dying within a second after losing consciousness regardless if I did before I was thrown down there. Winter is Coming is one of the most bs levels I've played given it seems I freeze a lot quicker than others players do at the end game while they can get up instantly or roll back without ever freezing at the end way too often to not be noticed. I see this happen on variety of other levels as well mentioned above at times including a handful of team levels. I don't know if that's due to anything in particular but it's becoming more apparent the longer I own this game. 

Because of that alone, I find myself playing this game less and less due to the bs luck people get in general. As mentioned, they are able to wake from knockouts, get back onto ledges, or even roll back into play before timeouts on various levels way quicker than I can. I don't want to hear the "lack of skill" and that kinda crap. I've played this game during Beta over 20 hours including the version from a couple years ago. It wasn't this bad at the start but you notice it more obviously the longer you play, whether a session or playing the game for a number of weeks. I'm seeing a game become less fair in non team games the longer I play this game. Sadly that means it's becoming a crappier product unless it's 4v4 a lot of the time to balance out the unexplained bs.

Would I recommend the games? Yes. However I can't say I tend to have much fun outside of 4v4s with a friend as randoms are insufferable to deal with as your team mates in a 2v2 setting or the fact they expect you to fully carry them.

This game deserves every negative review it gets and more, there is not a single skillful thing about this game. You can knock yourself out by landing on your ass, they've completely gutted headbutting and hit accuracy in general. You are more often punished for playing aggressively / trying to defend yourself than you are rewarded, between knocking yourself out constantly with headbutt, which USED to be a valid offensive strategy 3 years ago, and matches where people will  gang up on you whether they're on the same team or not, you are never fully in control. This game at its core is a "party game" but every single element besides its randomness (in my opinion, inconsistency is a better word) sets it up to be as competitive as possible, and the majority of the community acts and treats it like this.

Input delay on both KB/M and controller is incredibly noticeable. (This wasn't a thing 3 years ago during very early alpha playtests). It's something I thought would be an issue only at launch but it appears to be here to stay for good and is really one of the main reasons for this negative review. All of my data, controller inputs included, must be sent and reviewed by China before being allowed to be used in game I suppose. Picking a region of play where I have low ping makes no difference and this input delay is even noticeable in the tutorial which shouldn't involve an internet connection at all yet I still have input delay that makes having any sort of reaction time useless. I would compare this delay to having a ping of well over 200ms at all times. I am constantly playing with/against people who are not in my region which is simply obvious based on their usernames and the languages they speak, which can range anywhere from Spanish, Chinese, Japanese, Russian and French, which makes me wonder if choosing a region for matchmaking is even a thing or just a placebo.

Most of the last stand maps are sub-par at best, with some of them like Typhoon being a complete waste of everyone's time by its map design and mechanics alone. The sports team game-modes are very boring and are also a massive waste of time, and when they end in draws (which is common because the scores required to "win" these matches are higher than they need to be so they drag on forever) no one wins anything which just further cements time wasted.

The ability to throw objects at players when you're eliminated is possibly the worst game feature they've added since the alpha 3 years ago. In most cases when you have been eliminated you can easily decide the fate of one if not multiple players with this absolutely brain-dead, easy to use system. This mechanic also further promotes playing passively as the more people you knock out the more people you have throwing things at you and angry at you next round. It takes no skill, does not feel rewarding, and is absolutely rage inducing to be on the receiving end. In rare cases your reticle for aim is completely inaccurate and things you're throwing will go no where near where you are aiming. It is not a function of the "random party game" elements they have in place but rather it is consistently awful in certain scenarios where it just wasn't tested or the devs just don't care. There should be a queue for players who don't want this mechanic so the game can have at least some semblance of reward for being skilled instead of punishing you for playing well.

There is a 2 min quick match ban for leaving any match for any reason, even if your own teammate is greifing you because they're part of a 3-queue in a 2v2v2v2 game mode. There are people constantly cross-teaming to try and complete the achievements (most of which by their design encourage cross-teaming) that were made by idiots who in no way have ever actually even played the game before.

Speaking of a 2 min ban and why it's relevant, teammates are constantly AFK, and in pretty much every game mode this cements your loss. There is an AFK detection system that will kick these people, but it's easily bypassed by just pressing a button on your controller every once in a while. I guess these people want EXP while doing other things but when you lose you hardly get rewarded at all so they're literally just wasting other peoples time. You can report these people and they will not be banned, I have seen them weeks after meeting them initially doing the exact same thing as before. The bots that will replace your teammate if they do get kicked are completely useless (especially in sports game-mode, they will just walk off in random directions and run into walls) and sometimes even a hindrance, but by the time they're added in the damage is already done and you've lost anyways.

The loot box system in this game has duplicates, which you will roll plenty of, a low roll chance for "legendary" skins all of which look average compared to things that you can buy from the cosmetics store (most of which cost nemo bucks, or in rare cases just straight up dollars/euros) in the cosmetics store, and nemo bucks themselves are a finite resource that when you run out of you have no recourse other than paying real money if you didn't get the skin you want.

This doesn't even consider the absolutely scummy, extremely toxic and racist community. Text and especially Voice Chat between players is nothing but a negative experience as like I said earlier, everyone treats this game like its competitive, similar to shooters like CS:GO. People getting by with names that blatantly have an uncensored racist words in them and much more. The censorship for chat in this game is also hilarious, censoring words like "dumb" and "server". I have seen words that I will not repeat here that are not censored and definitely should be.

Also not even touching on the local co-op fiasco the game had when it first launched as it doesn't effect me, but really? "English isn't our native language" isn't an excuse for promising something and then delivering the opposite, you can't possibly tell me you don't have the funds to hire a decent translator or someone with an actual head above their shoulders that can go "i see you guys are saying you have local co-op, but it's no where to be found so are you sure that's what you meant?". It all just leaves a bad taste and screams incompetency. 

1 month after the game has released and there is nothing new and certainly nothing to look forward to. The cosmetic shops rotate the same cosmetics in the exact same order, all of the changes they've made via updates have had little to no impact on the game other than adding in 4v4s in last stand for 4 queues which i've heard a lot of people don't even like. 

The gameplay when you ignore all of these issues I've mentioned has become stale and repetitive, combined with the occasional AFK or cross-teamers this game just doesn't have good longevity and i wouldn't recommend it to anyone. The only reason I even bought this game is because the product it was 3 years ago was very promising, and what the game currently is is now is a shadow of what could have been a good game.

A very fun party game with friends. It's severely over-hated here on Steam. There are in-game purchases, which is a common complaint, but there is a very good reward system built into the game and a "battle pass" structure for players. Plenty of achievement based rewards and weekly/daily challenges to complete for XP and in-game currency. The mechanics of the game are fun as well, with a good variety of mini games/game modes in rotation. It's an E for Everyone game with a really unique art style that I really enjoy playing in a party with my buddies. Recommend to anyone looking for a fun game to incorporate into their gaming regiment. Have fun.

I can only recommend this game if you're blessed by RNGesus. Prepare yourself for spam based gameplay, the most obnoxious spectators in any game period, zero inkling of skill required to win, tedious achievements that borderline require brain dead opponents and a full coordinated team, unbalanced gameplay dictated by a dice roll of where things drop and how maps behave, and mashing for hours just so you can control your character for 2 milliseconds before getting knocked out by a single attack. 

Frankly I don't know how to fix everything due to most interactions being based on the physics engine, but a cooldown on being knocked out would be a fantastic start. Heavy punches should slow the character down to avoid the spamminess of people just sniffing your bum until you're KOed since you can't take the time to turn around without getting KOed, you can't sprint away since heavy punches not only don't slow you down, but actually speed the character up, and rolling in any direction can be countered by following with a roll or standing still to catch a backwards roll. Mashing to wake up should be replaced with a timer that starts when you please (since playing dead is a "mechanic") or a quick minigame, and you should know exactly how long you'll be knocked out for. Nunchuks need to have a higher probability of knocking yourself out, or be less consistent in KOing opponents. There's also an overall lack of consistency in landing blows, sometimes people will launch without getting KOed, other times you'll land 27 heavy punches or dropkicks (which are supposed to be an immediate KO) and you'll just bounce off every time like your opponent is a brick wall.

I want to love this game, and it's a ton of fun when it's fun, but it's very quickly becoming tedious to even play due to how easy it is to get get spammed to death all within seconds of the round starting. Oh also the soccer field is way too big and it turns into a rolling simulator. It's kind of wild how you can base a game so heavily off of Gang Beasts and have it be so much less consistent despite coming out years later.

All around, it's a great game with pretty decent replayability and brings out a bunch of laughs. Unfortunately, it seems like the devs really just do not care about the community's interests. Local Play is a mediocre experience with huge frame drops when using split screen (split screen already being a HUGE disappointment), the obvious predatory features like loot boxes/gacha/insane in-game currency prices in general, and there's no visible road-map provided on any of the game's social media pages; there really hasn't been any notable updates, besides minor bug fixes, within the month that it has been out. This game has a potential to be REALLY great considering it has such a vibrant artstyle and well-constructed maps, but it can be SO much better if the devs can manage to unplug their ears to hear the community.

Future Edit: The Party Animals website now links a forum where you can both ask questions, show your concerns, and even connect with developers through a "Q and A" format periodically. I believe they've become much more open with the community and seem to have strong plans for the future of this game. Please check it out! I can confidently say that I DO recommend this game now.

[h1] It's Party Time! [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

It's a hilarious game.  Just simply fun to play at the right moments.  Matches don't take long to find.  A lot of different skins and animals to chose from, and while there is an in-game store, it's not hard to get in-game currency to buy what you want.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

Some maps take forever to finish, like the soccer or football ones.  They aren't too fun after awhile.

Some maps are just bad entirely, so they are rarely picked.  Don't know how many total maps there are, but four or five are just never picked, so I've only experienced them a handful of times.

It's impossible to tell what is cheating and what is legit.  Some characters can move before timer counts down, seems to have longer life in places where other characters don't, etc.  The devs seem to lack communication in this area.  What has been implied is that some characters can be better than others - which is poor design.

The weekly quests are just bad.  Have to do one specific thing usually on a few specific maps.  It's frustrating and not fun.  They need to be more generalized, or randomized, so not everyone has to do the same thing.

Skin rotation is poor.  I've been waiting weeks for a skin to return.

Disconnects are more common in the middle of matches.  It's getting worse by the week.

Also, constant Twitch events instead of actually trying to improve the game.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

For now, keeping it installed when I want something a bit more lighthearted to play.  Hope they add more maps or change up existing ones to get more variety.  But I am seeing more flaws each week I play, so I am sure it's on life support with me at this point.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

You ever had a dream where you're trying to punch or push something, but you don't really have any force behind it so you just kind of end up swinging your arm casually over in their general direction? Or you try to say something, but you can't really make any noise, you just sort of whisper?

This game is like that. With everything. The punching, the climbing, the running and jumping, even the shooting. It's like you're in a dream where no matter what you try to do, you won't be able to do it. Like your muscles are made of microwaved playdough, you have motor control dysfunction in all parts of your body except your center mass, and you have no depth perception. And whatever you plan to do, will execute either miserably late, or at best, hilariously wrong, both of which, together, start to get real frustrating after only a few hours.

So if you're looking for the closest thing the video game industry has to the muppets drunken boxing each other, while the people under the table controlling the muppets are also drunk, look no further. Because the only way I can see this game being enjoyable is while being completely, utterly blasted. With friends. And at that point, any game that has online multiplayer will do, so it's not intended as praise. 

Save your money. Buy another bottle of whatever you were intending to drink to make this game fun in the first place, then drink it and play something else.

It has been a crazy ride! After all and all, I finally aced the achievements! I always wait for full achievements to make a review, this one has just been one of the tougher ones, if not the toughest! 

I really admire this game in most of the aspects. You don't often get a game that is this replay-able, this carefully designed and this well-executed. As a party game it has the right vibe --- the competitive aspect works just fine, not too much nor too light. On the other hand, the physics in the game hits different --- It may look just like some other games which I won't name, but you have to play it to know how different they are. Not to mention the cute visuals --- Probably is what attracts people in the first place! 

While the game is casual, the achievements are quite challenging. As much as I struggled with some of them, I have to say they are well designed. They provide a sufficient amount of challenges, and in the mean time fun to attempt and does not ruin the game for you teammates (for the most part, some of them does require you to be a little selfish).

There has been many controversies around the game. The price does prevent a significant amount of my friends from joining me. The devs may not have taken the right response in many occasions. However, rarely do I see a hateful comment on the game itself: almost everyone agrees this game is great to begin with. Some may think overpriced, some may hate the micro-transactions, but that does not hinder its outstanding gameplay!

Overall I would recommend this to my friends (which I already did), but also to any of you who stump upon this review. I wish this game could give you sufficient amount of joy, I meant it wholeheartedly.

[h1] Can be incredibly fun, but more often than not it's just frustrating. [/h1]

The controls work only after you figure out exactly how they work, (no thanks to the tutorial), because of how it's designed. To throw a person, it's not just grab them and face a direction and press x (or whatever on a KB and Mouse), you have to anticipate the momentum the person and yourself have and then sort of slingshot them in the direction you want.

Now with that in mind, you have people spending their entire days and nights figuring out how to micro-manage these tiny details so they can do a combination of button presses to fly across the level to knock you out within 5 seconds of the round starting and toss you 15 meters into the nearest pit because they're just learned how to be [i] that guy [/i] in a game designed like this.

Again, has an amazing potential, has been a lot of fun with friends, but it saddens me that every time we play it always ends with frustration because of one guy in the lobby who's spent an abnormal amount of hours in this game eliminates us all within seconds and abuses niche mechanics that aren't taught to players in the tutorial.

One final thought that's been apparent to me is that the game offers very little to no feedback to the player during playtime. You'll only ever know if you knocked another person out or if they knocked you out and if you're dead. 
This causes so much frustration because half the time you don't know if you're doing anything my swinging at another player and you feel as though the game begins implementing an RNG element here you have a 50/50 chance to knock someone out on a hit. Idk, maybe a skill issue, but some more feedback regarding play actions would be sooo incredibly appreciated.

I am a 40 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for his birthday from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. This game is lots of fun with friends. Reviews had me worried about the monetization model, but the in-game currency is super easy to obtain. I already have a collection of cute skins from leveling up and completing achievements. There's plenty of toxicity in voice chat, but that's pretty easy to disable (not sure why open mic is on by default?) Also, I hope the people who want an offline mode eventually get that, but, for me personally, I don't have much of a need for it. If that's a concern of yours, maybe hold off of buying. Overall, I think the game's worth it if you enjoy online party games and general low-stakes fun. Party Animals is one of the few games that's made me actually laugh out loud in recent memory :)

Dev's promoted this game as including the ability to play online as well as offline with friends.
They then released the game with online-only, blamed their user base for taking their own Steam page description at face-value, then doubled-down saying they never intended and will not provide an offline mode.

The Dev's lack of taking responsibility and instead blaming the community doesn't sit right with me, which is the primary reason I refunded the game.

I will recommend the game once I see evidence the Dev's are listening to, and more importantly, catering to their user base.

2v2v2v2 IS STILL IN THE GAME

It was never removed, all the devs did was make it so groups of 3 or more can't play 2v2v2v2 because that would allow for an unfair advantage. My guess as to why these people are complaining are either because they wanted to ruin the fun of solo/duo players (with either teaming up against said players or just holding a match open for as long as possible) or they just want to hate this game.

as for my thoughts on the game, it's pretty good. I really like how floppy the animals are, the fighting doesn't require that much skill, and the different maps always bring something new to the fight, so it's not just "punch animal and win". I still have yet to decide on the monetisation in the game though.

The Item Shop presents a bunch of skins in 2 areas: Daily rotation, and Weekly rotation. The skins will either cost Cookies (which are earned through playing the game) and Nemo bucks (which you can buy, but can be earned through challenges and the levelling system (which is a "battlepass" but with no premium track)). You can also earn skins through a gacha system, using Egg tokens which are earned through the levelling system or just bought with Nemo bucks.

I would be lying if I said I wasn't mixed on it. On one hand, it's free-to-play monetisation in a paid game, which is incredibly greedy, but on the other hand, they give you the currencies without having to buy anything (although it's limited to the current "pass"/level track, which doesn't have a timer, so who knows when that'll change). There's also no benefit to buying any skin, but I also sit in the camp that hates the saying "it's just cosmetics, they give no advantage", especially in a game where there is no progression outside of the levelling, so cosmetics are the only thing we have.

If the devs are so dead set on having this monetisation though, I do think there should be one more compromise, one that will at least reduce the hatred for the gacha system and the game as a whole. Allow us to use our cookies to buy Egg tokens, even if it's a high price. The gacha is set up to guarantee a legendary every 70 rolls (as in you will get a legendary at 70, not one of those false one's where they say you should get it at 70) and an Epic at 10 rolls. This is incredibly greedy with the current system, but if we can use cookies to get Egg tokens, it will at least give us the satisfaction of having earned the legendary rather than feeling like we're gambling away our money.

TLDR: If you don't care for skins and you're looking for a party game to play with a group of friends, I recommend it, but if you hate greedy monetisation so much that you can't stand to even play a game that has it, don't bother.

I'll update this review later, when I've done more stuff in the game and more has been added. I mostly threw this together to push against the idea that 2v2v2v2 was gone, and the rest of it is just stuff I thought should be mentioned for anyone who's considering buying it.

Party Animals is a physics-based multiplayer brawler that has been eagerly anticipated by many gamers. However, the game's launch has been met with disappointment, as it is plagued by a number of issues, including:

Server problems: Players have been reporting frequent server disconnections and difficulty finding matches.
Lack of offline mode: This is a major oversight for a party game, as it means that players cannot play with friends without an internet connection.
Microtransactions: The game features a number of microtransactions for cosmetic items, which are expensive and feel predatory, especially for a game that is still in early access.
Lack of content: The game currently has a limited number of maps and game modes, which can lead to the gameplay becoming repetitive quickly.
In addition to these issues, the game also suffers from a number of performance problems, such as frame drops and stuttering.

Overall, Party Animals is a game with a lot of potential, but it is currently in a very rough state. The developers have promised to address many of the issues, but it is unclear how long this will take. Until then, I would recommend waiting to purchase the game.

The game was good on release. But when the 1.1.1.0 update came out, there was hit box issues and climbing issues. It's almost as if the game took a step back into the beta. Kinda sad. It was good and now it's really not fun. You can't really overlook it either to enjoy the game. The issues take control of the fun now.

Hit-Boxes (MAJOR)- Sometimes it feels as if certain characters can hit harder than others and some characters can just tank hits. I knocked out a Gorilla with a hard punch and it only made him just fall over. But when he hits me I get thrown across the map and the punch would barely touch me. Sometimes hits don't even connect and it gets frustrating.

Climbing-Sometimes when you are about to die and try to climb, your character will just not climb or jump a millimeter in length and it's so frustrating. You have to let go and risk the chance of dying to try and climb again but it's not definite that it won't bug out.

NOTE-The release for the game had none of these issues. It was a lot of fun. Nothing in the patch notes had anything to do with touching these elements but it didn't matter. They added the fish back but what does that have to do with the elements of gameplay? The fish destroyed the game? I don't know.

Game is fun but I am noticing some inconsistencies after the latest update.  These various occurrences have made the game less enjoyable and make is seem as though it lacks balance.

I have had several punches and flying kicks land but the person I hit absorbs the blow and keeps moving like nothing happened.  This is also true when using weapons against other players.  They eat the weapon shot, and keep moving like nothing had happened.  Yet on the other hand, I've been knocked out by a punch mid roll away from said player, and I've even witnessed players being knocked unconscious when someone with a weapon was not even swinging.

The second thing that seems to be very inconsistent if the amount of time people are unconscious for.  Whether it is a kick, weapon, or punch, I have watched some players recover much faster than others which makes me question what the actual game design around these actions are.  Is it certain moves leave you KO'd longer or is it just RNG on how long you're out for.  I hit someone with a flying kick, and they were not even out long enough for me to grab them, yet they stand up, punch me, and I'm out long enough for them to throw me twice after failing the first.  

Lastly, on certain maps, some players seem to survive longer than others in deadly conditions, such as poison, and frost.  I've been tossed in as the game just starts and instantly died.  Other times I've watched players get knocked out into the deadly conditions, sleep it off, get knocked out again, sleep it off again, then climb/run right back into the fight.  How is that balanced?  

All of this seems to be more prevalent after the latest update, and has made the game less enjoyable to play because it makes you feel like the cards are stacked against you sometimes.  

Honestly, some changes I think would benefit everyone are a KO timer, a visible health bar so you know when you can and can't take certain fights, and then making some of these maps more like Broken Arrow where if you get thrown off, you're out.  Allowing some players to climb back into the fight and not others seems unfair and unbalanced.

EDIT: So, it turns out that I am very silly and don't pay attention. I have now played over 8 hours of the game and I'm loving it.
There are some annoying parts where it feels like the game is being unfair, and the "dead player throwing" system needs some work. When throwing things, there is nearly zero percent chance that you will hit someone with something you have thrown. The bombs also take over 5 seconds to explode, which is enough time for even someone that is unconscious to wake up and move.
The game is fun and I am enjoying it a lot. Now, we just need some new maps and game modes!!!

This is an extremely fun game if you have a local group of friends and wanna play with them. Probably one of the best local play games to release recently.

However, it is apparent that this game was designed with online play in mind first and it was quite difficult for me to learn how to start a local co op games with my friends.

If you are someone who likes to play local co op games however this is a good pick up for you.

I'm going to go against the grain on this one and say I'm not really having fun at all. I wish I had refunded. This could be cute with a bunch of friends, but my experience is mostly solo or duo quick match. 

Not a fan of map voting for only one game being played. Why aren't there multiple game mode rounds with the same people on varying maps? Most of my matches people pick the same favorites and there's some maps I haven't gotten a chance to try. 

Too many teammates afking or deliberately trolling matches. I get that it's a chaotic game and you're going to accidentally punch someone here or there, but I can tell when a teammate continues to hunt you down and throw you off the edge it's intentional. If you dare leave you're the one getting punished with a que ban, really? Being held hostage in bad matches isn't fun.  

The controls aren't for me, they feel frustrating half the time. l2p issue, get good etc I know. Nothing feels worse than getting kicked at the start of the match when you've barely loaded in and you can't even recover before being eliminated before you got to play. 

Minor gripe: I don't know why a minute of character select is necessary for such a short game. People scrolling through their skins without picking until the timer runs out. Just pre-select what you want to play as and move on. Feels like I spend more time waiting on load screens than actual action. 

It's disappointing because I was hoping for something cute and lighthearted in the same realm of what Fall Guys felt like. The animals, game modes, and humor is there, but core game play isn't enjoyable for me. Again, this is likely better with a friend group.

A lot of problems right now

- Cryo and Taser should NOT spawn on Broken Arrow because it can easily make one team win the whole round/game
- The projectiles thrown when you are dead rarely go where your cursor is pointed. I have hit several teammates because of this and have been accused of throwing
- Grabbing works 40% of the time when trying to climb up ledges, especially on Icebreak where it feels like only 10% of the time
- No indication if a game is going to be 2 or 4 teams during map select
- I have randomly been killed by teammates on maps like Typhoon who hit me once with a shovel accidentally and I die on the spot, not even being launched off of the submarine
- People were abusing a bug on turbine to survive while underneath the platform
- Hit detection can sometimes be like butter where you will just fly over someone. You'll just fly past them into the oblivion
- Having achievements be earnable by purchasing in game currency. Yes you don't HAVE to but the fact you can is disgusting.
- Other achievements are broken. I've won achievements for for the 4 team scenarios when I am in a 2 team game
- Beastball only has 11 rounds because some players will just instantly score a touchdown
- Turn off voice chat before you play casual. It's horrendous. I have been called every racial slur in the book by people who will use the gorilla character to roleplay as racial caricatures of black people. 
- Teammates LOVE to go afk or throw. Yeah it's not just this game, this happens in most multiplayer games. But it is especially detrimental here.

The irony is that this game was delayed yet it still has more bugs than an entomologist.

The game is a lot of fun if you play with your children or friends, and you don't get "competitive". 

But if you play online it's very frustrating. The fight mechanics are very hit and miss and often very random, and it becomes rather annoying that the 'dead' players can hit you with stuff after they've died. If you are the best at fighting, you still lose often because the dead players kill you by throwing objects.

The real downside of the game is the maps, or the lack of. First of all, they are not well thought out, and the maps that are not just fighting are so pointless. They are all about trying to carry things, and not fun at all. You can tell because they never get voted for.  

So at the end of the day, there's nothing but fighting to this game, and that gets old because of the lack of variety with the maps.

If it wasn't for the fun I have playing with my kids, I'd probably give it a thumbs-down.

Woof woof! Oh boy, oh boy! I gotta tell you about this game I've been playin' with my pals lately. It's called Party Animals, and let me tell ya, it's a real tail-waggin' good time!

First things first, Party Animals is all about fun and silliness. It's like a big, virtual playdate for humans. You and your buddies can join in and have a howlin' blast together. Whether you're barkin' up a storm in a wrestling ring, racin' through wild obstacle courses, or just goofin' around, there's never a dull moment.

The best part is that it's super easy to pick up, even for a pup like me. The controls are simple, so even if you're not a pro gamer, you can jump right in and start chasin', grabbin', and tossin' stuff around. It's perfect for playin' with your friends, whether they're seasoned gamers or newbies.

The graphics are colorful and cartoony, just like a Saturday morning cartoon. The characters are a bunch of cuddly critters, and you can dress 'em up however you like. I mean, who wouldn't wanna see a cute dog like me dukin' it out with a stylish kitty or a dapper bunny? It's a fashionista's dream come true!

One thing I gotta mention is the laughter. Oh boy, the laughs are non-stop! The wacky physics and unexpected mishaps will have you rollin' on the floor laughin'. It's like a virtual comedy show where you and your friends are the stars.

And don't even get me started on the party modes! You can team up, go head-to-head, or just free-for-all. It's like a never-ending dog park full of surprises.

So, if you're lookin' for a pawsitively good time with your pals, Party Animals is the game to fetch. It's a riot of giggles and guffaws, and you'll be waggin' your tail with joy from start to finish. Just remember to have some tasty treats on hand for a post-game celebration. Woof woof!

First off, the animals in this game are so incredibly adorable, the face they make when they are knocked out is just soooo cute.

The controls are awkward and delayed on purpose, this is to make it so that players of all skill level can enjoy this party game, you learn to pick things up and efficiently throw after a while, but it is still mostly luck. I'd say 30% skill. 70% luck. The overall clunkyness can lead to some pretty funny situations, definitely more fun to have the controls this way than to have it precise.

There are micro transactions in this game, but they are for cosmetics only, if you care about having the rarest/limited edition skins, you can sink a lot of money into it. The skins are aesthetics only, they do NOT give any advantages whatsoever or change the hit box of the characters. You can get in game currency, (both paid and non-paid) as you level up, and use it to unlock new outfits/characters. This is the only use for currency in this game. 

There is no local coop, your friends must also purchase a copy, I don't see this as a deal breaker though. (Like many people do)

The game itself is a lot of fun - my friends and I have definitely been enjoying it. 

That being said, it's another cash grab unfortunately. I see no good reason why a game for children would even have $25 skins available. 
It also has the microtransaction gambling that has become a huge problem for young gamers and is disheartening to see another developer do the same thing in 2023. If the game were free i might understand, but - it's not.

This game is great. Microtransactions are just cosmetic. If it keeps the developers making new content then I'm all for it. I don't get why people bitch about microtransactions if it isn't pay to win. I'd rather it be a 19.99 game with microtransactions for cosmetics than a 59.99 game with all skins.  I been playing for only 9 hours and never spent a single penny and already unlocked a lot of uncommon/rare skins just by leveling up and using the in game currency awarded to me for free. Only downside is its not a couch coop game and and its online only. If you have discord friends to play with then its a no-brainer to buy this game. If you're only looking for an offline-experience then I'd wait till that becomes a thing. Feel free to add me if you'd like to join me and friends play :D

patch 1.1 made the game worse.

Unable to play the 2v2v2v2 maps as 2v2v2v2 and instead it's all 4v4. Which sure would be fine if you were as 4, but playing as a duo and getting teammates that find trolling is the most fun thing to do just ruins the experience.

Now the main reason for not recommending the game. The devs showed even more that the game is nothing more than a cashgrab. daily/weekly rotation shop is still a mix of in game earned currency and premium currency, the only store being rotation means you'll get FOMO for skins and if you want to try to get a specific skin you want you'll have to gacha with premium currency. Granted you can earn some by playing the game but it caps out at a relative lowly number, at lvl 54-55 I dont think I got more than 2.2-2.5k with a lot of achievements that earned them too and a legendary skin is over 3000 premium currency in the rotation shop. Now they decided to speed up the milking of the playerbase by releasing a skin that is only available from direct purchase which clearly shows they just want some money fast and dont care about the game having any form of longitivity. 

So in all reality I can only say, the game is not worth the 18$ price tag, it isnt even worth a 5$ price tag in its current state. If they want to insist on a premium currency in the store that they force FOMO on and include lootboxes they should make the game f2p. if they want to keep the price tag put all skins in a shop for premium currency and have the rotation one solely use the cookies to buy skins from and the fucking gacha should NOT be premium and instead be cookies again.

This game is fun at times, but mostly frustrating. Suffers from the typical live service game stuff, casual fun thrown out the window when folks who have been playing nonstop since launch join the lobby. Slurs on voice chat essentially every game, and while you can mute it altogether, I wish there was something that indicated who was speaking so they could be reported easily. Voice chat in general in this game is pretty pointless, and text chat doesn't work in a lot of mini-games so the game would be a lot better without both in my opinion. Pick-ups are pretty busted and cheap to use also.

Also, small gripe, the stamina wheel being at the top left is weird. I feel like having it at the bottom right would be much easier and functional for players.

Beautiful Graphics and design, along with amazingly crafted and goofy art style, Party Animals is the most fun I've had in a while. I've done cartwheels midair, get flung out of the map at terminal velocity, drop kick people, and dodge frying pans. The maps are great, but there are a need for a few more, and removing the "winter is coming" map. I also thought a better way to get Eggcoins, the currency in which you can spin for a random skin or 'style; for an animal. Also, it requires a good chunk of grinding to get cool rewards. Its also nice that they come out with (what I call the original style for the characters) a 'base skin', at least one, everyday in the shop, for a low-ish price of 900 cookies (can be more than that but that's what it usually is). The item shop resets at 11:00 for me, which is a super weird time in my opinion. Its weird how they chose the middle of the day when a lot of people are at work or school to change the shop, making them have to wait after whatever they're doing.Its (in my opinion) better than gang beasts, except for some of the controls. If you liked Gang Beasts, try this out, if you haven't tried gang beasts, try this game out. Its hilarious, except for some times I'm being serious and trying to get achievements. And, its a good time-spender.

If your still thinking about getting it, or have a general question from what I think or experienced, just comment on this post. Thanks for reading, and have a good day!

I thought I could have a nice time with fellow friends, enjoying a new game that seemed fun. But then the massive wave of disappointment washed over me and knocked me down. First things first, the multiplayer invites are a bit buggy. The password that is stated doesn't even work most of the times, so no one can join, and you're off to be lonely again. Luckly people (not me included) have the divine's blessing and get to join through discord without any issue, but lost children (like me) have to cry in the corner and have to beg the host to turn off the locked room for just a moment. I never felt this much of a begger than in this game. Secondly, the controls? Like how many times does this game need to know that I want to grab that damn weapon? I'm already menacingly standing above the weapon, having only the grip in my mind, but what does the game do? Bro, I'll grab that rock for you. I beg your pardon, game? I have never felt this rage in my body, just wanting to grab on this damn shovel. BRO I JUST WANTED THAT SHOVEL. Anyway, let's all calm down first. Okay, so I get the idea about the fun being squishy thing like in Gang Beast, but I'm not a fan of a squishy thing that trips over its own feet. Like at least learn to walk before you fight for your life, animal.

developer_response:
Hey there,

Sorry for the inconvenience. We will need your log to further analyze the issue. Please follow the steps below to get the log:

1. Quit game.
2. Right click "Party Animals", then click "Properties". Type "-log" in the "Launch Options", and close the Properties window.
3. Restart the game. Then in Steam Library, right click "Party Animals ", then "Manage", then "browse local files". In the pop-up windows, you will see log files named "2023-xx-xx_xxxxxxxxx-Laptop Name". Each game session will generate one log.
4. Try to reproduce the issue and remember the time when you encounter it. Then quit the game, and ZIP all the log files.

Please go to our website https://support.partyanimals.com/login, and create a ticket with a topic describing the issue, and the time you encounter it. Then attach the zip file to the ticket and click send.

We will get back to you as soon as we find out what's going wrong.

Thank you for supporting Party Animals!

My negative review doesn't fully display the picture, I'd love to be able to give this game a positive review to but don't think I can [b]yet.[/b] 
If you don't want to read the whole pros-cons list / essay, skip to the summary at the bottom.

[h2]Pros:[/h2]
- Easy to find a game, never had to wait more than 2 minutes at any time.

- Super fun with friends, it's a better, bigger version of gang beasts. 

- Good variety of maps. modes & weapons to make things interesting.

- Characters are cute and charming, the IP colabs are really well done. 

- Lots of replay-ability, this has become my groups "go-to" game for the past week.

- Matches are quick and easy to drop in & out.

- Overall great party game.

[h2]Cons:[/h2]
- No OCE/Aus or South America server, this makes the game very difficult to play with a ping of 160+ at least. If you're in this region you'll often find yourself starting match knocked out and all the other cons that come with playing on 180 ping.

- If you have a party of 3 we've found that it likes to consistently pair the same people up no matter who the party leader is or join order, it often leaves that third person the odd one out.

- Without frequent updates adding new maps, modes & weapons this game will probably not have much longevity, after 19 hours the magic is slowly starting to wear off.

- [b]Monetisation,[/b] don't really need to explain much more on this but after spending $30 on the game finding out skins you want are locked behind the combo of a store & mystery crates (in the form of eggs), leaves a little bit of a sour taste in your mouth, feels a lot like it's going to be made free-to-play at some stage.

- Overall toxicity, there's little censorship in the game, people can name themselves a variety of slurs without problem, but words like [i]Stinky[/i] & [i]Slayer[/i] are censored?

- No offline play, huge issue for a lot of people and the way they addressed it seemed quite disingenuous.


[h1]Summary: [/h1] The game has the building blocks to set it up to be amazing, it unfortunately falls short at the moment but it's nothing it can't fix.
The introduction of new servers, offline play, map & modes and removal of monetisation are all things that could be added or fixed in future updates.

[i]If[/i] you're someone who's on the fence about buying the game or your friends are trying to gaslight you into getting it even though you think you won't enjoy it, I'd say your best bet would be to wait a month or so and keep an eye on the updates & see if the reviews take an upturn. 

[i]If[/i] you have the disposable income, friends[i](optional)[/i] live somewhere there's a server & this won't stop you from buying another game this month, go for it. It's a super fun game best enjoyed with other people not focusing on being competitive I guarantee you'll have a good time.

If you told me a year ago that I'd be addicted to a game where cuddly creatures engage in chaotic brawls, I would've laughed. But here I am, countless hours into "Party Animals," still laughing and having an absolute blast.

üêæ Graphics & Animation: The visuals are just adorable. Every character model oozes charm and personality. The animations, from the clumsy falls to the ragdoll physics, add layers of comedy that make each match memorable.

üêæ Gameplay: Simple to pick up but with enough depth that keeps bringing you back. Whether you're tugging on a jelly bean in a frantic game of keep-away or trying to toss an opponent off a floating platform, there's never a dull moment.

üêæ Sound & Music: The sound effects are spot on. Every thud, whack, and squeak adds to the hilarity. The background music is catchy and fits the theme of cute chaos perfectly.

üêæ Community: What's better than playing with friends and howling in laughter together? The community is great, and with frequent updates and new content, there's always a reason to jump back in.

Minor Gripes: While the game is incredibly fun, occasionally there can be connection issues or glitches. But the developers seem active and responsive, often addressing issues in updates.

Final Thoughts: If you're looking for a game that offers non-stop laughter, especially in group play, "Party Animals" is a must-have. It's a perfect blend of chaos, strategy, and hilarity, wrapped in an irresistibly cute package. Grab your friends, pick your fuzzy fighter, and let the adorable anarchy begin.

Pros:
 - Extremely well performing on my 3060ti & Ryzen 3700X on ultra settings.
 - AMD FSR and NVIDIA DLSS Support
 - NVIDIA Reflex support

Cons
