 - There are some cases where you'll die from melee impact of weapons, not sure what this is or why but it can be annoying (no HP bar?)
 - Game doesn't tell you what to press to get back up after a knockout. Should be a recovery bar or something

After just buying a new PC with what I'd consider to be pretty good specs (NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050, AMD Ryzen 5 5600 6-Core Processor and 16GB of RAM), I fully expected this game to run at no less than 60 FPS, which wasn't the case at all. After around 30 minutes of consistent gameplay, the FPS dropped so slow (around a 5-10 FPS mark) to the extent that it became unplayable. Another few noteworthy inconsistencies would be the gameplay mechanics altogether, i.e punching, grabbing, throwing. Everything just seems so tedious and luck based to the point where it doesn't feel rewarding at all when you win games, it's almost as if the only way to successfully execute an intended action is to pray to the luck gods that your character decides to align properly to the exact correct molecule. It's like controlling a boneless corpse. Not to mention the weapon spawns too. Why is it fair that one player with a shovel or nun-chucks can knock other players out in seconds? That way the game just becomes a race to get a weapon and practically become unstoppable. I recall being able to keep a player knocked out on the ground almost permanently by just spamming the headbutt control, rendering them useless for the majority of the match. One unintended press of a button and it could be the reason for a loss. Keeping in mind the target audience for this game is likely younger children, I can imagine that it's perhaps unfair to judge a family type party game on control consistency, but it's no secret that older audiences play this game too. Not to mention that this game costs actual MONEY with very minimal maps and game modes to play on as well as an army's worth of in-game purchases that can be made for a pretty excessive price in my opinion. This game is in NO way worth it's price, nor is it worth playing alone (or on a decent PC for some reason?). There is an extensive amount of teamwork based modes in this game too, which I found to be unpleasant when being paired with literal children that had absolutely no idea what they were doing, making winning almost impossible when almost every single match I participated in, I HAD to have a teammate. Overall, if you're looking for a funny party game where you beat people up, buy Gang Beasts.

developer_response:
Hey there,

Sorry for the inconvenience. We will need your log to further analyze the issue. Please follow the steps below to get the log:

1. Quit game.
2. Right click "Party Animals", then click "Properties". Type "-log" in the "Launch Options", and close the Properties window.
3. Restart the game. Then in Steam Library, right click "Party Animals ", then "Manage", then "browse local files". In the pop-up windows, you will see log files named "2023-xx-xx_xxxxxxxxx-Laptop Name". Each game session will generate one log.
4. Try to reproduce the issue and remember the time when you encounter it. Then quit the game, and ZIP all the log files.

Please go to our website https://support.partyanimals.com/login , and create a ticket with a topic describing the issue, and the time you encounter it. Then attach the zip file to the ticket and click send.

We will get back to you as soon as we find out what's going wrong.

Thank you for supporting Party Animals!

This game is getting a ton of hate over the gacha mechanics and because there are micro transactions. For one, you DO NOT need to spend any real life money to acquire any skins in the game whatsoever. The in-game currency is attainable through just leveling up and playing the game. There has only been one skin that was locked behind a paywall, which was because it was a collaboration with some other company. I have played for 50 hours now, and have only spent 5 bucks for that one skin, but I have gathered dozens of other customization's through just playing the game. I find it ridiculous how people like to bash this game for it's micro transactions when nobody is forced to pay for it, if they had just played the game they would've had their desired skin in like an hour. Also keep in mind this game is $30 dollars, there are companies that actually make you pay $70 dollars and still expect you to pay for a battle pass and other skins, while this game offers everything for free. 

A real critique that I can offer about the game is that it's maps sort of pale in comparison to gang beast's and that maps that are mainly fighting and throwing each other aren't the main focus, but rather more sort these little mini games and team competitions. Another critique I'd give this game is that there isn't much else to do after hitting the max level, I personally haven't hit the max level as of yet, however I do hear about there being a lack of content after reaching level 100. The biggest thing that probably bothers me about this game is that there are some skins locked behind doing stuff on other apps, for example there was a T-pain skin that you could only get from I believe tuning into the guy's stream. No offense but I aint tryna watch his ahh. There was also a tiktok skin, and other's, that seems like such a chore to do for a skin. 

What this game does well is just laughing at every game. In a typical game you can just expect to be beaten and tossed around, watch a bunny beat a gorilla to death in some corner, and a bear drop-kicking some other animal. This game's funky physics, movement, and implementation of weapons and stage hazards, offer a good balance of competition and party craziness. Also as I said, the fact that everything is attainable through just playing the game is a big plus, the closest thing I can compare it to is when you would buy a skin pack in PVZ Garden Warfare 2 if that makes sense. 

The one thing that this game will always have my support over Gang Beasts is that it actually updates there game regularly with new cosmetics and even stages, unlike that dead game that hasn't been updated in over a year. But yeah, this game is fun, definitely needs work on there being grounded stages for just fighting and for there to be a bit more diversity other than just 2v2v2v2, but it's still young and has been making efforts to improve.

[h1] THE REAL MEAT AND POTATOES OF THIS GAME [/h1]

[h2] Coming from a guy who has seen and played this game for a while, I can tell you the real deal about this game and some confusion people have [/h2]
 
This game is [b] NOT PAY TO WIN [/b] the only micro-transactions for the game are cosmetic wise and you can still get the currency from playing the game itself.

[h1] OFFLINE MISINTERPRETATION [/h1]

What the original description meant for this game is that you could play with your friends via co-op mode on the same device/room. The game did not mean to say that you could play without any internet.

[h1] DELAY PROBLEMS [/h1]

This game has been around since 2019 and has experienced some long delays in it's life. Rest assured, [b] If a game is being delayed that means there it is being polished and worked on to become even greater [/b]

[h1] MICRO-TRANSACTIONS [/h1]

As stated earlier, this game is not pay to win but it does have micro-transactions. The only thing you can buy in the game are the currency which [b] CAN BE EARNED VIA PLAYING THE GAME [/b]

[h1] FUTURE [/h1]

(as of writing this review) Party Animals doesn't have a lot but it has only been around for a couple of weeks. Expect a few glitches here and there and some servers needed for other countries, but the game is excellent and doesn't deserve the amount of hate it is getting now. [b] Don't be tricked by the mixed reviews, this game is a better version of Gang Beasts and is a perfect game to play on any day. [/b]

I have to say this game is definitely worth $20 let alone if it ever goes on sale.

Pros:
-Fun movement mechanics that gives a new life to games similar to gang beasts and human fall flat.
-Variety of diffrent objectives/maps/outfits
-Easy to pickup for anyone (had lots of newbie friends play like pros after a few games)
-Custom games is surprisingly well fitted with options and maps/gamemodes 
-Good amount of achievements

Cons:
-No official offline support (note: this is a party game so it does not affect the majority of players)
-skins are a bit expensive along with the deceptive practice of 2 seperate curencies (not as bad as other games where you cant convert currencys)
-After playing 24 hours, maps are kinda dull (maybe add custom maps/gamemodes)

Overall take: Great party game for 2-8players, my friends and I pickup this game when were bored and have lots of enjoyable moments and fun memories. 

Ps. Free skin for getting 3 starts on tutorial.

Honestly, the characters are cute and that was enough for me to get the game. Unfortunately after playing the game for a few hours and having the same minigames rotate in over and over with no diversity, as well as so many last man standing games where if you get knocked out quickly you sit and not play the game for 3 to 5 minutes, honestly I can say that you will spend more time not playing the game while in it then you will playing it.

I wanted this to be fun, I wishlisted it and got friends to get it, but in the end I wish I hadn't. Nobody wants to play a game where you get knocked out quickly and then dont play for several minutes while everyone else plays. Also if knocked out you cannot quit back to the menu to start another game, because you will get a BAN for doing so, even if you are already knocked out. You have no choice but to sit there not playing the game...

At least in games like World of tanks and such if you die, you can return to the garage and pick a different vehicle to play another round with. In this you sit and do nothing accept every 20-30 seconds you can throw a banana peel at the people actually playing.

Large waste of money and would refund if I hadn't played over the 2 hour limit trying to learn the minigames at the beginning... :/

Lots of character potential, but poorly thoughtout game modes. Maybe consider adding the option to either play last man standing modes, game modes where you dont die and stop playing, and then a random mode.

Then the player could actually play the game STYLE they wanted to play, similar to other games letting you choose random, elimination, or capture the flag.

Will update my review if the game modes change, but for now, STAY AWAY!

Who gives a game like this an always online requirement?
It is also quite disappointing how the Storefront mindset, where the games serve more as a storefront for monetization than an actual game, rears its ugly head once again.

Why in the world would they otherwise have no direct way to start a Local Game (you have to use the Serverbrowser and set it to private to start a local game) and right at release sell Skins that cost nearly as much as the actual game?

My plan was to stick this on the Steam Deck and then take it to friends. 
Not going to happen. I am not going to be, from their perspective, weird and ask my friends for their Wifi password so I can connect my gaming thing to it. 

Real shame. 

And the way this released also kind off betrays either a real disconnect with gamers that'd go for a game like this or the fact they ultimately were geifering for primarely the money after the massive Wishlisting the game must have experienced when it was first announced and I believe after a Demo was available. 

Again, just a shame but by now we should probably be expecting disappointments like this.

Right, if you want a game that does this much better look into GangBeasts.

This isn't a game I want to give a negative review on. I played it with a friend for a few hours and it was really fun. Yet this game is not responsive on Australian internet. 150 ping at best. Because of how many people have complained about it, I really hope they rectify this. I'm imagining that it isn't that hard to do and if this many people are giving bad reviews for this specific reason, then it means that this game is failing a very large portion of its audience in that regard.

Other than that, it's gangbeasts with more content. More maps, more modes and much higher quality assets. I love the cute designs but I just really want it to be playable because atm its hard not to constantly accidentally drop kick my friend in the face until his head is mash potatoes. The input delay due to the lag is wild, especially when contrasted with the client sided tutorial. Which also brings me to the issues of local co-op. Sure they screwed up and accidentally said offline, oh well. The main issue is that if I did want to play this with people right next to me, i STILL couldn't have a responsive game due to the shitty input delay of their asian servers.

Please make an au/nz server Recreate Games, this game has so much potential...

In the realm of multiplayer party games, Party Animals stands head and shoulders above the rest, particularly when compared to its counterpart, Gang Beasts. This delightful and whimsical game has captured the hearts of gamers worldwide with its unique gameplay mechanics, charming characters, and captivating visuals. With an emphasis on fun and laughter, Party Animals has proven itself to be an exquisite gaming experience that surpasses Gang Beasts in numerous aspects.

One of the defining features of Party Animals is its innovative and intuitive gameplay mechanics. Unlike Gang Beasts, which primarily relies on ragdoll physics, Party Animals presents players with a more refined and polished control system. The controls in Party Animals are responsive and easy to grasp, allowing players to fully immerse themselves in the game without feeling hindered by clunky movements. The precision and fluidity of the controls add an extra layer of enjoyment, making every action feel deliberate and satisfying.

Moreover, Party Animals boasts a diverse and lovable cast of characters that are brimming with personality. From the mischievous raccoon to the adorable penguin, each character is distinct and offers a unique playstyle. This variety ensures that players can find a character that resonates with them, enhancing the overall experience. On the other hand, Gang Beasts lacks the same level of character diversity, which can lead to a sense of repetition and monotony in gameplay.

Furthermore, Party Animals' vibrant and visually stunning graphics elevate the game to new heights. The colorful and detailed environments, coupled with the charming character designs, create a visually appealing world that is a joy to explore. The attention to detail in Party Animals is remarkable, with even the smallest elements contributing to the overall aesthetic. In contrast, Gang Beasts' visuals, while quirky, lack the same level of detail

Determining whether "Party Animals" is better than "Gang Beasts" or vice versa is subjective and depends on individual preferences. Both games fall under the same genre of physics-based multiplayer brawlers and offer unique experiences. Here are some reasons someone might prefer "Party Animals" over "Gang Beasts":

1. **Graphics and Art Style:** "Party Animals" features cute and colorful animal characters, which can be more appealing to those who prefer a lighthearted and family-friendly aesthetic. "Gang Beasts," on the other hand, has a more intentionally quirky and ragdoll style.

2. **Gameplay Variety:** "Party Animals" may offer a broader range of gameplay modes and scenarios, catering to players who enjoy diverse challenges beyond just brawling. This can include mini-games, obstacle courses, and more.

3. **Controls:** Some players may find the controls in "Party Animals" to be more intuitive or responsive than those in "Gang Beasts," depending on personal preferences.

4. **Online Multiplayer:** "Party Animals" might have improved online multiplayer features or netcode, making it a better choice for those who want to play with friends or others online.

5. **Development and Updates:** The ongoing development and support for "Party Animals" may provide players with more frequent updates, new content, and bug fixes, which can enhance the overall gaming experience.

6. **Community and Player Base:** Depending on the platform and region, one game may have a more active and engaged player community, leading to a better multiplayer experience.

However, it's important to note that "Gang Beasts" also has its own merits and a dedicated player base. Some players might prefer its more unique and quirky style, or they may have a nostalgic attachment to it since it was one of the earlier games in this genre.

Ultimately, which game is "better" depends on your personal preferences, the features you value most in a multiplayer brawler, and the kind of experience you are seeking. It's a good idea to try both games if possible and see which one aligns more with your gaming tastes.

[b] üíÄ …™“ì  è·¥è·¥ú …¥·¥á·¥á·¥Ö ·¥Ñ·¥è Ä Ä·¥è ô·¥è Ä·¥Ä·¥õ…™·¥è…¥ ·¥è…¥ ·¥ç è  Ä·¥á·¥†…™·¥á·¥°, ·¥ä·¥ús·¥õ  Ä·¥á·¥Ä·¥Ö ·¥õ ú·¥á ·¥Ñ·¥è·¥ç·¥ç·¥á…¥·¥õs ·¥ú…¥·¥Ö·¥á Ä…¥·¥á·¥Ä·¥õ ú ·¥õ ú…™s ·¥è Ä ·¥õ ú·¥á ·¥è…¥·¥ás ·¥è…¥ ·¥ç è ·¥ò Ä·¥è“ì…™ ü·¥á üíÄ [/b] 

I really really want to recommend this game, but the state it is in at this very moment I cannot. 

The concept is amazing, and I adore all the cute animals along with the cosmetics that are out, and the collabs they've done. Visually it is a really good, a cute cartoon-y game where you get to be a stuffed animal.

Unfortunately, the community is already incredibly toxic and the game hasn't even been out more than two weeks. I am a girl and I feel like I am in a COD lobby by the amount of hate I get when speaking. It is very common to get cussed out in games and called slurs because you knocked somebody out or are just playing that game the way it is meant to be played, OR because you sound like a girl. [spoiler] [i](If I get told to make one more sandwich I am going to put laxatives in it).[/i]  ò‚Äø ò [/spoiler] 

You would think with the game being about really cute stuffed animals the community would be nice and welcoming, but it's not. You can argue that I should just mute the voice chat or just ignore it, but the game was made with voice chat and I enjoy interacting with the wholesome section of this community, the ones that are just trying to have fun and don't threaten to un-alive you for knocking them out.

And the game play, I could write an entire review just about this. You can pick up a weapon, and it is pretty much game over for everyone else without a weapon unless the weapon holder is miraculously knocked out, or they run out of stamina. If you get nun-chucks or a shovel then it is almost impossible to get close enough to that person to knock them out, especially on maps like the alligator river or airplane, because those are not at all forgiving and one misjudged jump is the end. I think weapons should have some type of cool down or some type of durability at least. There should be no reason a single cat with a pair of nun-chucks can knock out eight people in a row and win the game simply because they were the first person to pick up a weapon. It is ridiculous.

Speaking of being knocked out, what is the point in playing when people can just stand over you and continuously knock you out? There have been many times where somebody is upset and targets me or another person and tries to keep them knocked out for the entirety of that game, and it is incredibly frustrating to stand up only to be drop kicked into the shadow realm once again. 

This is just a quality of life request really, but they should add something in the game where you can see your own stuffed animal better. This would help visually impaired individuals, because sometimes you can lose your own character in the chaos of everyone. Maybe a little glowing outline or something else to better indicate where you are in the group.

Overall, I like the concept of this game. It is cute and fun with friends, but it certainly can be improved. If you are looking to buy it I would wait a little while to see if there are any updates. 

[strike] [b] UPDATE 08 OCTOBER: [/b] So, they updated the game to make seemingly all of the games 4v4, which is ish IMO. They should add an option to have 2v2 modes AND 4v4 modes, that way duos and large groups have options to play together on the same team. I think the 4v4 isn't necessarily a bad thing, but having a wider range of team sizes that you can select from would be nice. [/strike]

[b] UPDATE 10 OCTOBER: [/b] They reverted back to the 2v2 modes thankfully

[b] UPDATE 23 NOVEMBER: [/b] Just updating this for the Steam Awards, (for the better with friends catergory) but I think that the changes the devs are implementing soon will definitely help the game.

Since the first trailer of this game I was intrigued. To say the least, this game has been a blast since release. This is game is very fun when you play with friends, which I would recommend is getting a bunch of friends together and sitting down and playing online together either online or in a private match. Just a heads up that only parties of 4 will be allowed to que up online play. For everyone complaining about micro-transactions either you haven't played enough or just here to complain? They literally give you free cookies and nemo-bucks for leveling. I can see the loot boxing being a problem but either than that its cosmetics at the end of the day. I don't see a problem with micro-transactions if its not game enhancing.

At the end of the day it's a chill game where you can sit back relax and knock some people out and play as a team, nothing serious.

I'm not a Chinese player, but I too feel like shit when I wait for years for a good party game, and get a skin store with an optional game attached to it. It's quite clear what is really the focus here right after you launch the game. It wouldn't be a huge problem really unless it literally handicapped the game. Because it's an online gambling store first, they have to protect in-game currency and casino, that means they can't allow you to just gain experience and play locally. So "local" games will gain you exactly 1 XP out of thousands needed to unlock anything fancy, not to mention it just does not work offline if you'd like to play on a couch, so a lot of problems come from that - they have to reserve and pay for the data centers around the world, you have to deal with no unlocks from local games and ping issues. As for the game, I've expected a bit more polished Gang Beasts, but it's about the same if not less fun. Some game modes are good to try a couple of times, but there are not many. The visuals are good, sure, it's cute. But really, if that was a _game_ in the first place, it would have been released years ago, much more fun to play and just plain better.

Party Animals isnt just a game, its a saviour of my life. This beautiful physics-based game is a masterpiece of its kind, this was the inevitable grand upgrade from gang beasts. I didnt know how badly i needed such a game to come into my life. You see, I suffer from a lot of illnesses, you name it - i got it. Anyway, this game became a runaway escape to a vast new reality, away from all my illnesses. I didnt have the stress of doctors running in and out of my hospital room, giving me organ and blood transplants, no... this game was a whole new dimension for me. It wasnt just a game anymore, it was the reason I was saved. I played and played party animals and slowly the doctors noticed I got better. Not long after, I had mildly healed from most of my illnesses, and soon after, I didnt have them anymore. I slowly looked to my screen with the lobby screen of Party Animals, a tear shed from my eye. I impulsively hugged the screen as tears ran down my face, "Party Animals" I cried, "Thank you so much...". Party Animals had saved my life. I was free. This game changed my life for the better, so hopefully it can change yours.

I am very critical of games and will shit all over them and their creators when poorly released. No exception, but here is my honest review ...

RAW RATINGS
Gameplay: 9/10
Performance: 8/10 - see addendum for more info
Visuals: 8/10
Sound: 7/10
Music: ?/10 (I play with music off)
UI: 9/10
Settings Options: 6/10
Pricing: 10/10
Cuteness: 20/10

DETAILS
Their is a surprising amount of strategic depth in even the simplest of choices, like whether to hold something single or multi-handed, drag someone single or mult-handed, when, what, who, and where to climb. You can even grab unto enemies OR friendlies, and make choices from there, possibly helping or hindering them.

There is the best selection of mini-games around, a whole mess of skins to earn including tie-in skins (Ori and The Blind Forest), the physics are sound and consistent, matches feel fair and balanced, death still allows minimal interaction (think rainbow six siege).

I would 1,000% recommend this game to anyone, no caveats.

--------------------

Addendum:
My PC houses a Ryzen 1600 and a RX580, 16GB ram, and an extremely fast storage. Despite my modest specs, I get a rock solid 75 if VSynced, and often significantly over if VSync is off.

The one exception to exceptional performance, which is the watery bridge map, which get atrocious FPS once waves start moving things around, most certainly CPU bottleneck here, as my GPU is relaxing with mimosas on a beach somewhere, whilst my CPU is in a coal mine in Africa working for warlords. I trust they will fix this if possible, though that remains to be seen. :-)

It gets old really quick. It will have you laughing for sure, but the grind is exceptionally repetitive. After about an hour it feels like unless you're really invested in unlocking new animals, you wont really have much incentive to play. 

Might be fun with a large group of friends, but without the banter, etc. its really at the mercy of who you get paired with.

The fighting system is exceptionally dumb, which again, would be fun to pick up and play with a free-to-play game, but not something you spend money on. 

Getting made to spend more money if you don't want the impossible grind, is also a bit of an F-you to the buyer - The old excuse of "oh but you can earn it with 3000 hours of gameplay" shouldn't be valid.

It's sad that I'm leaving a negative review on this game, I really do enjoy it, but, I can't in good faith give it a positive one. 
First off, the fact that you do not, and will not provide a local co-op after having it in your description for years is shameful amd should be investigated by steam for false advertising. The always online model does not work well when playing locally with multiple players, it's laggy and un-enjoyable, almost to the point of unplayable. And secondly, the Prices of in game skins are absolutely insane. $22 for 1 skin?? This game is just one big micro transaction. I see why you don't want people to play offline. There would be no way for them to purchase skins if they did, thus you won't offer it. 

One last note, the game is horribly unbalanced. Shovels killing you in one shot with out reason, being killed by poison fog after tounching it for half a second while other run around freely it in with no ill effect, etc. And only rewarding players who win the Match with a decent amount of XP to level up.

Such a wondering experience of fluffy animals and cool modes.

[h1] You pay to be spammed with microtransactions // Gacha lootboxes // Not-premium currency is indeed a hidden premium (p2f) currency[/h1]

This game was review bombed the first week due to the legendary skin price of $23 (50/50 the microtransaction mixed with the fact they promised offline which never came). Which is ridiculous considering is more expensive than the game itself and not even the deluxe edition would give you enough cash to buy that skin.

Then they """"""""heard""""""" the community and changed it to the in-game currency [b] BUT [/b] with a trick. Thing is that you can only farm these in-game currency via leveling the free pass (at least it is not worth another 15 bucks) which is tedious, and can only be actually raised by wins (loses actually do give some XP, but it's a misery tbh). Or by weekly quests, these quests only give you 1.500 coins each week (the same amount of time the shop takes to rotate). This means that the skins are """"obtainable without paying"""" but in reality, 22k coins (what they are priced at) costs, you guessed right, the exact same $23 than first week.

I'm only speaking of the rotative shop (which is another bad thing as well that this is a thing outside that trash game called Fortnite). Models are beautiful, but most skins can only be obtained via gacha, it is not that you can get them from lotboxes but they can appear in the shop, no, you can only obtain these by buying gacha lotboxes, most of them are the preferred by the community.

Don't get me wrong, the game itself is pretty fun. But don't make me waste money on a game where I'm spammed to "progress" to get skins but at the end the only way to get those skins is paying more than $20 each.

[h2] Having said that and mentioned the trash mix between fortnite/genshin impact monetize system, I have something to say about gameplay... [/h2]

I would recommend this game if it wasn't because of that trash monetization. It is pretty fun but still the game is not perfect. It is a copy paste of Gang Beasts but better, looks better, plays better, but here you can be knocked WAY too easy, only thing making it difficult is that the exagerated physics makes every hit fail randomly, but not big deal.

What's indeed a big deal is the fact that 80% of time you will be playing maps that you don't want to play on with people you don't want to play with because the main mode can only be played in random voted maps in teams, not deathmatch. This can be easily solved by a selector of preferred maps and team or solo check with a simple matchmaking auto-fill function in case it does not find anybody or enough players coinciding with you.

This is a problem considering that you're not probably going to like half of the maps on this game, since all the maps are not simple arenas but they all have "handicaps" you are going to probably be finding them tedious and stressful rather than fun. If you don't believe me, don't mute people, you will not take too much until someone appears yelling at how much they hate you and how much that map is trash.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]

üîπJust if they remove that monetization or somehow fix it, then I will change this review as positive, because the game is fun even with both negative gameplay aspects I mentioned. And I'm probably going to keep playing. 

üîπJust to be clear. I don't have any problem with cosmetics priced with real currency. My problem is when those skins are actually more expensive than an actual (irl) shirt (at least in my country, and I'm not even speaking of a low quality trash looking shirt). As a reference for another online-based games with microtransactions; I believe no game has right to charge a skin more than what League of Legends charges for theirs, unless it is half as popular as that game is. And skins there are not the cheapest, but at least they are way better than any other game's skins with all animations and proper visual and sound FX, definitively better than the overpriced cosmetics you will see here for $23.

üîπUntil you see this review has been changed to positive, don't buy at full price; get it in a key website or wait until it is at least at 60% discount.

‚Ä¢ This game is damn fun. It‚Äôs got that chaotic brawler ragdoll vibe, like Gang Beasts. It's got the addition of weapons (nunchucks be OP) which I think is a net positive.

‚Ä¢ Lots of variety in game modes to keep things fresh and a good map selection too.

‚Ä¢ No offline mode is a bummer, especially when I just wanna play some lag-free split screen with the boys. I mean it barely lags but then when it does I don't wanna hear one of em use it as an excuse for losing lol.

‚Ä¢ If I were playing this by myself only online I would definitely get bored and stop playing in like a month but because I'm playing locally with friends on the weekend I don't see me dropping it anytime soon. 

‚Ä¢ Overall I would recommend this game, buy it if you're a fan of the game style. However once/if it gets an offline mode, I would say its an instant buy.

Yes, the game having to be always online sucks and we were considering not buying it because of it. But we decided to give  it a try nonetheless and we were not disappointed. 

It's a great, pretty polished game that offers a lot of fun for your group of friends. 

Positive:
+ So far no bugs found. Game feels very polished.
+ Under 20 bucks.
+ Haven't laughed that hard in a long time.
+ Weapons to use in battle. 
+ The graphics style is cute, fitting of the game and looks fun.
+ The games menu is simple to understand, it's easy to create a lobby, add friends and chose a game mode.
+ Controller support is super easy. PS4 controllers are supported as well (not always the case). 
+ There are several game modes (minigames, like a soccer mode) to play with your friends online/locally, which are a ton of fun.
+ You can play in local split screen (tried it with only two players though), with two controllers (PC)!

Neutral: Haven't played online with other people than my friends, so can't comment on that.
Neutral: Yes, there is an ingame shop but it's pretty non-intrusive. You don't have to buy more stuff to have fun.

Negative:
- Always online.
- Sometimes the loading screens are a bit long but nothing too bad.
- Grabbing/using weapons sometimes is super frustrating.

Try the game, if you and your friends don't like it, just refund. It deserves better than a "mixed" steam rating in my opinion.

Even though I understand all the fuss about the in-game transactions, but they really have almost 0 impact on the game itself and are purely cosmetic.  Therefore I just can't give this game a thumbs down because:
1. It is silly. In a really fun way. I haven't laughed that hard in a while. 
2. It is easy on the player: a fun experience rather than a competitive sweat-fest. 
3. It is easy to jump in, play few matches and jump out - a good tool to relieve stress without having to commit.
4. The outfits are pretty original and fun.
5. It does not get boring fast and is full of action.
6. You can have a huge impact on the outcome of the match even as a spectator (when you get knocked out).

Overall: if you are after some action packed fun for a match or two, this game is for you. I can hardly imagine myself playing it for more than 1hr in one session. Give it a try!

Let's be honest. I am from what someone would call "a region with restricted access". I.e. China. I am writing this review partly because of the grudge accumulated from the years of waiting, being mistreated and outright abused, and partly because of the necessity of clarifying why we, as a whole, have such a negative attitude towards Recreate, the company that made this Game. I am writing this in English so that all of you, the honest players, can take a peek at what happened behind the colourful screen.

## Can We Talk About the Game First?

Sure. Party Animals is, as you've guessed from the name, a party game. It follows the slapstick formula with cute, fluffy animals as the dressing. It is visually appealing and is an easy pick-up for players at all levels.

The control is intentionally awkward so it fits the "everyone can have fun" party game style. You don't have to worry about someone being too pro at the game that it would crush the competition. But this awkwardness takes some time to get used to. For starters, you can't really control where you are facing and the pick-and-grab mechanism will get in the way if you spam the grab button, trying to pick up the key item.

Aside from the brawl, there are a lot of minigames that spice up the tone. But what minigame you get to play depends on the roll of the dice (and the minds of other players). Each round, you get 3 randomly selected maps to vote for.

The biggest downside is the **lack of local multiplayer**. As a party game, it is a courageous decision not to have a local multiplayer mode. My guess is that all the maps are designed around the 8-player versus mode. Typical 4-player mode won't make the cut.

The price point is also a bit too high for a party game. Oh, it might not be the case for YOUR region. In addition to the microtransaction built-in, I honestly don't know what should I feel. I paid a premium for this Game, only to be hit by a gacha machine in the face.

I guess it's a good time to explain the grudge.

## Why the Negativity?

As you may have known, Recreate is a Chinese company. I am not hinting about all the conspiracies revolving around privacy issues and data breaching -- it's too bland even for an avid conspiracy theorist. I am talking about the aspect of community management.

Recreate, at least in the domestic market, did not perform well in community management. Back in late 2019, when everything was still in the good ol' order, Recreate had released a beta version of the Game. The Game was already well-polished. We were all hyped and expected its release.

However, this is where it all started to go downhill.

It starts with the delays. Well, I guess that's a norm for game development. They always delay. But a three-year delay is more than what we can manage. During the Pandemic, while we were staying indoors, longing for a game for distraction, Recreate had chosen to "perfect" their work. They wanted "a better hair rendition" for the animal avatars. Okay, it's their artistic decisions. I won't judge. But what we have here is something practically identical to the 2019 demo. I guess they have improved the hair rendering code so it can run on a lower-end machine. (What's funny is that this fine hair rendering looks quite strange on Xbox such that some are questioning why the animals look jagged. I think they have fixed this issue but, still!)

If it's only that simple, I don't think it deserves such a bad rating.

As I have stated from the start, it all comes down to the community management. Party Animals was officially announced to the domestic market as early as 2020. But for all these years, there is virtually no official announcement made. No devlogs. No progress indication. Nothing. However, they haven't missed any international game events -- there were ads being made.

I mean, really? You have the manhours to make those ads, but not posting a tweet about where the project is going? Seriously?

I guess ads also count, at least they can let us take a peek at what the game would be, followed by a date that's either too vague or will get delayed (again). They didn't even bother to add a Chinese subtitle. All the press materials come in English first.

Fine. I'll take that as a try of i18n. Recreate wants to ship the game overseas. They are an ambitious company. But it just nudges the domestic market in a wrong way.

And then, the utterly tone-deaf interviews landed. Producer Luo, I remember that you said you wanted to make a "perfect game". Is this what you've dreamed of? Maybe. It's glitch-free. It is perfect in the sense that it runs without a hiccup. But a game is consumed with paratexts. A game cannot be played in a vacuum, in an idealized plane. I don't want to be harsh towards the developers and artists working for Recreate, but Animal Party is a dumpster fire and you know it. Are your servers stressing out? Should we "buy the game but never play it"? Because "as soon as we started playing it, [you are] losing money"? I know it's meant as a joke. It's a joke that nobody laughed.

98 CNY. Is this the price you are asking for? For a party game? Sure, I can afford that. But you chose to not add local multiplayer. It means if I wanted to invite my friends to play this game, they would have to pay for a copy themselves! That's a red bank note a pop! Let's have a check on other party games. Almost all of them are below 50 CNY. For those who didn't see the problem: imagine that this game asks for $40 or more, will you be so tolerant to microtransactions? Will you still think that "fluffy animal cute"?

About the controversial naming, I'd left it aside. Again, those are jokes, whether intentional or not, that got nobody laughing. Well, maybe some laughed. Puns to vulgar terms always work as a filler. At least the name was addressed before the launch. I'll give it a pass.

I'd like to address some additional operations from Recreate in the domestic market. We do have a homegrown gaming community and it is as toxic and chaotic as yours. In the Party Animals board, there is not a single negative review of the game. You should really give the board moderator a raise. They are developing tenosynovitis just from swinging the ban hammer too much.

## Can Recreate Redeem Itself?

Now the Game is finally released for good. We laughed, we wept.

A game company, no matter the size, can always redeem itself. But not by doing the wrong thing one after another. None of the problems were unredeemable, but without proper treatment, they would accumulate and finally burst.

The game itself is of great quality (in terms of overall robustness). But the community disaster has already happened. Let's see if Recreate can come up with something better to turn this thumb upside-down.

Oh, by the way, if the game becomes F2P in a year (with boosted microtransactions), I would consider it a backstabbing move and this review will become settled.

Great party game with friends, and as long as you silence in-game voice chat then solo Quick Play is fine as well. Game is best if you have a few friends to hop into Quick Play with, or enough to play Custom matches against one another. It has some flaws, listed below, but it won't stop me from recommending a solidly fun game where the only in-game transactions are for wholly unneeded skins. 

The game is very good but has some flaws/things that lack proper explaining;
- The heavy punch (sprint punch) has hitbox issues galore, it seems. Sometimes it KO's in one hit, other times it bounces off people ineffectively from the same rough distance and angle as a KO punch. It's hard to gauge why it's not very consistent. Lag? Comedy? Who knows. 
- Some maps are worse for dead players to throw things at players in [yes, when you die you get to throw objects at the active players; it's neat/comedic], and sometimes the thrown item is *wildly* off course. And sometimes a thrown item KO's a person when it hits them and sometimes it doesn't even if it's hitting them the same way that the one that KO'd them did. It's confusing. 
- Price of skins could stand to be lower. $10 a pop is a little steep feeling. Not League of Legends or DotA steep, but not particularly inexpensive. 
- The worst part of the game overall is really just the players, per any multiplayer game. Lots of whiners on here quitting as soon as the game map they don't want is voted in favor of and complaining about getting leaver penalties. Losers. Matches last between 5-10 minutes, suck it up. 
- Speaking of quitters; if someone quits, they're replaced with an AI player. Sometimes they seem very good at the map objectives (like Beast Ball [football]) and other times they stand in areas and just die (Winter is Coming/bonfire map). Some consistency would be nice.

I really enjoy this game and have lots of fun with it, playing mostly quick matches. I don't care about the MTX since I just take what I get and don't care about getting certain skins, so that is no problem for me.

The only problem I have is that there should be better mechanisms against AFK players because in some rounds you meet people that don't move at all.

I really enjoy playing Party Animals because it's a super fun and crazy game where you get to control cute animals with floppy movements and engage in hilarious battles. The game looks like a colorful cartoon, with the animals having funny expressions and movements that make the game even more charming and entertaining.

What I find most awesome about Party Animals is how unpredictable and creative it is. You never really know what's going to happen next in a match because there are all sorts of crazy weapons, hazards, and surprises that can completely change the game. From crossbows to plungers to bombs, you can use all sorts of items to either get an advantage or mess with your opponents.

Another great thing about Party Animals is that it's a really social game. You can play with your friends, either online or in the same room, and it's always a blast. You'll laugh a lot and probably tease each other too. Plus, you can also meet new friends or rivals by jumping into public matches with strangers. And the best part is that the game is easy to pick up and play, so anyone can join in on the fun, regardless of their gaming experience.

I'm going to recommend this game despite my surprise from the in-game purchases. The reason I do this is because this model actually made me realize, that the overall audience is a casual one.

When I first heard about the game, it was on a youtube trailer without mention of a PC version. What it did do however was advertise it on xbox. This is important because my theory is that they are targeting folks with Game pass.

The use-case that comes to mind is a casual player finds out about the game and picks it up because they don't have to pay 20$ when gamepass is a thing. Given this, the game itself can make up for smaller costs by using the nemo bucks and battle-pass-like format.

I don't need to go into an entire explanation, but if you catch my drift, I think it's fine so as long as you get it knowing what it has out of the box. The mechanics are generally overall fun with friends, so I'm personally just going to be enjoying the base game. Anything you buy isn't pay to win and is purely aesthetics which can be obtained overtime. Since it's just that, and core gameplay is always available, I'm entirely ok just enjoying it as-is.

Party Animals is a great game to play when you just want to play a funny and silly little brawler with a group of friends, or juust need some silliness on your own to relax. Its cute, charming and the ragdoll physics make it so you win as much as you lose due to silly game mechanics. The characters all remind me of stuffed animals just beating eachother up. I would definitely recommend this game to people who are parents and looking for a fun game to let their kids play. Or adults who never let their inner child die.

My only gripe with it, is limited game modes. And the fact you cant chose between 'i want to queue for solo modes' or 'i want to queue for team modes'. I think there should be an option to toggle which type of game-modes you want to play--- such as Last Stand or more cooperative modes like Fluffy Redemption/Trebuchet within Quick matches would go a long way in tailoring some customizability to the gameplay experience to those who have friends with busy schedules and cannot get everyone to sit down for a Custom Game lobby with more than 4 players.
 I also like beating up strangers on the internet and hearing them get mad over voice chat over a cute, silly, fluffy animal game, if I'm being honest.

Having an absolute blast as a solo player which I was hesitant and worried about. Quick play matchmaking is instant and proximity chat makes the game funnier than it already looks. All items in the daily shop can be acquired by playing the game with no real money spent, all by leveling your character. This game is a blast and for sure worth the $20 and than some. If you want a party or chill game to play by yourself or with the homies, this is it

It's like a combination of Fall Guys and Gang Beasts, very fun and funny and it supports Remote Play if you want to use that.
Controls are simple and easy but you have to learn how to move your character properly to fight well.

8 animals beat the shit out of each other with fists, feet, heads and whatever weapon is lying around but every level has an environmental hazard that gets worse/more restricting over time to stop the game from going too long and forcing players to move and fight.
It also has a team mode where you play in two teams of 4v4 and have an objective to fight over while stopping the other team from doing the same.

Only a few problems;
No offline mode, doesn't bother me
Remote Play is always split screen, fine with two players
Very limited servers, I imagine it would be impossible to play in places like Austrailia, Africa and potentially South America and Russia

-Fun when you play in a lobby of only people you know because you're willing to forgive a bunch of the game mechanics.
-will become frustrating getting killed for arbitrary reasons. hit by a shovel? dead. next guy hit by a shovel and they just punch them back and knock them out.
-how long you stay knocked out seems to be random as well as what it's going to take to get knocked out.
-everything seems very RNG
-playing with randoms is just going to piss you off because griefing is so easy to do especially in teams based mini games.
-also planned on having this be an offline game but you have to have it always online, and split screen is not the best of experiences.
-your view is almost constantly being obstructed by something and trying to get the camera to a decent angle is borderline impossible.

solutions: get good, and just don't play those game modes....

I genuinely don't understand the negative reviews and I feel like the devs don't deserve those.

It's unfortunate that the wording of the description hinted at offline mode when in reality was not the case. I don't even know if "single-player" tag should be on the store page or not (btw, playing alone is not even close in terms of fun compared to playing with at least a single friend). Though I understand the issue with not having servers for all the parts of the world. That's not great. Monetization I am not sure about? I get the price for skins is pretty high, but the game also gives you a damn ton of free currency. I am sure there will be other ways to earn ingame currency as well later on, something like a free season pass or something. We will see. But up until level 100 (this will take you around 50 hours) you earn a lot.

Anyway, the game is awesome. It's super fun and addictive. Playing solo is not that great, but if you have at least one friend, it becomes incredible. This will make you laugh a year worth. Also, compared to other similar games, the maps with objectives are pretty fun and they keep the game more interesting than if you only had deathmatch arenas. All of the maps are cool and different in a way. Even the maps that are kinda similar, play differently.

Hope we can get more and more interesting modes, maps and weapons! A great game.

TLDR; The dumbest guy on Earth can win a match, flawed game design over and over, uninstalled.

The most terrible game designs I've ever seen in a video game, majority of levels are simply not fun and it's based on pure luck and randomness.

Everything's random.
I know it's a silly game but at some point there needs to have concrete controls over your actions that WORK.
Climbing? punching? it's all hit or miss if it works or not or if you can come back up or not, whatever your stamina is, I've played 17 hours through all the levels many times, inputs won't trigger at times or your character's animation will get in the way.
If it's desync (which would happen 80% of the time), then they need to fix this ASAP.

Blunt melee weapons are OP, once you get used to the swing you can clear a map like Ice Breaker or Isiban in 2 minutes without much trouble, knocking out someone is one thing but eliminating a player by hitting them with a melee is retarded.

AFK players everywhere without consequences but if YOU leave you get a 2-minute ban, they can be AFK 5 minutes they won't get kicked out, who's stupid idea was that at Recreate Games??

There's a fake report button in-game like Fall Guys and RL had that probably go in their junk mails, hackers will be coming in flock soon (already have some)

Lack of outfits, I have 40k cookies and around 4k nemos after 17 hours and I bought a few outfits, the same outfits come back week after week in the store, everything else is with eggs and achievements, what's the point of having so many cookies and nemos then?

This game was pushed back for over a year and I wonder why, did they even have a QA team???

Out of every video game that suffers from the horrible idea that leaving a game should be punished, this game SHOULD NOT HAVE THAT FEATURE. This game is FOR FUN, why would you actively determent your game by making it less fun. I am not taking away from other people's fun by leaving the game, therefore I should not have to play through the most unfun parts of the game. All because of some horrible feature created for competitive games, this game suffers from a lot; but this is the biggest issue and that's saying something both good and very-very bad. For devs that seem fairly in-touch, this is the biggest left-field out-of-touch feature they could add to this game.

For anyone wondering, the average game is 5-10 minutes; therefore quitting and recieving the punishment if faster than playing through the maps you don't wish to play.

1. First and foremost, remove the absolute largest anti-fun feature created in videogaming history.

2. Add a map filter than removes the ability to queue for maps I don't want to play. No, I dont want to play straight line map with no depth, no I don't want to play circle map with the nothing but something that sucks the players towards the middle. These are all things that are so easily avoided, that does not cause ANY issues no matter what they say. 

Not having this feature and addition of "feature" are both anti-fun and are a determent to the game.

I previously had a negative review due to what seems to a bit of confusion. Some people are reporting the game cannot be played offline at all, others say you can, still others say only on certain platforms. So if you had any doubt about that and need to play this game offline, do some research before you buy because depending on your circumstances it may not work. I keep finding conflicting information, so I'm leaving it out of this review for now.

Assuming you do have online capacity however, this game is incredible. It's very clearly just gang beasts but with cute animals, but it really works. The cute animals give it a unique feel and make it stand out, and there was always a thrill in the early part of the game when you would see a new animal for the first time. You have obvious ones like dogs, cats, and rabbits, but some real odd balls that were a treat to see. They did a really good job of making the other game modes fun, I actually prefer some like the train mini game to some of the pvp maps like the ice one. 

The game does have a few weak points. Matchmaking is buggy right now and if you don't leave a match after the end and instead instant queue for another one, it often either crashes the game or gets you stuck in an endless loading screen. The game is heavily lootbox / microtransaction filled and many cosmetics (and even some characters) seem to only be available through these. You can get a few loot boxes from levels but after you reach max you would have to spend real money to roll the dice. I've seen about 30 different animals (albeit about 1/3 are variations of dogs and cats) and while that is definitely a lot I'm already itching for more. The game just came out so no telling how often updates will arrive but if they are frequent I think this game will last a long time. 

Lastly, this game really needs to have local multiplayer. It might already have this, but once again I have seen very conflicting information, and it seems like it is also platform related. In some capacity it seems at least one version of the game does have this, but it's very odd that it is not universal.

There are TONS of ways to get extra free stuff, even some pretty premium stuff. Also, a 100+ tier BP where you can earns so much extra goodies. Secondly, the internet requirement can be lame if you were expecting to be able to play offline but NONE of the top online games like this had offline capabilities. Fall Guys was $20 when it released and they didn't have it either.

Now that I've addressed my thoughts on THOSE issues, the game itself is incredibly fun. It's funny and my son and I highly enjoy it.

Game's not really worth it unless you got people to play with. Maps are untested for exploits and a lot of them just seem less fun and fair than others, like Ichiban where you can almost never recover. Some weapons are way better than others like the nunchucks, and there's some hidden healthbar mechanic so you can just die from being hit hard enough. It should be easier to pick up weapons too, instead of having to drag them the right way. 

Main problem of the game is there's no effort to cultivate a positive community so you get a lot of sweatlords and trolls which make it unfun to play. This game has all of your standard live-service / mobile-games style of monetization. Not as predatory as games like Diablo Immortal since it's all cosmetic...

Ultimately, its a really great party game with friends, but changes are needed so I can recommend it:

- Let me quickmatch with a local party.
- Add playlists to quickmatch into, depending on my party. Solo, couples, 4p teams, solo only teams.

- Free camera with zoom and better split-screen. It's way too cropped.

After seeing the game has mixed reviews it got me a bit concerned. I've dug into all negative ones and pretty much there are two things people complaint about: no offline/solo mode and skins to buy. If I can kinda understand why people are upset they cant play offline (even though I don't understand how this game could be fun with bots), but I totally don't get the whine for paid skins. They are cosmetic ONLY. It's not like they will get you any sort of advantage against other players. Plus you do earn in-game currency quite fast, so you can still get nice looking skins without spending an extra cent. 

 The only thing I hope they do - is consistently keep map pool fresh and updates, as there are not a lot of maps and those will get boring pretty soon I'm sure. Few QoL updates would be also good in terms of matchmaking with friends. But besides that I'm overall happy I gave this game a chance despite all reviews. It is insanely fun with friends.

I play this nightly with my husband since it released and we both love it. It's challenging but not in the sense that it requires a lot of skill. Personally, I do not feel like the match-ups are unfair nor do I feel like I am disadvantaged at any time and I like the voting feature where you have a say in which map you can play on. Even if you're playing the same map 3 or 4 times in a row, each match-up is different and there's always an equal opportunity for everyone to potentially win. Once you're knocked out for the round, you still get to play on in the sense that you can throw things at people rather than just sit and spectate. The abilities of your fighter are the same as any other person you're playing with our against and so long as that never changes, it's great. 

This game has the option for in-game purchases with RMT, however, thanks to how the rewards system is set up, there is no need to purchase any in-game currency to get what you want from the shop. There is zero pay to win aspect. I also love that there is a lot to choose from as far as the cosmetic selection goes, even with options to win/purchase/play as an animal dressed as popular IP! While there is the aspect of micro-transactions, Party Animals does not feel micro-transactiony. You are literally only buying a skin - nothing more than a cosmetic. 

I think my only con would be that the length of time it takes for Beast Hockey, Beast Soccer and Beast Football to end is a bit too long but that is just personal opinion. Or I should just get better.

[h1] My Honest review of Party Animals [/h1]

Let me start off with [b] WOW! [/b] I took no notice of this during the Xbox Showcase as I was more interested in Forza Motorsport at the time, but after seeing a friend play this game through VC in discord I was blown away by the amazing gameplay and wanted to get the game to play it just for the sake of playing. (And of course play with my friend...) [spoiler] That's [b] WHEN [/b] she wants to play with me ofc... [/spoiler]

The Gameplay is so great! I can't stop playing this game whether I'm getting head bonked, hit by a frying pan or just being fried from accidentally stepping into the train's system. It has so many game modes that you can play from Duos to teams and from American Football, surviving the conditions or just surviving a black hole. 

Honestly I really don't mind if I have to stay online just to enjoy the game, and the micro transactions don't bother me but you know that's the main part of the game industry [b] BUT [/b] with this game you can earn the items by levelling up so it's not all doom and gloom behind a paywall. 

I really think the devs have hit the jackpot with this idea and I cannot wait for new updates to come to the game!

I really do recommend this game it's a 10/10 experience!

[h1] Party Animals: A Wild Brawler Worth a Spin [/h1]

Alright, let's talk about "Party Animals," and yes, it's tough not to mention "Gang Beasts" because, well, they're like siblings. 
Both are chaotic, physics-based brawlers that thrive on the unpredictability of flinging cuddly creatures at each other.

"Party Animals" doesn't quite reach the beastly heights of its counterpart, but it's got its own brand of charm. They've swapped out the gelatinous, gelatine-hued fighters for fluffy, adorable animals. These furballs toss each other off bridges into seemingly bottomless pools of water, and it's as brutal as it is hilarious.

What sets it apart, though, is the variety of maps. From crumbling bridges to indoor arenas with arcade machines, each one is a delightful dose of fun. Some even bring in unique challenges like rising poison gas or encroaching cold. They're not just visually appealing; they add depth to the chaos.

Now, if you've played "Gang Beasts," you're familiar with the wonky physics controls. In "Party Animals," it's no different; You're flailing around like a caffeinated octopus trying to perform open-heart surgery. 

But that's part of the charm. The only time you feel truly in control is when you're delivering a dropkick, which is strangely satisfying.

I've had a blast playing "Party Animals" with friends, and it's clear that this game is meant to be shared. You can go wild with up to eight players online or have a cozy couch session with four players on a local console.

At launch, there's not an overwhelming variety of game modes, but they're a hoot. "Last Stand" is the classic mode you'll probably enjoy the most. Custom games can get a bit repetitive since you often play the same map multiple times. But some maps, like the sinking submarine level, are so fun they don't get old.

Then there's "Team Score Mode," offering a mix of mini-games, from football-ish to train racing. It's bizarre but adds to the variety.

"Party Animals" throws in some monetization with XP to unlock cosmetics and rewards. While there's a gacha-style system, it's not overly aggressive, and you can unlock most rewards in-game.

So, "Party Animals" is off to a solid start. It looks great, plays well, and is a blast with friends. It might not change your life, especially if you're a "Gang Beasts" veteran, but if you've never experienced the joy of a physics brawler, "Party Animals" is a great entry point for this genre.

This game has potential, but it is making so many basic mistakes, like it hasn't been in development for years. They barely demoed the game and it shows sadly.
- Sports modes are incredibly dull and time consuming.
- Grabbing rarely works correctly, especially for weapons and often other players. You will grab items incorrectly many times, as well as grabbing things you dont want to. The worst case of grabbing is the ice level, where it wont grab onto the side properly a lot of the time so you are eliminated.
- Climbing (jumping whilst holding) is really bad when you reach a ledge, which only gives more chance for other players to land an easy hit on you.
- Physics are sometimes just randomly bad, throwing you for no reason, you can hit someone 10 times, they hit you once and you're knocked out. I think there's exploit abuse going on.
- No visible indicator of your health, so you have no idea how hurt you are.
- Win rules are strange for some maps, like the submarine one, you can be the last on the submarine yet not win because there is someone far away in the water with a little more stamina?!

I really hope these things are fixed, it has a long way to go and I can't believe the game is released in this state. I will give it a few months and if it hasn't changed I will be asking for a refund. I hope to change my review sometime, right now playing the concept and art of the game is great, but it's so frustrating to play and I always leave feeling worse than when I started.

Fun game with friends. Lot's of unique gamemodes both for elimination and team based, assuming the game will be serviced and updated long into the future there's no reason not to get this game at the price point. Additionally, the fact that Party Animals has a nice balance between micro-transactions and unlockable content through achievements or just by earning currency to buy skins makes the game very easy to get stuck into. The music and visuals are perfectly done to make the game easy to run, visually appealing and doesn't you turning off the music or sound effects.
Some of my favourite maps include Broken Arrow (a plane where teams compete to knock each other off), Blackhole Lab (where a blackhole periodically spawns in the centre above a hole, dragging people to their death), and Fluffy Redemption (a team mode where you have to move coal to the furnace at the front of your train while trying to sabotage the enemy).
All in all it's a lot of fun and definitely worth going into with a friend (or many for an epic showdown with just your mates in a private match.

[h1] There is potential, but this needs a lot of work. [/h1]

I've had this game on my wishlist for three years, and my enthusiasm has been met with disappointment. I have a soft spot for whimsical indie games of this nature, as there's nothing quite as enjoyable to me as partaking in party games with a lively group of friends. The inclusion of ragdoll mechanics and the like only amplifies the hilarity. Games such as Gang Beasts and Human: Fall Flat have certainly resonated with me.

My anticipation for this particular game was quite high; however, I must express my dissatisfaction with the mechanics, which fall short of expectations for a game of this genre. Unlike its counterparts, it lacks the ability to independently control each hand. Consequently, the gameplay devolves into a chaotic button-mashing frenzy, reliant on spamming the punch button in hopes of achieving a knockout. Regrettably, there is no discernible skill differential or means to genuinely outperform one's opponent. Instead, it boils down to aimless floundering, with the victor determined largely by chance.

I firmly believe that this game harbors substantial potential if only the developers would adopt combat mechanics akin to those found in Gang Beasts, where players possess a sense of control over the outcome of their interactions. Furthermore, the climbing mechanics in this game appear to be subject to random outcomes. One must simply press the jump and grab buttons and hope for the best, as the results can vary widely. Sometimes, a character effortlessly returns to a platform with a single jump, while on other occasions, it takes five attempts or more. This disparity creates a palpable disconnection between the controller and one's in-game character.

To truly elevate this game to excellence, it is my sincere suggestion that the developers introduce individual arm control for combat, climbing, and grabbing. This adjustment, I believe, would undoubtedly enhance the overall experience and propel this game to the top tier of its genre.

[h1] Ok, so lets clear some things up. [/h1]

This game has mixed reviews, which this game [b] definitely does not [/b] deserve. 

Lots of people are giving this game negative reviews because of the fact that the game does not have an 'offline' singe-player mode, or because of the fact that the game has micro-transactions.

[h2] Let's start with the offline single-player mode. [/h2]

To clear things up; the game [b] DOES [/b] support couch split-screen co-op. The only thing it doesn't support is offline play, as you need an online connection to be able to play the game at all. I do understand people being upset about this, as the devs could have been more clear about this, and shouldn't have used the word 'offline' in the game description (which they removed as of now).  

[h2] Micro-transactions [/h2]

In no way is this game pay-to-win. All the micro-transactions in this game are cosmetic, and don't give you an advantage in any way. Matter of fact, both types of currency's are obtainable through just playing the game, and completing weekly/daily challenges! Which means that if you want to spend money to get your characters to look different, go ahead! But it's also obtainable by just playing the game and saving up the currency you get!

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]

Even though i haven't played a lot yet, I can definitely say that I love this game. If you liked Gang Beasts, you're gonna love this one. The gameplay is almost identical, though it feels a little less clunky, and more controllable. Also the fact that this game adds quite some weapons to use, quite a lot of maps on release, and several game-modes to play, makes it so the game doesn't get old quick (which I did have with Gang Beasts). If the devs continue to update the game with more maps, game-modes, weapons and characters (which they are actively doing right now), this game is going to be fun, and fresh for a long time!

If you liked Gang Beasts, you're definitely gonna love this one. Don't let the reviews fool you, the game is a blast! Especially with friends.

Next issue: Online multiplayer, I don‚Äôt really see many issues with lag it‚Äôs pretty stable. So that‚Äôs a plus! 

Bugs: I‚Äôve noticed a few things that don‚Äôt make sense and im not sure if each animal has its own weight? How does that make sense? I think it‚Äôs a bug regarding the characters size and tallness because there is a map with poison, and I can be knocked out for a second and I will die in the poison, while a goose who is longer neck won‚Äôt die in that poison because I feel most of the body isn‚Äôt in the poison so it doesn‚Äôt trigger. Rating of game: I give it a solid 7/10 just because it‚Äôs so fun with friends but when you are paired up with a stranger disconnecting or who doesn‚Äôt really know what they are doing and throwing you off when you are teammates can be frustrating. I'm going to directly compare this game to Gang Beasts in my review because they are very similar games, although in my opinion, Gang Beasts is better. I'll explain by telling you the difference between the games.


In Gang Beasts, you stay down longer each time you get knocked out, with your first time getting knocked out being only a second unconscious. And then going closer to knockout #10, you'll be down for around 6 seconds. So you have lives, in a way, because even if someone knows how to throw, then they won't have time to throw you off the edge unless you got knocked out right next to one.

In Party Animals, how long you stay down is seemingly random. I'm unsure without testing it, but it could be tied to your stamina, but I've been insta-knocked out on Spawn and been out for at least 4 seconds before, so I don't believe it's fully tied to stamina if at all. But in Party Animals, it's luck based on if this knockout is gonna be the killer for you, and if you spawn right next to somebody, you've got a 50/50 chance. And with the added caveat that there's a designated throw button and the fact that knockouts send you meters away, you can easily be thrown off map the second you get knocked out, if the blast from the punch didn't do it for you already.

In Gang Beasts, there is no stamina bar except for an invisible one when climbing or ganging from something in general. Just basic attacks and jump attacks, which are stronger. Bodies were heavy as they realistically are, so you had to be sure to pick someone up in the right way to throw them, and then get them right near the edge.

In Party Animals, stamina is a key feature, and you do more damage based on how much stamina you have. On top of that, running punches and dropkicks are heavy attacks so KO's happen pretty quickly. If you are out of stamina and get knocked out, it's an instant death. As well as if you land in water without stamina, it's an instant death. So juggling your stamina bar while fighting your opponents is something you always have to keep watch on, which takes away a bit of the fun of just beating the shit out of your friends and strangers. In my opinion, simple works better with brawlers like this. And you'd think that'd it'd be less random with these kinds of systems, but somehow it's not.

In Gang Beasts, every customization item is free and available to you, with options to save different presets.

In Party Animals, monetization is a big part of the game. While you can earn the three different currencies from leveling up; once you hit that level cap, buying is your only way to get currency until they release a battle pass, which will also cost money.

In Gang Beasts, controls are limb based and deliberate. Climbing is one hand a time, and grabbing onto one specific thing purposefully is entirely possible.

In Party Animals, climbing controls are simpler, but more random. You throw  yourself upwards by launching yourself up, letting go, and grabbing on again. But if the surface isn't entirely flat, or somebody is in your way, prepare to fall all the way down because when you climb, you let go with both hands each raise in height, so if your arms don't connect, you fall. And might even get knocked out when you land as well.

There are more comparisons to make such as map designs and modes, but this would be way too long of a review. All in all, this game is fun for a little, while Gang Beats is fun for a while. If Boneloaf would update Gang Beasts, it would be top of the charts again.

I thoroughly enjoyed the game, with its endearing and humorous characters. It has the elements to be as captivating as other big titles like Fall Guys. Though it comes with a price tag, 

I appreciate that in-game store characters can be unlocked using game currency earned while playing. There's an option for real-money purchases, but dedicated players can accumulate substantial in-game currency without spending extra. 

The so-called "free battle pass" is a nice addition, though it's worth noting the game isn't free. 

Playing with friends amplifies the fun, and the inclusion of voice communication is a plus.

 The game mechanics are straightforward, and navigating the menus feels intuitive.

This game is extremely fun. Most of the negative reviews stem from either offline couch mode and micro transactions being thrown into your face.

So far, in the 6 hours I have played, I have earned over 30 skins to use and have not spent a single dollar. The game rewards you heavily for playing and having fun. The battle pass style of leveling has tons of rewards from in-game currency to paid currency and tons of skins, profile pictures, and profile backgrounds. I have barely seen things sold for crazy amounts and even then I have earned enough to buy multiple skins and re-rolls of the mystery box machine.

The couch mode does not bother me either. I bought the game because its a party game and I wanted to enjoy it with my friends not offline with bots. 

Give this game a try, you will get plenty of laughs out of it and is definitely worth the 20.

Let me start by admitting that I have had some fun with this game, but it is very short lived. The animals are cute, the animations are cute, sometimes funny things happen. But lets get to the center of the shit cake. The controls are AGONIZING. This game was designed by people who want you suffering regardless of whether you're winning or losing. It never teaches you that, to really throw someone, you must be sprinting while doing it. Your health bar is invisible. Your stamina bar might as well be invisible. Also I don't give a shit about the offline play or the microtransactions. All my gripes are with the gameplay.

"Party Animals" Review:

---

**Pros:**

1. **Global Reach:** The game provides global servers, catering to players in North America, Asia, and Europe, ensuring a broad player base and improved matchmaking.
   
---

**Cons:**

1. **Matchmaking Penalties:** A significant drawback is the severe penalty for canceling a matchmaking search. Even if you've just entered the matchmaking queue and opt out within seconds, you're subjected to a wait time. This is especially frustrating for players who may need to adjust settings or have genuine reasons to leave the search.
   
2. **Controller vs. Keyboard & Mouse:** For those who prefer playing with a controller, the game seems to be at a disadvantage when compared to the keyboard and mouse setup. This might be a turn-off for players who are more comfortable with a controller.

3. **Limited Asian Server Nodes:** While the game offers global servers, the Asian servers only provide a Chinese node. This could potentially lead to latency issues for players in other Asian countries.

4. **AI Teammates:** Having AI teammates against real players isn't the best experience. This can lead to unbalanced matches and diminish the competitive spirit of the game. It's particularly frustrating when faced with this issue multiple times in succession.

---

**Verdict:** 

"Party Animals" presents a mixed bag of experiences. While it promises global reach with its servers, some of its features, like the strict matchmaking penalties and the limited Asian server nodes, can be deterrents for players. If the developers address these issues, the game has the potential to offer a more enjoyable experience for all players.
