I‚Äôm not sure why this game has negative reviews, I played this with a few friends and had a lot of fun would definitely recommend this game.

I don't really understand the negative reviews.

You need an internet connection to play, yes. Unless you're in the middle of a natural disaster, won't you have internet in the year 2023?

Game is fun to play with friends, and even if you don't have friends, there are enough maps and game modes that it's rewarding to play alone. 

Cosmetics really aren't that expensive. In 5 hrs I've earned enough currency to buy any of the premium skins I want... If you do weekly challenges, you'll get 20% of the amount of currency needed for a premium (most expensive types) of skin per week, and even more through leveling up. The only thing that feels a bit off are the surprise eggs, because after you earn the 10 or so through leveling up, the only way to get those blind draw skins are with money.

I think down the road they'll either need to add more levels to go through, or add in cheap battle passes to sustain the game.

Ultimately, as long as they can keep a steady pace of content I don't foresee this game going anywhere. It's tons of fun, and it improves on the Gang Beasts formula A LOT.


It's an 8.5/10 for me, and I foresee that score going up as long as they continue to add content.

Fighting your friends as puppies, kittens, and a whole menagerie of fuzzy creatures is an experience that's as delightful as it is hilarious. The game itself is very fun if you play it with friends or without.  It is quite funny, any K.O hit is absolutely brutal, me and my friends can have countless hours of fun playing either quick match or customs.  The biggest gripe for me though, is the achievements.  Some of them are simply easily or a nice little challenge to get...I know some games make these achievements a grind to get so you feel some sense of gratification, a game like this however, i don't feel as should have such hard achievements.  Most to all require you to do it in quick match which you can go in with a party of 4 to make your life a little easier, but to get 4-7 other people to either cooperate, or k.o so you can then go for them is quite difficult, hell its hard enough as it is to get friends to not throw anything or knock each other out.  The one achievement has you survive on a plane that ices over and you have to survive 2:30, and even when you get the people to cooperate, that challenge is damn near impossible.  I just hope they tweak the achievements at least a little bit...Other than that the game is very fun overall 7/10.

I've been following the development of this game since the very start when it was codenamed 'Happy Happy Nemo'. I was so glad when it was officially announced and I was hyped to buy and play it. Until I was met with a quick match that was restricted to teams only, no 8-man Free-For-Alls, instead, I got 2v2v2v2 and let's face it. Who is playing this game solo to play teams. I get the game is supposed to be played with friends and all that but the game should be able to be fun without them. The fact that you can't change the quick match search settings and are stuck to voting for a mode which will ALWAYS BE TEAMS (2v2v2v2 or 4v4) annoys the hell out of me. Also don't forget how the microtransactions are in your face, especially the fact that there are lootboxes and in-game currency obtainable by buying them. You'd think that the progression in a 20 dollar party game would allow you to buy all the cosmetics with only cookies with the option to buy cookies if you really wanna buy a skin immediately but I guess not. I'll re-buy it when they make good changes to the game because I really do wanna see this game thrive.

This game is really fun to play, the silly characters and mechanics are very on point. The many different stages and game modes keep you engaged and the 8 player cap makes it just enough mayhem but without getting crazy like fall guys for example (something about that much people and lag makes it less enjoyable for me). You can definitely progress the game and get avatars and cosmetics without spending another dollar, and there's enough of those I think. There IS a lot to buy don't get me wrong, which bothers me a bit because I usually enjoy seeing a lot more rewards for my progress in game but overall I don't think they're abusing players by paywalling all customization, just saying. Would be nice to have more servers in other parts of the world so people don't play in >100ms latency like in South America and Oceania but I read somewhere here that they did blunder a bit and running this thing is rather expensive so I wouldn't hold my breath on that one or buy it expecting that they expand it to other regions soon. 8/10.

[H1] SHORT SUMMARY: VERY RARELY I FIND IT HARD TO GIVE A GAME EITHER A RECOMMENDATION OR NOT. IT DOES EQUALLY GREAT BUT TERRIBLE THINGS. THIS HONESTLY COULD BE THE MOST NEUTRAL GAME I HAVE SEEN IN A LONG TIME. [/H1]
Hello, do you crave fun? Do you get some joy out of some fuzzy cartoon animals beating the ever-loving sense out of each other? Then I might have a game that might deserve your attention. Just don‚Äôt tell the Peta organization, although if you look into their dealings, they might have actually harmed more animals then they have saved.

[hr][/hr]
[H3] GAMEPLAY [/H3]
Gameplay Grade: A+

Party animals is family friendly casual type of game, where the player takes control of one of a selection of playable animals whose objective is to brawl it out over various game modes. Currently there are three modes available to play. Might not seem all that much but each one is enabled to be modified further with the game lobby settings.
[list]
    [*]Last Stand ‚Äî Where you need to be the last one standing in a full out brawl. If a player has been knocked out, they are able to through stuff into the arena to the betterment or detriment of the surviving players.
    [*]Team Score ‚Äî Here you‚Äôre set into at least 2 teams and trying to score points. When a team scores a point, the map will reset shortly after a quick replay showcasing the goofy ways people score points.
    [*]Arcade ‚Äî in the last mode you and optionally your team must throw your opponents out the arena to win. Nothing more than that in this mode.
[/list]

To help spice things up from time to time and keep things fresh, random items at random intervals will fall from the sky similar in such games like Super Smash Bros. Items such as a frying pan to send folks flying, plunger that sticks to people, freeze gun for well freezing other players, a taser to try out electroshock therapy, and plenty of others goofy little things. So, if you like, you can be a rabbit with a baseball bat, smacking down a dragon only to be drop kicked by a cat in swat tactical gear inside of a blackhole generator.

At its heart this game is a party game which means it is meant to be played with friends, or with strangers if you do not have any via quick play option. However, I must admit, the game loses its luster after around 2 hours because everyone has their enjoyment for the day and watching animals smack each other with shovels stops being as funny as it used to. That is until next and folks are trash talking towards one another and just enjoying their time being spent among friends in discord. This is a game you do not play for long periods of time, but after a break this game reminds fun and enjoyable.

I would give the gameplay an A+ for outstanding work. This game knew what it wanted to be, and it achieved it in this category. 

[hr][/hr]
[H3] PRESENTATION [/H3]
Presentation Grade: B

The presentation within the game is phenomenal. The usage of bright colors makes things appear more cute then it actually is, which given game‚Äôs style choice helps it tremendously. In an age where a lot of game developers are trying to push more pixels and higher fidelity, they fail to realize that given time that their style choice will fade where games that went with a softer more bright color style will last far longer. For example, you can look towards the Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker. The sound design is spot on especially with all the little items you can pick up and use. 

Yet the only real draw back within the presentation is that if you do creation content and have this game, you must disable the music within the game because it is copyrighted, thus if you publish videos or live stream it, you will get struck by the copyright system, and as of the time of posting there is no streamer mode. This is horrible because we live in the age of the internet, and does things that are counterproductive towards the age. No one would have much desire to share content of this game if they are going to get copyright struck.

Presentation earns a Solid B for doing the minimum to stand out but not going above and beyond.

[hr][/hr]
[H3] DRAWBACKS [/H3]
Drawbacks Grade: F

Onto the negatives, this game does not feature an offline play mode in any capacity. Yes, you can play split screen locally however you must connect to an online server initially to be able to play. This takes away from the customer because say these servers go offline, then your game is no longer available to be played. For recent example of this look towards Payday 3. You can have your online services but allow players to play the game they of bought.

The next thing I‚Äôm going to bring up is not excusable. The original description of the game had blatantly said offline play was in the game. However, it was then later removed shortly after the game‚Äôs release due to backlash for not having said mode. The developers had given a news post on Wednesday September 20th stating that this was due a translation error. Granted things get lost in translation but you had 2 years to comb over everything since the last beta to launch. Even if was not meant to, you have falsely advertised your game. 

This game also has an in-game shop where you can exchange your money for paid currency in currency packs. Common practice in current affairs but they also do the thing where you cannot directly purchase the cute outfits you desire and will you will have left over currency. This is known tactic, which may be known as a ‚ÄúDark Pattern‚Äù to direct the player to buy even more currency. Now I will state that a large number of outfits can be obtained through standard play given time, but that doesn‚Äôt excuse the fact that you can exchange your paid currency of a 2 to 15 rate to buy the earnable outfits much faster if you have the money. I also need point out that the shop store is a rotating one which is known to pressure people into buying things because they do not know when something will be available again if ever. Through leveling your account, you will earn up to $20ish dollars of paid currency for free. Some outfits could be more expensive than the game itself. You are also unable to purchase the outfits directly and must buy the currency packs.

There is also loot boxes but referred to as surprised eggs, you can earn a token during play via leveling up or by purchasing a spin via paid currency. As the game currently stands, you can only get set number of spins for free from leveling up. It reminds to be seen if the player will be able to earn more after reaching max level. If I recall Loot boxes are banned in the Netherlands and legislation around the world is picking up about the issue.

Either through lack of attention, incompetence, or outright direct design, this game has a Dark Pattern. If you like to have a thorough explanation or further information, The Youtube channels Techquickie and Extra history have done video content that explains this further then I can in this steam review due to character limitations. In short, this game will never ask for your confirmation when you purchase something. The F.T.C. here in the United States has been battling these types of issues in court cases. Please add a confirmation button to the game.

[hr][/hr]
[H3] FOOTNOTES [/H3]
Final Grade: C+

Greatness can be easily ruined by horrible actions, hopefully this game can improve upon the groundwork that has been laid. Party Animals can easily get an A+ but the drawbacks are too great. I want this game to be a success because video games are my hobby and I want the best for everyone. Sadly I would have to leave a not recommended here because there is no neutral setting in the process.

Consider joining the Steam curator group: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/39651895/
For me its an hot blurry mess and half the controls dont seem too work what am watse

After almost 4 hours of playtime, I can not agree with any of the negative reviews. People are complaining about microtransation when I have yet to see a single sign that the game wants me to spend money on skins or to be better at the game. The only microtransactions that might be ingame, are the ones that let you purchase Nemo Bucks. They are NOT required and give you zero benefit except skins. There is also no pay-to-win factor to this game, it's all cosmetics.

You don't want the skins? Don't spend the money. A voluntary payment is not grounds for a negative review.

Now to the game:

Party Animals is a fun PvP game that lets you play adorable animals in different party games. Some are in teams, some are in duos. The controls are different but not difficult and just something that need a little bit of getting used to. I can personally say that me and my friends have laughed so much that our stomachs hurt from this game and I'm looking forward to all the fun we'll have in the future. 

The game has a level up system that lets you unlock A LOT of free things. Skins, Avatars, Avatar Frames etc., even ingame currency from Egg Coins, to Cookies and Nemo Bucks. You can also get Twitch drops like currency and a cute Twitch skin from there.

In the end, it's awesome. The pricing wasn't too high, the gameplay is hilarious, the games are super fun and the negative reviews are from people that clearly don't realize that every game nowadays has something that will require some form of small payment, be it lootboxes, skins, weapons etc. Party Animals is no different and at least those purchases aren't being rubbed in my face.

Love the game and would definitely recommend it!

At this point, I don't recomend it, its hilarious and very, veryyy FUN, [b]BUT[/b]

[b]- The system is very random in battles, making it frustrating practically every time, what do I mean by this for example:

- You land several hits and your opponent is not stunned

- You knock your opponent off the platform or into the frozen river several times and he comes back

- You receive a blow and stay stunned for 2x to 3x longer than your opponent, even if you also stunned him with 100% of your stamina

- When the opponent throws you, you die or freeze immediately, unlike them who always return[/b]

In other words, the system that calculates the "HP" of this game is broken, I play for fun and I don't want to tryhard, but losing several rounds because of this crappy system is frustrating

In short, the game is very fun, very beautiful, but its system needs a [b]HUGE POLISHING[/b] because it needs a lot to be good

Party Animals is a quirky game filled with amusing animal characters, each offering a variety of skins that you can acquire through an egg machine or by spending cookies and in-game currency earned by leveling up or by "investing" real money. With a vast selection to choose from, there's something for everyone. (except for animal abusers ig...)

The game truly shines when played with friends, creating memorable and hilarious moments. However, be prepared for a bit of chaos if someone in your group decides to become the disruptor instead of focusing on team tasks, leading to entertaining but often annoying battles and knockouts. (I'm that person, friends hate me... pls hug me and say it's gonna be alright...)

I'd recommend using a controller for a smoother and more enjoyable experience, as the mouse and keyboard combo may feel less intuitive. (and you'll most likely destroy your mouse by smashing it all over your desk)

The game's price point is a consideration. If you have friends to join in the fun, it's worth it. However, if you're planning to play solo, you might want to wait for a sale or explore other titles. Paying ‚Ç¨18 for an online-only 'phone-style' game with additional microtransactions for characters and skins can seem a bit steep.

In terms of maps and game modes, Party Animals delivers enjoyable and well-crafted experiences. My only wish is that there were more maps to keep the gameplay even more diverse and exciting.

For my own experience, I've consistently had a blast playing Party Animals. However, I can't say the same for my friends, given that I tend to be making the game difficult for them. While I find the idea of spending extra money on skins a bit unnecessary, I'm content with the selection of free options available.

I am surprised about the negative reviews the game has got ( the review seems to be getting better slowly).  The game is fun, creative, and worked perfectly since day 1. This type of game developed by an indie developer could be a buggy mess but I have yet to encounter a single bug, and that proves how much the developer cared about the game.

If Rubber Bandits and Gang Beasts had a child this would be the game. Multiple different maps with up to 8 players, different game modes, custom lobbies. Heck of a lot of fun with people and always a blast. Plenty of things to unlock via achievements and also igc "cookies" to buy cosmetics. No battle pass, but leveling progression system with rewards. The game is also auto-fill and you will most of the time have a full lobby unless someone leaves.

I have been waiting for Party Animals for almost three years and pre-ordered the game as soon as it was available. The characters are still incredibly adorable and the gameplay is still as fun as the demo. I have seen some reviews of others complaining that the developers only added a few maps and skins to the official release compared to the demo years ago, but as someone who didn't get to play it before, this is already a lot of maps and modes to explore!

The game is definitely F2P-friendly, as you can earn both of the two in-game currencies and coins used to draw eggs from the claw machine or purchase straight from the shop to get most of the character skins just by playing and leveling up. The rest are achievement rewards. The skins are all just cosmetics and don't affect the gameplay itself, so you can still win using any basic character without the clothes.

Some other bad reviews are about being unable to play offline and local multiplayer (shared/split-screen) issues, so if you are just planning to play online co-op and PvP, give it a shot. There're updates coming with new seasonal features, game modes, and cosmetics frequently. If you have enough friends to play with (or against), you will probably have the funniest and most enjoyable time together.

Most of the negative reviews here seem to be centred around the fact you must always be online to play (including local multiplayer) AND there is a vending machine style loot box you can roll on to get cosmetics. If these things bother you, don't get the game.

That being said, the game itself is fantastic. I would definitely recommend playing with friends, but the physics system just creates an abundance of hilarious moments. Weapons are well designed, most maps have a unique gimmick, some of these can be very fun to work around while trying to knock each other out of an arena. Most importantly, the game breathes polish, it has been very well made with a stylistic art style that looks gorgeous.

Naturally some of the maps are more fun than others, myself preferring the brawl knock-out style game modes to the sport based ones for example, but there is a voting system that can be used before each game that tends to avoid the less popular maps.

If you're looking for a purely fun party game to play with friends, i'm not sure there is much better out there.

Pro's:
- Adorable aesthetic, with hilarious animations and just a really solid, polished look throughout.
- Decently accessible control scheme.

Con's:
- Online connection is required even for local play. They have been pitching it this entire time on the premise of "play online or offline," and only walked that promise back after people bought it and it became clear that the devs were lying. Tried to play with friends at a party at my house, and there were numerous additional steps to make it a "private" server even with all of us on one machine. And, of course, an online connection was required. Took the wind out of our sails almost instantly.
- Because they discreetly built this whole game around the online component, the "shared screen" multiplayer that makes Gang Beasts so easy to pick up and play is gone here. Every player gets their own tiny split screen, which is honestly just absurd for a game of this nature and scale. Each of us struggling to make out details on 1/4th of the screen space we would otherwise have, on an arena that's so small that we're basically all looking at a tiny version of the exact same thing from slightly different angles. Not at all worth the trade-off for camera control in a game where we shouldn't even be thinking about the camera.

I was excited at the prospect of being able to play this game online when local play wasn't an option, but to see that online  has completely dominated the design philosophy of this game is a massive downer. It's been one of my most anticipated games for a long time, but I returned it after an hour. Honestly so incredibly disappointed.
This game has the potential to be a better version of Gang Beasts. The biggest improvement to be made is a fixed camera angle for Local Coop. Fantastic game otherwise!

    This game is fire. If you like Gang Beasts you should totally get this. Even if you don't like gang beasts or know what Gang Beasts is, you should get this. A lot of people are complaining about microtransactions, but they aren‚Äôt that bad. Yes, you can buy currency, but you can also earn it in the free ‚Äúbattle pass‚Äù like system. Sometimes items in the shop will cost actual money, but like just don‚Äôt buy them. You can get plenty of skins by just playing. Most of the negative reviews are due to the lack of offline mode. While I agree that this feature is a must-have for people, I don't think that makes the game deserving of negative review. This is an incredibly fun and well made game. The launch had a rough start with the server queue due to the flood of players but after that first day I haven't had any server issues, crashes, or encountered any game breaking bugs.

I also see complaints about the price of the items in the store and while I agree that the prices are high, there are plenty of challenges, achievements and ways to earn in-game currency without spending any real money. 

With 20 maps at launch and multiple different modes, I feel $20 is about right on par with the amount of content that it offers. If you're looking for a fun, casual, and competitive game to play with friends or even by yourself, you can't go wrong with this.

Got this to play with friends because it seemed like a fun little party game and boy is it poorly made with terrible inconsistency.

Players who play on MKB have an advantage to those who play with controllers. Can pickup and throw you right away while on controller you have to wait for input lag to grab things. You get knocked out for longer than others with no chance to recover or come back. Sometimes even one hit KOs right at the start of the match with just one punch and not a weapon. Some weapons can KO you with one hit as well, the shovel seems the one that can do it the most often. 

At times you can be the last one standing but the win is awarded to another team. Groups of 4 will team up and win trade rounds and gang up on solo teams. Too many AFKs that are replaced with an AI bot that just stands around and does nothing. 

Terrible network connections that cause lag throughout the whole match and will drop you out of the match. Oh and you will end up with a leaver queue as if this game is ranked.

[h1] You must be curious why this game has so many negative reviews in Chinese. [/h1]
For English speakers:
If you know what this game has done in China, you will know why Chinese players give so many negative reviews to a game produced by a Chinese studio.
They had released a demo three years ago, when the epidemic was in lockdown and everyone was at home with nothing to do. If they had released the game then, it would have been a monumental achievement in the history of gaming, probably on par with 2016's Overwatch. But they didn't, insisting that the game needed more processing, which took almost four years. The pandemic is over, and naturally people don‚Äôt have time to play party games. 
This is actually not the point. I just want to complain a bit as a player who has waited for so long. [h3] The real point begins here. [/h3]
Before the game was finally released, the producers made it clear in interviews that their nitpicks resulted in the game being too expensive to run, and [u] they were not shy about making it clear that they were prepared to make players pay for the company's operational missteps. [/u] [b] However, there doesn‚Äôt seem to be much problem with the price in Europe or the United States? [/b] 
We all know that games on Steam are priced differently in different countries, which usually depends on economic conditions and exchange rates. The same type of party games are often priced [b] half [/b] as much in China as in the United States, while Party Animals are almost the [b ]same [/b] price as in the United States. To refer back to the previous paragraph, [u] they were not shy about making it clear that they were prepared to make players pay for the company's operational missteps. [/u]  [h3] So, let‚Äôs guess which players bear this cost? [/h3]
[b] Any promotions and announcements from the studio based in English are a mask of hypocrisy as they have never released the same content in Chinese, [/b] even though this is a Chinese studio. Their attitude towards Chinese players is ignorance and arrogance. [u] Some people posted videos on China's YouTube (some of you may have heard of it, namely bilibili) exposing the company's different treatment of English users and Chinese players. However, these videos were subsequently reported and deleted by the company, and any negative comments and questions raised by the player community have also been blocked and deleted without an official reply. [/u]
[b] Finally, I'll talk about what's really about the game itself. [/b] After almost four years of work, what's the difference between a game and a demo? I don't know how many of you have played that demo, but the answer is, [b] almost nothing, [/b] except for some paid skins and raffle boxes.
In addition, in China, the in-game currency was officially designated as "ni mo bi". If translated into English, it would be, " [spoiler] phack u coin/dollar [/spoiler] ", just read it out. [strike] Could this be an unintentional mistake? [/strike]
Yes, this has nothing to do with any non-Chinese people. I just want to show that our anger is not unfounded. [h2] Chinese player have indeed suffered unfair treatment from a Chinese company. [/h2] How ironic! But if you still can‚Äôt understand the reason for so many bad reviews based on Chinese, then I can only wish you good luck.

As somebody with about 40 hours played in this game, here are my thoughts. A great game and super fun to play with friends. For those who don't have friends (L), you can join there discord and be a part of a fun, decently nice, community. While it isn't the best game, it is very fun and for at least a good while, not repetitive (In my opinion). I understand that people have their frustrations with the game, I have my fair share of dislikes as well, but it is still an overall fun game! I personally think it is best to start playing with a friend if possible, so you can learn together. I also recommend watching videos by "@ScoobyYTT" on YouTube for tips when you are starting, or when you just need some extra help. In conclusion, party animals is a pretty good game. It is very fun with friends, and has a large (mostly) friendly community around it. If you have the $20 dollars to spend, I recommend using it on this game.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

developer_response:
Hey there,

Sorry for the inconvenience. We will need your log to further analyze the issue. Please follow the steps below to get the log:

1. Quit game.
2. Right click "Party Animals", then click "Properties". Type "-log" in the "Launch Options", and close the Properties window.
3. Restart the game. Then in Steam Library, right click "Party Animals ", then "Manage", then "browse local files". In the pop-up windows, you will see log files named "2023-09-xx_xxxxxxxxx-Laptop Name". Each game session will generate one log.
4. Try to reproduce the issue and remember the time when you encounter it. Then quit the game, and ZIP all the log files.

Please go to our website https://support.partyanimals.com/login , and create a ticket with a topic describing the issue, and the time you encounter it. Then attach the zip file to the ticket and click send.

We will get back to you as soon as we find out what's going wrong.

Thank you for supporting Party Animals!

review:
Game is fun, but I won't recommend it in its current state:

- There's no offline mode. Why does a party game need to be online-only other than trying to sell expensive skins? Speaking of which...
- Extremely predatory mtxs. There's a skin that literally costs more than the game itself.
- Some modes are just extremely unfair (having an ice gun in the fighter jet level, giving whoever can grab it a huge advantage, as anyone who gets shot are automatically eliminated).
- You get a 1-2 minute ban from Quick Play if you quit, which is dumb for a non-competitive party game. Why should I stay in the game when my team has been eliminated on the last round? This is Gang Beasts with animals, not Halo. Nobody is taking this game that seriously, nor should they.
- This is just my experience, but playing solo is a pain. I couldn't win a single round due to having crappy teammates more than half the time.
- Even though chances of winning are low, if you happen to be in a huge losing streak, you'll still have the same player level, as this game seems to only reward XP for wins. Even Fall Guys lets you progress without winning.

I was just punished for quitting early, even though my game was frozen in the stage select screen. Also, one of the daily challenges was to eliminate 10 people as the Bat, even though there was no way for me to unlock it without paying more money for in-game currency in order to even have the CHANCE to unlock it.
Game is extremely fun with friends

I really don't understand why everyone is giving all this hate on the game. 

Yeah, there's tons of micro-transactions, but if you complete achievements and just play the game, you will have the opportunity to unlock tons of characters. I've already put like 8 hours into the game and have plenty of skins and characters to choose from. 

I love this game so much. I've had fun playing with some friends and its just all around a fun and friendly competition type of game. Physics are awesome. The UI and designs of the game are beautiful. Maps are well thought out. 

The only critique I have is that when I've tried redeeming codes, I get network errors constantly and have to try like 5-6 times before it registers and when I search for custom games or people, the search can take up to a minute of trying to find something. But thats something I know will get fixed in due time. 

Well done, Recreate Games.

[h1]A Well Deserved 5/10.[/h1]

10 Hour Later Update:

Party Animals is [i]still[/i] a very fun game marred by idiotic and questionable design choices. 

[h2]The Good[/h2]
[list]
[*]Fun gameplay and physics, some fun levels.  Good times fighting friends [i]online[/i].  You'll for sure get a laugh out of it.
[*]Lot's of characters to choose from.  Many are unlocked by achievements, though some can be very frustrating, it's nice that they are there.   
[*]Graphics are very good.  The aesthetics of the game are great.
[/list]

[h2]Middle of the Road[/h2]
[list]
[*]Limited time skins.  Nice they are having some crossovers with other games (like Ori and the Blind Forest) but annoying that they are limited time events praying on your FOMO.  These skins are also SUPER expensive and nearly impossible to get both unless you play religiously.
[/list]

[h2]The Bad[/h2]
[list]
[*]Microtransactions (or should I say macro at this point?).  One legendary skin costs more than the entire game.  Loot box's are in the form of eggs you open.  Sounds like you can get duplicates.  There's something that resembles a seasonal battle pass that's free, I'd expect that to change in the future.  It has everything a scummy F2P mobile game would, but with a price tag of $20 on top of it.  Seems predatory towards kids, and I don't like that.  (I'm aware it's all cosmetic, but releasing a paid game with MTX skins day one is a negative mark from me.  Anything developed pre-release should just be available to earn via playing day one.  Monetize your game later all you want, so long as its a fair priced model.)
[*]No offline mode.  Presumable ripped out to keep people online and wanting to spend money on their MTX's.  Changing the game description after the fact is also scummy.  I do have a steam deck, and guess I'll never get to play this one on the go.  Anyone defending this is simping.
[*]Local play is a mess.  You cannot customize each controller to each players desired preferences.  If I want my Y-axis inverted and the other player doesn't, tough luck.  The game also letterbox's the screen (black bars top and bottom), so you lose a good portion of your usable screen and get stuffed into tiny screens of your own.  Games like Human Fall Flat don't do this, why does Party Animals need to?  (update:  work around to controls is playing via two PC's on Steam Remote Play, and having the second player map their controls through big picture.  You also have to drag and drop controllers to other slots via the steam overlay as remote host to get them to register.  JANK).
[*]Quite a few levels are super lack luster and boring.  Not enough levels for it to not get stale after a relatively short amount of time.  
[*]Party and UI system kinda sucks.  No options to choose if you want to quick-join into a 2v2v2v2 or a 4v4.  I prefer the fighting, not interested in janky soccer.
[*]Matchmaking bans if you leave a game you don't want to play.  Nobody is taking this game that seriously, especially when you're forcing quick-join on us and not letting us set some parameters of what we want to play.
[/list]

Mostly just a quick summary of my initial thoughts.  I think the developers should re-visit local play, as well as offline if this is indeed supposed to be a party game.  I already know nothing will be done about their macrotransactions as whales are sure to keep spending.  Game will need more levels ASAP or people will definitely start getting bored.  

If all the things I listed above don't sound like they'd bother you, then maybe you'd enjoy Party Animals.  It can be fun and hilarious, but as of right now the cons outweigh the pros.

If this review makes you mad because you associate this game with your own identity, leave a comment crying about it.  Surely it'll make you feel better.

This is a bad game with no added value three years after the demo. What a disappointment!

To be fair, I was one of the players who played the original demo 3 years ago. The game was new, vibrant and fun. 
After three years of development, there is nothing new apart from a few maps and the ridiculous random-ass throwing mini-game after death, which absolutely ruins the game and adds another random element to the already random fights.

I believe the physics have gotten a LOT worse since the beta. I do not remember experiencing such randomness back then. The game does really poor job in registering hits and the sheer nonsense of how long you get knocked for is absolutely mind-boggling. I Usually, get knocked out for 6+ seconds, while the others get knocked out for barely 2 seconds. It has also happened to me several times that  I have been killed by a single hit right at the start of a match, how ridiculous is that?

Also, the local co-op? Hah, good one, devs, sure, language barrier xD

I would definitely not recommend anyone to buy this game.

This game has some awesome fun to be had with friends, however... the knockout mechanics are odd to say the least. They are extremely inconsistent. Someones i punch someone in the face and it knocks them out, sometimes it does not, and sometimes the knockouts last 3 seconds, sometimes they last 10+ seconds. The raw inconsistency of the core game play mechanic, makes this game extremely frustrating. Although this can be annoying, the amount of crazy funny things that can happen are high, and the "after death" mechanics are absolutely great. Throwing an item from the dead to knock out a friend is super funny and tossing a bomb into the mix of a small map creates some good moments.

DON'T MIND THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS!

The complains generally point out the in-game shop for premium skins, even though it is a quite costly game!
If you don't want them, don't buy them. That easy.
There is a leveling system with different rewards, like skins and currency (for skins), and achievements to give you even more skins. 
No Pay-To-Win system at all, only cosmetics!

Gameplaywise I'm having a blast and laughing at all the shenanigans happening in the game, like someone knocking himself out with his own nunchuck xD
There are several new maps and many different team-based 4v4 arcade modes, that were not available in the beta.
Another new feature for spectators are throwable items, so that you can still annoy players from beyond the grave.

Few additional notes:
- Can queue up as up to 4 players (max players per map are 8. so 4v4 or 4 teams of 2) -> haven't tried out as 3, but you'll probably get a random in your team
- You have to choose unique players names and there have been many instances, where I would get matched with players with racial slurs in their names. So far there is no option to report them.
- Games can get pretty onesided, if one team knows what it's doing and the other don't. Not suggesting a rank system, but it can get frustrating for easily tilted players. If you can't take an L in a fun game, then this might not be for you.

Okay so I love love LOVE this game. I‚Äôve been waiting for it‚Äôs release since the demo in 2020, so the new maps were a welcome addition to what i was already pining for. The game is less expensive than I thought it would be, so the shop doesn‚Äôt bother me. All of the costumes and animals are super adorable, and the chaos is super fun and funny. The fast paced nature also makes it easy to recover from a loss, and I personally feel like the array of maps now gives gamers of differing strengths their ‚Äòtime to shine‚Äô so to speak (ex: someone more strategy oriented can have advantage in certain modes against those more combat oriented). Having been so focused on this game for 3 years, I was inwardly pretty defensive about all of the bad reviews on release day, but now that I‚Äôve had time to process I have some more thoughts. I‚Äôm not gonna focus on the ones that I don‚Äôt personally have an issue with (I play most games online solo, and again, the shop just doesn‚Äôt bother me) but more so ones not brought up:

For starters, friendly fire is a big issue. You can turn it off for custom games, but not QP. If you‚Äôre a little spacey like me, it‚Äôs not always easiest to tell who is on your team when everyone is in a frenzy and the colors are a blur. I‚Äôve knocked a few people out purely by accident, and then I can‚Äôt even send a message in game apologizing or explaining myself. There are also leave penalties, which are understandable, but if your teammate accidentally knocks you out (or purposely because you wouldn‚Äôt know), of course you‚Äôre going to be mad and want to quit! Furthermore, sometimes the AI replacements are seemingly OP, and I‚Äôm suspicious that the matchmaking algorithm isn‚Äôt quite right yet. 
Continuing on, in last stand, sometimes (often enough to be a problem) the game glitches and awards the win to the second place player instead. It‚Äôs absolutely infuriating to see every other player go down and then have the star go to someone else, and if it happens to you, it often just feels sleazy, cause you know you didn‚Äôt deserve it. 
Then there are the spectator items. When you knock someone out with one, it‚Äôs AMAZING but when someone knocks you out, it‚Äôs rage inducing. There is no way to really dodge these, and it‚Äôs very easy to bean someone with pure luck, which means that even if you‚Äôre the best player on the team, you could potentially consistently lose just due to spectator items. There‚Äôs no way to turn them off in custom or otherwise, and they have consistently ruined a great game for me. 
Lastly, there is the server issue. This doesn‚Äôt personally affect me, but I felt like it was worth mentioning regardless, as it‚Äôs a BIG mess up. There are no Australian servers. If you are in AUS, you will have to connect to Asian servers, and the ping is just atrocious. If I was an Aussie buyer, I‚Äôd be pretty peeved. 

To sum it all up: I think this game is absolutely worth it, especially at $20 (unless of course you‚Äôre from down under). There are definitely hours of fun to be had, and the AI is pretty decent in custom games, so you can enjoy on your own, with friends, or with strangers. The designs are cute and fun and the game modes are delightful, especially so to someone who played the demo and expected just that. Like any new game, there are issues, and I would appreciate them being fixed, but in my experience, they‚Äôre minimal enough that I would continue to play in any case.

Party Animals is an addictingly fun arena brawler with incredibly cute and fuzzy animals, each level has its own unique gimmick and each round feel reasonably short & sweet. 

You can que with up to 3 friends for Quickmatch where you can vote on 1 of 3 levels to play which can either be the last stand type levels, where all players are divided into teams of 2 for a first to 3 survival where you try to be the last man standing, hope is not lost if you're eliminated as you can throw in various objects into the field which can either save your duo partner from elimination or secure the round for someone else in a very comedic effect. Alternatively you can also vote to play any of the 4v4 team maps where you need to work together as a team to score points and win.

If just playing random maps with other players isn't your forte, then you can always host your own Custom-Games where you can play against bots and customize the game rules to your heart's content, if you only want to play privately with friends then this mode is for you. You even have access to play a pair of Fight Club levels where your teams objective is to pumble and yeet your opponents off the safe areas of maps until the other team runs out of lives.

As far as balance goes some items can feel incredible oppressive and difficult to work against, unless you can time your punches and jump kicks right you might end up having someone smack you with a shovel until you're knocked out for good or comically yeeted off the stage, while other items like the freeze and stun-guns can feel incredibly oppressive to fight against at times, if nobody who's already eliminated knocks down the gun standing player that has someone in an indefinite stunlock, it can very easily feel like you're not allowed to play the game when someone is perfectly positioned to constantly hit you with the stun-gun with every shot...

If you enjoy fun and over the top comedic brawling games like Gang-Beasts then consider giving this game a try as well, and if you're a bit picky about your spending then i highly recomend picking this game up when its on a sale.

(at the time of making this review 9/24) I'm very neutral about this game. its not bad, but I've played better rag-doll fighters, the problem is, some maps when you get knocked out of the ring the climbing is inconstant, you'll sometimes get out on the first try and sometimes you won't. but sometimes when you do, theirs someone waiting for you to knock you back down. Someone has a two handed weapon? don't try to get near them unless other people are. weapons don't break so they can keep spamming them unless its the nun chucks then there's a chance that they'll knock themselves out but it doesn't happen often, and when it does your already dead. So far there is no queue for certain game modes or teams, so you have to get lucky that 1 outta 3 maps are the one you wanna play. most of the half of the modes are 4 teams of 2, so maps feel really cramped at times. if they added an option for 1v1, 2v2, 3v3, or 4v4 then you wouldn't have three other teams to worry about. this game is just at the name says PARTY animals, it's still fun to play, but it really shines when you play with friends where as quick play, it's just yourself unless you get a friend. When you're by yourself you can get a rageful teammate who tries to knock you out when you accidentally knock them out because most people don't communicate with each other, and it's very annoying/ difficult to see who your teammate is because they will have their small name as your team color, it would be nice if they had an outline or showed who your teammate is when selecting the animal so you know what they look like. this game has only been out for less than a week so everything i said will/ might change and so will my opinion about this game, I might like it more, I might like it less. If you are thinking of buying it go ahead but play with friends for the time being. If you don't have any friends then i recommend waiting, making friends, or playing custom games. 6/10 because with friends it's fun.

[h1]If you were thinking about picking up Party Animals for couch-coop play, unfortunately I have to just recommend you look elsewhere. The local play is just flat out bad. Gang beasts got this right six years ago, and it's sad that this game can't do the same.[/h1]

In couch coop play, you are forced to create a lobby on the internet, so if your internet is bad, or you're on the go, for instance (Steam Deck :) you're shit outta luck, you basically cannot play. But let's say, you do have a decent internet connection, there's still a glaring issue. For the main gamemode, last man standing, every player is forced into using a quadrant (1/4) of the screen to play, which means if you're sitting a reasonable distance from the screen, in a four player match, you will not be able to tell what's going on half the time. This problem does not fix itself even when playing with two players, as the screens are divided into the small boxes instead of a split horizontally or vertically. Though I think the only thing that could fix this problem, is scrapping the different views for all four players, and consolidating it into one, big view, where the camera dynamically shifts to where players are positioned in the map. And you can still have the spectators throwing items, just have their cursors be a different color to differentiate and put a lil icon of the currently selected item, plus a little bar with slices in it to be the 'coins.' I can understand the split perspectives for team modes, though maybe just consider having one per team, to reduce screen clutter.

All these problems make me really sad, because this game, I truly believe has the potential to far surpass the amount of fun and chaos you can have in something like Gang Beasts. This game has the potential to be the absolute highlight of any party game session, and leave everyone feeling like they had fun. I know this because even just playing the matchmaking that's in the game with random people, I had a blast, and I know it'd be far more enjoyable with my friends. But with that, all the issues the game has just makes it a flat out bad party game, and right now, I don't think it's deserving of the title "Party" Animals. Because right now, the best way to play this game is on a screen of your own, and if you wanted that true party experience, you'd have to setup a lan party.

If any developers are reading this, know that I love Party Animals, you have all made such an amazing and charming game, with some brilliant gameplay and maps. I think if you changed the way you handle the local coop, your game could be the headlining party game of all my, and many others, parties.

Party Animals is an absolute blast of a game that brings laughter, excitement, and a whole lot of joy into your gaming sessions. While I can't confirm its performance on lower-end systems, my experience on standard hardware was smooth and optimised. Playing with friends is where Party Animals truly shines with its online multiplayer options, delivering hours of hilarity. And for those times when you want to go solo, you can still join in on the multiplayer action online, making it just as entertaining. Micro-transactions are cosmetic only, and you can earn in-game currency through gameplay. I hope the developers stay consistent with updates because Party Animals has the potential to be a long-term favourite, offering a lighthearted and laughter-inducing gaming experience that's hard to beat.

First and foremost: you have to be online to play this game. This sucks. Devs please make an offline mode. Im recommending this game for now but if this doesn't change I will change this recommendation in the future.

As for the game, its "oh crap the kids need to go to bed because we lost track of time, played 3 hours straight, and now its an hour past their bedtime" fun. Seriously, my kids and I had a blast playing and we are looking forward to playing tomorrow.

You DO NOT need to play with random internet strangers. You can, but you can just as easily go to Custom Game, make the lobby private, have the other players press RT on their controller, and now you've got "connected to internet but local only" couch game. Even better? Get a friend with a computer, have them load up 4 players, join your private lobby, and now you have 8 player mayhem.

There are 3 categories of game modes, and so far none feel gimmicky. FYI I have not tried all the maps for each category. There is the classic - beat up the other teams, throw them off, knock out mode with 9 maps. Each map we have tried (maybe 6 out 9 so far) has been a different experience and brought new obstacles to the mode. 

The next category is team/score based. There are several different maps, we have only tried 4 and each mode has been a blast. There is soccer and football mode: and i really thought this would be a gimmicky mode but nah, it was actually fun. Nothing like playing soccer, running to the ball, jumping and drop kicking the ball halfway across the map while you knock out an opposing team member. Blissful. My kids and I spent like 20 minutes in each mode. 

There was another really cool mode: parallel coal powered trains. Each team has to throw coal into the steam engine to make it speed up. The train that speeds ahead the furthest wins. Sounds kind of interesting, maybe some opportunity for teamwork, but wait... you can hop to the enemy train! You can smack them around, pull the brake and really cause mayhem to help your team. Or you could hit a sign along the train track jumping to the enemy train and get hit with a 10 second respawn timer.

There was another mode my kids and I tried on a whim, again, thinking it was going to be a gimmicky mode to fluff out the game but nope! It was some sort of capture the flag game except the flag was a safe tied to a air balloon floating in the middle of the map. And you have to jump grab and hobble back to your base to score. It took us a couple minutes to figure out how to move the flag around but once we did, it was a blast.

In arcade category, there are two maps with one being called "final destination." We tried that and to our surprise it is two teams of up to 4 each in a subway station fighting it out with 10 lives for each team. Some weapons can take out enemy teammates but the main method to reduce the enemy life bar is to knock them out, throw them on the subway track, and have them run over. The only problem is subways run every 15 seconds or so and you can get back up. This leads to mayhem, confusion, sacrifices to take down the other team.

I do want to point out there is the ability to pay real money for cosmetic stuff, but it hasnt been overly obnoxious in your face. Its there, at the bottom of the screen. We did unlock a token after about an hour of play that let us unlock a new character, which was cool. It sucks that it is kind of pay walled. You could grind to get currency or meet some objective to unlock a coin to get a new character, but its not designed to make the grind feel rewarding, like new skins every 1/2 or so of gameplay.

Overall, this is gang beasts mechanics with tons of different modes added to make it really stand out as its own game. It requires you to be connected to the internet, which is kind of a bummer. No true offline couch coop allowed (as of writing this review). Even though its a paid game, you will find that getting new skins is a grind that isn't rewarding and using real money is the quickest.

This game has a few grievances with it that are all completely valid: No offline mode despite the wording originally saying there was (the dev team even doubling down that it was essentially a reading error (they were right, you were wrong) due to English not being their first language), and the monetisation model for the game.

Again, neither of these are invalid complaints.

Just because Fall Guys got away with it when it was a paid game, doesn't make it okay. The multitude of different currencies are akin to mobile games made solely to trick people into spending money (including ridiculously bad conversion rates). This is bad business practice, players want ONE kind of currency from a paid game, no bullshit.

Despite these grievances - the game is good for what it is. It's a solid foundation for a genuinely fun party game.

- The hitboxes are janky, but that almost works in its favour as if they were too defined, the game may become too sweaty.
- The AI players are less than useless, in team-based game modes they essentially just run at the objective and are made to be fodder. In elimination modes, they don't even fight back, or just end themselves like Amazon package drones that realised they're not being paid.
- The report system is pretty lackluster considering the profanity filter is *too* good, including the blocking of "God." I can't believe how many times I've heard slurs be yelled in a party game about fluffy animals being sucked into a black hole.
- The servers and matchmaking suck, like, Multiversus tier suck. If you try to punch someone that you got matched with that's in Mexico, playing on their stolen Xbox, that punch isn't going through. In fact - you've already been punched one thousand times and they've won three times before you even realised you're dead.
- No filters for certain maps. I don't want to play team-based modes with Jimmy Jr. (4) that's on his dad's Steam Deck in the basement with one bar of wifi that feels nothing but the urge to run at the ball, or grab anything that moves. I don't want that.
- The music is awful. Seriously. 

It sounds like a lot of negative points, and that's true. But despite this, I recommend it because it's fun, and I really hope they keep moving in a direction that focuses on the fun elements it has.

This game is my favorite game since Wobbly Life! (tied with Wobbly Life)

Party Animals is a cute game with a lot of content for only 20 bucks. Some of the most fun I've had in a party game recently. It took my friends and I about 3 hours to play every map and game mode. It plays very smooth, is easy to pick up, finding lobbies is easy, and the graphics are cute. I load into the game very quickly. It does what gang beasts did but with way more content and replay value. 

I am always annoyed by micro-transaction systems, but I never care as long as it is cosmetic -- as it is with this game. It is very unobtrusive. You can usually unlock animals from achievements anyways. 

[b]Addressing other complaints:[/b] it is annoying that it can't be played offline. However, anyone who bought it and found out they couldn't could VERY EASILY get a refund. There's no excuse to review bomb the game now that it is very clear its online only. I think its sad that a game the developers put a lot of love and time into is being bombed for a fixed mistranslation and a cosmetic microtransaction system.

Game Duration and Experience: Recently, I played for about 5-hours with a few friends on a discord call, and what an exhilarating experience it was! It's not an exaggeration to state that this has been one of the most enjoyable gaming experiences I've had in recent memory.

Laughter Galore: The game does a fantastic job of creating spontaneous moments of hilarity. Throughout our session, there was hardly a moment where someone wasn't erupting into laughter or cheering. The sheer amount of joy this game has brought into our session is a testament to its brilliance.

Controversies and Misunderstandings: I've noticed that there has been some contention regarding the game's offline capabilities, which has unfortunately led to mixed reviews. To address the elephant in the room, I'd like to point out that party games, by design, thrive on interaction. Thus, the idea of playing such a game offline seems counterintuitive. Though the developers might have hinted at offline capabilities, it wasn't showcased in any of the playtests I'm aware of. It‚Äôs essential to evaluate a game by its strengths, and this game shines when played with others, be it online or offline.

Setting the Record Straight: Party games are fundamentally about togetherness and creating memorable moments. They aren't solitary experiences. Whether you're snuggled up on a couch with friends or connecting through an online platform, the essence remains the same ‚Äì fun-filled interactions. I genuinely believe that many who gave this game a negative review may have missed the point entirely.

Verdict: Party Animals delivers an outstanding party gaming experience that should be celebrated and recognized. The essence of a party game is its ability to bring joy, laughter, and moments of pure fun, and this game does all that and more in spades. For those looking for a delightful time with friends, look no further. You've found the perfect game!

[READ] - Unbiased and FACTS worth of a review + Important pros and cons 

At first glance after reading the comments and seeing the spam of negative reviews I was hesitant at first However...




Do not let the negative comments fool you however I will mention some pros and cons with the game.

The game is very fun with friends as well some interesting maps and is overly quite fun and enjoyable. Considering this is the developers first game at making something they have done well to be honest as well as do some mini updates here and there. 

Micro transactions - I am not sure why people are complaining as its completely optional. You can get all the rewards just by playing the game normally anyway. And tbh every game has micro transactions noways and I didn't pay $50 for it and its not a triple A game so do what you want with your money either spend it on the outfits or don't they don't force it in your face really. If anything its hidden to the sides of the screen tbh.

However the skins are a bit on the heavier side in terms of micro transactions if you don't want to grind normally as well as some other skins too. However i don't really see this as too much as a con as skins are not really needed and are cosmetic anyway people who are complaining can just NOT SPEND anything so I don't see the huge deal. There are a few that are high priced but then again ITS OPTIONAL so. again shouldn't be a huge problem however I do feel like they can be adjusted 

Servers - 
Considering the game came out literally 3 days ago I think that is has so far is great. However you may need a fast internet connection and depending on your location will depend on your latency which is not too bad unless you are from Australia right now they are not really using any servers that can be used by your region but they already stated that they are keeping limits on the game ATM. Accessible to XBOX and PC because they are a recently new dev company and its their first game so they want to get it right.

Can I play with friends? - 
Yes you can play private matches with friends. However when you click quick play it just shoves you into a random game however I do wish there was a mode to pick which ones (via quick play) you can with custom servers and find the game mode you want there but in quick play you cannot.


Can you play in private servers alone? without going into public lobbies -
 Yes you can you just launch a custom game and off you go. Invite some friends or add some AI. You do get a bit less XP for playing with ALL AI but that goes with all games tbh.

Is this game actually fun? -
Depending on your idea of fun. If you like playing with friends and knocking them out and tossing them all over the place while landing a bomb next to another freind and send them flying off bridges then yeah its a good laugh yeah.

However I suggest YOU the CONSUMER take it upon yourself to play the game and give a review yourself at first I thought I wouldn't enjoy it but with due respect most are being karens and making a big deal because other people are doing it and just following the negative review chain. 

Take it apon yourself to play the game however from personal experience me and my friends love it and makes a good random party game.

Hope this review cleared some air. Feel free to upvote dislike it whatever you feel. This is just here for other people to see.


So overall its a new game, It has its flaws atm but that's expected as its recently released not to long ago. In terms of the server issues with "Australia" and I hope they add more features in terms of accessibility to pick what modes to use in quick play.

TLDR: 
Pros

- Good game with friends
- Rag doll physics are just hilarious
- Interesting maps and hopefully they add new ones
- Play it for yourself and give it a shot (if your willing to spend ¬£15 - $20 ish dollers? i think)
- Headbutted people off the arcade machines and out a window 10/10 and makes for some funny moments.

Cons
- Australia currently get it the worst for servers atm
- You may need a solid internet connection to have the best experience and pray you are closest to your server 
- Defiantly room for more improvements but I think their main focus will be seeing how this game plays out before they expand further (they already mentioned that on the forms)

Game has a lot of good things but also some bad things. 

First of, I will start saying that the game itself is extremely good and very polished. You can feel the developers drive to make this game entertaining, fun, customizable and full of replayability. They managed to do well in all of these categories for me which makes the game extremely good for me.

The bad things now... 

It's local play is limited, and there is no Offiline mode. You can only play with one friend in one PC/Console and it HAS to be in a custom game for some reason. The Splitscreen is also weird placed on PC which are just two small blocks. They could've easily made it at least 4 players per PC by the size of the screen.

You are limited to certain server regions (for now) and that can be a deal breaker because of lag. If they plan to add more servers in the future, I can easily say that I might commit more hours into this game.

It's disheartening to witness this game receiving mixed reviews, but I believe there's more to it than meets the eye. Despite initial confusion regarding the offline mode and the in-game shop, I've found myself thoroughly enjoying this title. The game boasts a charming roster characters that adds to its appeal.

Now, let's address the issue of expensive skins. While the pricing model could use some adjustment, the good news is that purchasing them is entirely optional. I do encourage providing feedback on the pricing structure, as it's an important aspect of the game's future. Personally, I'm holding off on acquiring skins at their current prices, but it hasn't left me feeling frustrated. I'm hopeful that the developers might introduce skin sales or include them in a capsule machine rotation down the line. Additionally, it's worth noting that the game offers a leveling system that rewards you with Cookies and Nemo Bucks (the premium currency) as you progress.

My primary concern, however, revolves around the voice chat feature. Frankly, I wish it didn't exist. While it can be disabled, I've encountered instances of harassment, particularly as a woman player. Unfortunately, the system for reporting voice chat harassment is somewhat lacking, with the only option being to send logs through text chat. Given that the game is accessible to children as well, this aspect makes me uncomfortable. I hope they address this otherwise I'll just keep disabling it. 

Setting aside these concerns, I've personally waited a long time for its release, and I'm pleased to say that I haven't experienced any server issues so far. and I've been enjoying the 3rd day of this game. I have at least 16 hours so far. Yes I have a problem. My game play experience has been remarkably smooth and I have not witnessed any server issues at all.

i seriously don't understand all the hate for this game.

as a person with already 15 hours on the game despite it being released 3 days ago, i'll give you the honest truth. but first i'll inform you of the stuff you need to be aware of.

1. cookies and nemo bucks
nemo bucks are considered the "premium currency", you get 200 nemo bucks every two levels in the "battle pass". cookies are a much more common thing to get. if i remember correctly, you get 1500 cookies every other level. so essentially it goes like this:

1500 cookies
reward
1500 cookies
200 nemo bucks
and so on.

however, at least for me, it takes a little while to level up. although that really depends how good you are at the game.

2. "battle pass" (i forgot the name of it)
the "battle pass" (as of now) is completely free and accessible to everyone. in the battlepass, you can earn avatars, outfits, characters and more. the more common things you'll be getting are egg coins, cookies, and nemo bucks. as i've stated before it can be a little while to level up often, unless you're an absolute monster at the game.

3. egg coins
so, theres essentially a gacha system in the game. 1 roll costs 120 nemo bucks, and 10 rolls costs 1200 nemo bucks. it's incredibly rare to get a legendary, as i've only got one in all 15 hours of my gameplay as of writing this.
IT'S ONLY A GAMBLING SYSTEM IF YOU LET IT BE

4. misunderstanding about offline gameplay.
this was already addressed by the developers, but in case you don't know what happened, i'll explain briefly here.
so, in the games description it says something along the lines of "offline and online gameplay". people from my understanding thought that would mean single player?? which really doesn't make sense. or for whatever reason thought that you wouldn't need internet to play the game? i really don't know. but, there is TECHNICALLY a "single player" mode. there are things called custom matches, in these custom matches, you can make one yourself and add as many AI you want in the lobby. there are different difficulties you can edit for each bot. in these custom matches you can also choose the gamemode, map, how much health/stamina you have, etc. people also have public matches making it so you can play with friends with your own rules.

5. matchmaking, gamemodes, and maps.
i never had an issue with matchmaking. it's quick, simple, and easy. all you do is: press quick match, press the green button below "+ invite friends". and then you are all ready matchmaking. after that, you will get put into a lobby where the lobby will then vote on a map. each map has a different game mode. for example, there's beast soccer, and ice breaker. ice breaker is a 2v2v2v2. while beast soccer is 4v4, making it 8 people per lobby. i will state what maps i remember are 2v2v2v2 and 4v4 below.

**2v2v2v2 maps**
ice breaker
broken arrow
wind map (i forgot the name)
winter is coming
(and some poison cloud map i forgot the name of)

**4v4 maps**
beast soccer
beast football
beast hockey
buzz ball
lollipop factory
stay afloat


i've given all the information i could remember. if i miss anything i needed to address, i apologize.
================================================================================================
common issues people have with the game

1. microtransactions.
people complain about the "premium currency" (nemo bucks) being too pricey, even being more expensive than the game. while this is true, you (at least for now) can get the "premium currency" for completely free. the "battle pass", if you will, is ENTIRELY free and therefore you get the nemo bucks for free. i will let you know though it takes a little bit of time and saving.

2. gacha system
i personally don't see the problem with this. yes, it is a gambling system as is every gacha system, and yes, it is rare to get something you like. although, it's up to your decision whether to do it or not. gacha system from what ive seen also can be waited to be purchased from the store or even sometimes purchased from the character itself with ingame currency (cookies). the ingame currency being cookies. for reference in the item shop, the "epic" characters in the item shop are 3000 nemo bucks if i remember correctly. while the gacha rolling is 120 nemo bucks for one roll, and 1200 for 10 rolls. although one small complaint i have is that you get only half of the amount of the outfit (it's also transferred into cookies, so you wont be getting nemo bucks from duplicates :C) when you get a duplicate, but that's just me being greedy.

3. matchmaking
i saw someone complaining how you get in a lobby with complete strangers. and i don't really understand because that's like complaining how fortnite is online. and plus, it's not necessary to play with strangers. i've mentioned custom matches and AI before. although you will not get XP from custom matches i think.

4. monetization system
i will admit, the monetization is absolutely terrible. and i don't know for sure, but from what i've heard you can get temporarily banned for it. but also, keep in mind. this was made in shanghai. making english not their first language. so i understand why there are issues with monetization. there is also voice chat that from what i believe, is not monetized. you might get in trouble if you get reported for saying something derogatory. so, yeah. monetization is terrible and is really the only issue i have with the game.

5. advertising
i see where people are coming from with this. although, again like most of the issues. it isn't in your face until you click the item shop, or MAYBE your locker on some occasions. but, it's like how fortnite advertises. and nobody had a problem with fortnites advertisements, so i don't see why people are having issues with this games advertising. they have been already sponsored by star wars i believe, so that could be what they're talking about. i don't really understand what some of them are talking about, so i'm just running on what i think they are saying.

6. friending system
this.. is actually pathetic the amount of work the players don't want to do. all you need to do is click on your profile, click on your ID code, it automatically copies it to your clipboard, and paste it in some sort of chat you and your friends have. i hate to be harsh, but the negative reviews are mainly people being lazy and expecting the game to make it easy for them. friending isn't hard, also, so when you see people complaining about that, just keep in mind they have no idea what they're talking about.

i'm noticing this repeated theme of "they make you work for currencies and characters". and, if you have at least one wrinkle in your brain, you will understand WHY this exists. it's so people can stay invested. i saw someone say that they "expect" you to buy currency. this.. is entirely false. they do not EXPECT you to buy anything. you could work for it and get the currencies for **completely free.** it just takes a lot of work, which these people clearly don't like doing.

the two biggest complaints i'm seeing are the microtransactions and the offline mode, so i'll briefly sum that up here.

microtransactions, despite what everyone tells you, do not and will never (as of now) require you to spend IRL money on the game. the "battle pass" is entirely free (AS OF WRITING THIS) where you get said currencies from the "battle pass"

offline mode was a misunderstood concept. i understand why people thought local matches would exist although even then you can easily friend them with a simple 2 clicks and a paste. i can't talk about split screen because i am on PC, so i'll leave that to the console players to talk about. i've heard that it's only a two person split screen, though.

sorry if this review missed anything or had any issues. this was wrote at 1:00 AM so i am a bit tired and might miss things. i won't be fixing it if you do point out issues, so keep that in mind. anyways, have a good day/night.

[b]Party Animal takes inspiration from Gang Beasts but sets itself apart with an endearing lineup of adorable animals. The game merges solid mechanics and physics with a distinctive cute aesthetic.[/b]

[b]- Character Variety:[/b] The game boasts a variety of animal types, each with its unique and fun skins. (Seriously, check out the images and names!) The attention to detail is evident: not only are the visuals cute, but they are also well-executed. You can almost feel the fluffiness of the animal fur!

[b]- Game Modes:[/b] Dive into 3 distinct modes: "Last Stand," "Team Score," and "Arcade." These modes together span a whopping 20 maps, a lot of it with different mechanics. And contrary to some reviews, there's flexibility in starting a game; you can create or join a Custom Game Room with or without a password, without needing a full team of 8 players.

[b]- Monetization:[/b] Some negative reviews are due to monetization, but it's important to note that in-game purchases are solely for skins and do not affect gameplay at all. I fail to see any problem with this in this specific game, specially because they need to maintain a server and release updates.

[b]- Pricing:[/b] A minor setback for some might be the game's regional pricing. While there's some differentiation between regions, it could be more substantial. For those on a budget, the Game Pass option might be a much more appealing option.

[b]In conclusion, Party Animal is a delightful blend of fun mechanics, charming graphics, and varied gameplay. The minor issues with regional pricing and misunderstood monetization shouldn't deter potential players from diving into this furry pandemonium! [/b]

The game is fun, really fun. The fact that there is a skin that costs more than the game itself is just goofy. There is a gacha machine for skins that can be paid for with in game currency and real world money. It dampens the fun a little bit but is also easy to ignore. The game is pretty generous with the standard and premium currency in the free battle pass that serves as it's means of progression (there is no paid battle pass). When you start out you have a bunch of animals to pick from and the rest I have gotten from the battle pass and gacha pulls, multiple of which were rare. At this point I have almost every animal after one day of play. I've played games with similar monetization schemes that feel less than fair but I've gotten the opposite vibe from this game. Kinda feels like the publisher demanded it and the devs did it as fairly as they could.  Would still be nice to have a way to hide real world monetization somewhere in settings for all the kids that will inevitably play considering it is a paid game to begin with.

Requiring an internet connection is this games biggest fault. There is a local / AI mode but you still need to be connected to play. I imagine that this is an anti-piracy measure but really only proves to be anti-consumer. I don't have to worry about my connection much and only play online anyway, but it's still a huge caveat that can hopefully be addressed.

The game itself is very Gang Beasts-esque. There are a solid number of maps, some objective based, some last man standing. Random melee/ranged weapons spawn in and give matches a smash bro's vibe. Controls are simple and silly but not frustrating, you can definitely get gud, I can not.

Graphically, I think it's gorgeous. Solid blend of art style and fidelity without overdoing it. The physics shine in both interacting with the environment / items and combat. Running a 3080 / Ryzen 3900x I was at a mostly locked 144 at 1440p with everything cranked and DLSS off. It scales really well if your running older hardware / steam deck as well. It isn't hard to get a locked 60 while still turning up a few settings that matter to you, so long as FSR is on of course.

There's cute avatar's / frames / emotes and skins to collect in the battlepass and through getting in game achievements as well. It feels like your unlocking stuff every game.

Based off of the current state of the game industry I can definitely see the monetization getting worse, per the suits upstairs, but as of right now it doesn't feel AS egregious as it could thanks to the level of polish it currently has. Go beat up animals with a shovel.
