I rate this 7/10 to 8/10 because it's that kind of game you get to play with friends or get a kick at the fact that you play as a cute animal and watch said animal beat the living crap out of other animals, it's not serious.

Adorable creatures slugging it out in a bar room brawl! 

The movement and combat mechanics, while intentionally clunky by design, will take a solid minute to learn. However, once you learn how to combine the two effectively, it's both satisfying and entertaining when you land hits on your opponents...or when you accidentally hit one or all of your teammate(s). There is a decent list of animals to choose from, mini-games, and weapons to pick up and use. 

Whether you play in a party or jump in on your own, this game is a hilariously good time.

I know people have issues with the micro transactions (monetisation)/offline mode, and while I do think that there's a self apparent problem to the ethics of monetising a game like this, which is clearly going to be played by children, if we can set that aside (and assume that parents will do the right thing), then the game itself is excellent, very fun, very cute, very high replay-value. 
Also, you can unlock pretty much everything just by playing the game regularly over a large enough period of time.

dum fun

This game has been really fun and a joy to play so far! The different gamemodes provide fun alterations to the gameplay that are a blast to play with both friends and alone with randoms. The cast of different animals in this game provide plenty of funny scenarios and help to create the cute aesthetic that the game is trying to present. I will say that sometimes the gameplay can be a bit clunky, such as not being able to grab certain objects. However, this is only about 10-20% of the time while playing.

The people who are complaining about the falsely advertised are justified in being upset with the developers. HOWEVER: the review bombing on steam has been blow quite out of proportion. I understand that there being no offline mode may be frustrating to some people, but this is a digital only game, so you need an internet connection to buy it anyway, and I don't think it's too crazy for devs to assume that most people who would be buying this game have internet. The only time this would be an issue is if you want to play the game while travelling or during a power outage, In which case I can understand the disappointment. But it's not like you can't play the game with just friends or family, there is a custom game option which allows you to play the extent of the game, so couch co-op is still a viable option.

The other thing i've seen in reviews is discussion about the "aggressive monetization" this game presents. Everything is this game is purely cosmetic, meaning you aren't at a disadvantage if you don't have every new cosmetic item in the shop. I will say that the legendary skins being around $20 is absurd, but the game provides you with plenty of currency from the levelling rewards, so you would never need to pay real money for a few skins you want, you'd simply just have to play the game. Also, the game gives you a starting roster of about 12 animals, meaning you have a wide range of characters to choose from to keep yourself entertained. You can completely disregard the shop entirely if you so choose, and there aren't constant ads or notifications trying to shove skins down your throat. If you do want to get some costumes for your fuzzy friends, either buy them with in-game currency or complete different challenges to get skins and rewards. As someone who often doesn't shill out money to buy in-game cosmetics, I am completely satisfied with the system for unlockables they have in this game.

Overall, this game is incredibly fun and addicting, and I'm having a blast playing it with friends. Don't let the review bombs hurt your opinion of this game. If you loves games like Gang Beasts or Stick Fight, then definitely play this game.

In conclusion, did I make this review to poke fun at the salty people complaining about the cosmetic system? Yes I did. Thanks for reading.

Great game solo, amazing game with friends. I like that I can enjoy the game on my own in the quick match screen or have a fun night with friends in custom lobbies. The monetization isn't as bad as some people make it out to be, but I will admit that I am a little salty over getting duplicate surprise eggs and the duplicates being converted to the doggy snacks/bones instead of the egg currency. The goofy physics of the game add to the hilarity and the cute little critter costumes are adorable. Most of the maps are enjoyable, but there are a couple of the maps that make me want to pull my hair out because the game play feels so slow; Beast Soccer being the main map I dread playing because the field feels way too large. There's been more than a couple of instances where nobody managed to score a goal on Beast Soccer and it resulted in a draw. Aside from that, all in all a good game.  It's a game worthy of going on the "party game" list. 

I hope they give us the option to change the color of the background at some point because the orange idle screens are blech. 

animals I would like to see in the game at some point : red panda, axolotl, fox or kitsune, peacock, African wild dog/painted dog.

*** You can only get in-game Cookie currency via achievements, leveling up, or getting duplicate eggs that can only be earned via leveling, achievements, or converting real money to another in-game currency and then rolling a duplicate surprise egg. I feel like I've hit a wall with earning currency and if I want to get new outfits I'll have to spend real money to play the conversion game which seems like a huge negative. There needs to be a way to earn currency just for participating in matches. If they ever make changes to how you can earn in-game currency then I'll go back to making it a recommendation, but as it is now I cannot recommend this to people.

This game is what it says on the box. It's polished, very well-developed mechanics, whimsical, cute, and great gameplay loop. Some of the negative reviews are STRANGE AF, and I'd like to go over some.

For starters, people complaining about the game having a cash-store are clearly omitting (or simply not realising) that the cash-store currency can be earned via the FREE BATTLE PASS. And they're all just cosmetic items.

Then some people are complaining that this PARTY game isn't single-player?? HELLO???

The only real valid criticisms of this game I can see are that local co-op isn't really that well-done. I can't imagine this will affect most of the player-base, but it is a slight over-sight. Local co-op is functional, it's just weird.

Overall, this game is pretty great. They're already doing some IP collaborations with ORI, and some individual content creators. It's cute, it's fun, it's easy to progress, the Battle Pass is free, and they do seem to have a great road-map.

This game is a lot of fun, which IMO is it's main selling point. I've been waiting so long for a fun dumb knock around party game with friends. I was half tempted to buy Rumble Party or even Gang Beasts again (I have it on PS), but saw this game advertised a year ago and was waiting ever since. All the reviews complaining about a "predatory" store and battle pass, are way over exaggerating. 
The game never shoves it in your face, or has a paid for battle pass alongside the free one, there's just one "battle pass" everyone gets and you unlock currency/skins/characters by playing the game. You can also do the same by completing challenges like: "Win *insert game mode* 5 times" or "Get 5 knockouts in a game" etc. So unless you're really upset that you didn't get a vampire skin for the cat or something while it was a limited time, you'll honestly live. There's way more predatory games out there, and this barely counts. 
IMO $20 is a steal, and this game deserves support, here's hoping it isn't just the next Fall Guys or something because this game is guaranteed fun.

After playing this game for a few more hours and finding randoms to party up with along with other friends I must say this game is actually really fun and will retract my "negative review" towards this game while clearly listing the positives and negatives:

Pros:
- Slick UI, graphics, skins, music
- Funny combat situations due to the way characters act so wonky and clunky
- Very cool map designs, so far I cannot say I disliked any maps
- Amazing party game to have a few laughs and just vent off from serious crap
- Overall very polished gameplay besides the grab mechanic which imo sometimes feels a bit more clunky than it should especially when climbing or having to grab weapons in certain angles

Cons:
- Griefers and AFK/Ragequitters in basically every other lobby if you are playing solo as of the time of this review 
- Lack of FFA/Solo game modes. Some of us cant have a party to play with at all times and as it has been proven multiple times not necessarily playing with randoms as your teammates can be the most pleasant experience especially when you are going against "premades" who are trying their best to achieve victory.
- Certain weapons feels overtuned such as the nunchucks and baseball bat, they are extremely precise AND spammable with their attacks
- Lacks more maps and more game modes (such as FFA/Solo, something like capture the flag, push the payload, etc)

Idk what everyone is crying about...I'm 22 hours in -- I've had zero crashes, zero bugs, super fast queue times, minimal lag :D I've played local multiplayer with my brother against bots (fun). I've quick-played against other people (also fun). Bottom line -- it's fun! It's like Gangbeasts x2 with the UI of Fall Guys, and it's very well-polished. 

The Egg Drops? Cmon...you get the currency for FREE through the battle-pass-esque leveling system. I've gotten like 10+ drops already JUST from playing the game (not spending any extra money)! Do I have EVERY skin n animal in the game? No. But what would be the point of playing if you already had everything?

ALSO, LET'S NOT FORGET THE GAME IS $20, NOT $60! I HOPE they add things like a real battle pass. I want to see new animals, new skins, and fun events to keep this game alive. I'd pay $5 or $10 every now again for more content, and continued love from the devs.

ONLY CON:

I don't typically write reviews for games, but I feel like this one had a pretty harsh case of review bombing,so I'd like to do my part.

Early reviews really harped on two specific issues which have both been addressed by the devs. I won't bother explaining them - you can easily find them if you'd like. Suffice to say that there was an overreaction, and there have been some bad-faith assumptions made about some of the fixes that were made.

The current main issue I see people addressing is microtransactions. I agree that generally speaking, MTs are bad for the industry, but this game's pay model is no worse than the industry standard.

Gameplay as a whole feels great. The physics is a good combination of goofy and responsive. This is not a game to play competitively - it is a game for shenanigans, so don't expect tight and responsive controls. There is a good variety of game types, none of which seem particularly prone to griefing or cheese tactics. The maps remind me of playing Crash Bash (criminally underrated party game btw) as a kid. Character design is cute and fun, with good costumes / skins. Voice chat is a good addition, even if there are some rather annoying people on mic.

Definately worth the purchase, and would be even more so during a sale. The devs seem keen to support the game for some time in the future, which is always a plus. Eager to see what kind of content comes post-launch.

Insanely fun coop game. If you're looking for an amazing party game this is one you'll be returning to constantly. Big bonus points because this game supports couch coop, which is a rare thing nowadays. And you can always also play with friends online - and if you're looking to diversify the team layouts among your friends then select the custom game category instead of quick play. This will also let you dictate the map pool, and you can still get strangers from the internet to fill your lobby as usual.

[h1] Please Read before you buy [/h1]

There's a lot to like, but let's be real and address all the negatives first and foremost:

1) The game is always played with 8 people. So if you've only got three friends who own the game, prepare to be matched with 8 random internet strangers, some of whom are probably 5 years old, all of whom are pretty awful. "Well, that's not so bad, as long as my friends and I are on a team," I hear you say. *ahem*
2) Whether your game is a free for all, four teams of two, or two teams of four is entirely dependent on the arena selected and, I'll remind you, random internet strangers will be the ones controlling at least a considerable slice of this vote. 
3) You could work around issues 1 and 2 if the game would take a leaf from Rocket League's playbook and allow you and your group of friends to select the sort of match you'd like to play before queuing up. Seriously, why can't me and 3 friends select "4v4 matchmaking" and then be presented ONLY with arenas that are compatible with that? AT THIS STAGE, I'M NOT ASKING FOR NEW ARENAS OR GAMEPLAY MECHANICS -- just a filter!
4) Some new game modes would be helpful, but even they don't require all new arenas to be made. Ice Hockey, Soccer, etc could still be fun even in a 2v2 setting. But no, you *have* to be online in this PARTY game with "PARTY" literally written in the name. And the "why" you have to be online might be the biggest downside of this game by far:
5) This is a game that you purchase (for $20 USD, no less) that then expects you to shell out money indefinitely for costumes and characters. I want you to pay attention to the quotation marks I'm about to use here, because they mean a lot tonally: You can "earn" opportunities to "win" a "chance" at a character or costume that you want, but those require you to win matches and earn experience points. Not only does the experience required to go from level to level increase drastically (meaning that you might need to win 10 matches to "earn" your first "chance" at a character or costume, but you'll have to win 30 to "earn" your next), but their tied to your "animal level" which has a limit.

So even if you were MADE of free time and just really LOVED the game, you will eventually run out of opportunities to 'win' the character or costume you want and there are already far more characters and costumes than there will be ever be opportunities you can "earn" as opposed to "buy."

Does any of this sound familiar to you? Well, it should if you're familiar with the rise and fall (heheh) of "Fall Guys" which started as a pay-to-play game, people were irritated at the level of money the game was expecting you to pump into it for cosmetics and so started requesting refunds. Steam put pressure on the publisher to change their pricing, and they said, "well if you want us to go free to play, we'll sign on with Epic since they'll pay us for exclusivity on PC" and even with their sizable check from Epic and all the whales spending real life money to buy cosmetics, the devs still abandoned any efforts to stop hackers/cheaters from ruining the game for everyone leading in a rapid decrease in the game's popularity.

[hr][/hr]

So with that all said, let's address the good: Do you like gang beasts? Well this is that but with cute animals. [strike]And a horrific monetization system, awful match-making, no offline mode, no Steam Friend-list Integration so you have to do this weird and completely arbitrary lobby code thing because they couldn't figure out how games like Rocket League have both cross platform and friend-list support so they built their own rudimentary system instead.[/strike]

If that's enough for you to enjoy yourself, then by all means have fun. But you might be better waiting for this game to become free to play, which I can pretty well guarantee will happen sooner than later.

After +3 years of waiting, I give the game 6/10

The game have wobbly mechanic that was cute and funny at first, but feels more like clunky controls 

The developer put a lot of their time and energy into making a lot of cute animals to choose from, they all share the same move set, so they're just a bunch of skins to choose from

The game mode is either last team standing, score points, or some objective you have to do. Some maps can be short or drawn out long depending on how the random teammates participate. Most of the games I've played there's been afk because they don't want the penalty of leaving a game mode and being in timeout

So that's 10% of the game, the other 90% of the game feels like playing a mobile phone app with the gacha slot machine to win a random skin and grinding to level up to unlock in game currency to unlock certain animals or skins. I don't see a lot of replay value after 2 hours of playing the game, so I refunded the game and got my money back.

I'm pretty sure this game will become F2P soon with how it's currently made and the other games I've played that have micro-transaction are TF2 and Hearthstone, but they're FREE to PLAY

But the skin system is... weird.
You start with 10 animals  and for skins there is too much mecanics:

Like, you have a "Battle Pass" (Only free rewards, no premium stuff) and you can get game currency (bones) and skins from it

With bones, you can buy skins in the shop (Shop have random skins and is update every day and week) but also with 
bill (The thing you can buy with real money and get some from Battle Pass)

In the pass, you can unlock coins to open a loot box to get a random skin. You can also buy loot boxe with real money. All the skin the loot box gives you can also be bought with bones / bills if the skin is in the shop

Most of the common skins are worst than their free version. (Just a color variant from the default)

You can also unlock special skins with Steam Achievements and (I think) you can only unlock those with achievements
_____________________________________________________________________
To conclude, this game is very good and haves other game mode than "Punch animals in the head"
I don't regret my money and will continue to play. But, the absence of server in Africa/Australia, the skin system that is... not bad but far from good... make it hard to grade.

If you just want some fun, this game is awesome and worth the price
If you want skins, then... it isn't the best game for this. I would have said otherwise if you could get free bones from matches and if you could buy everything with bones. Paywalls in a paid game is a big no

Everyone's up in arms about a translation error from a company who's first language isn't English.... This game has already brought so many laughs and enjoyment playing it. It's like Gang Beasts but way better with more content and insanely cute characters. Couldn't recommend it enough. Runs smoothly (even with friends in other continents). For everyone crying about microtransactions as well, the battle pass is free which gives you FREE currency that you'd normally have to buy. If these people played the game they'd realize it's an easy level up away from free cosmetics (including the fancy ones).

The gameplay is fun, and most importantly, funny. It looks pretty good too.

However, I'm gonna have to give this a negative review for now.

Their store is predatory, with skins that cost more than the game itself, multiple currencies, real money lootboxes (that can be duplicates!), timed sales to abuse that fear of missing out, twitch drops, you know the deal.

Also, the censorship is insane. You can barely complete an English sentence without it being censored, making people think you're cussing, which in turn gets you reported, and then (temporarily) banned. Want to appeal that ban? Tough luck: you'll have to write a ticket on their website for that, but it won't even allow you to login.

These devs are clearly inexperienced, have no clue about the English language, and have spent most of the development time on making a predatory store.

Avoid for now, check back in a couple of months.

Highly recommend picking up this title for a cute physics based brawler with great polish. I had access to the playtest and found that the added gamemodes on release was refreshing. My hope is that they will continue to add more gamemodes, which I'm suspecting they will! The gameplay is very similar to Gang Beasts but I believe the added cosmetics to each animal will give everybody a way to customize their favorite critter. There's nothing like seeing a Darth Vader Duck get knocked out by a boomerang he threw, meanwhile a Wizard Crocodile is desperately swimming towards safety, all while you have a Pink Shark with a t-shirt on it's head camping the edge. 

While the gameplay supports solo queue, it is far superior to play with a group online (up to 4 players per lobby), with there being support for far more players in a custom lobby. 

However, while I do recommend picking this game up for a fun time I'm a bit saddened to see some micro-transactions pop up in the store for some characters. It's not as egregious as other games, as most cosmetics are available through leveling up your account (and spending the two different currencies available). My hope is that most of that content will be unlocked for free in the future.

Some of the weapons are incredibly overpowered compared to the rest. I'm looking at YOU (shovel), but the balancing of different weapons is something they can fix in the future. Regardless, the mixture of long ranged, to wide swinging, and just downright hilarious weapons make for a fun and (sometimes) aggravating experience. 

Oh, and voice chat makes it 10x funnier.

[h1] To clarify some things [/h1]

In case some of these details are the ones making you doubt about buying the game

[b] Battle Pass? [/b]
No, it's the level up system. There's no "premium" battle pass nor you can buy "tiers" (aka player levels)

[b] Money for skins? [/b]
For the most premium ones, and the level up system gives you """some""" (still little). Cause the free currency/leveling up is enough to unlock 99% of the animals. If you care about the prettiest skins, yeah, money. But if you just want to have a blast with fun gameplay, no need to bring your wallet, and many of the Epic free currency skins are still very good

[b] No Offline Mode? [/b]
True, it sucks, so if that is your main point to get the game, it doesn't have it. But it still allows for local couch players to join your party and jump into the game together

[b] Repetitive gameplay? [/b]
No. Looking from outside, 3 MAIN Gamemodes may sound like too little variety, but every map (20 in total) of every mode brings something different to the table, so whenever you DO get into a map you've played before, you'll probably want to try a different strategy from last time.

[b] Personal opinion? [/b]
The game is amazing, simple as that. Sucks that there's no offline mode, but that doesn't really take away from how fun it is to play. It has monetization but is way too far from being the worst in recent times, only skin related. The game has a wide variety of maps that keep gameplay fresh as you try to learn the core gameplay of your character and the maps.


[b] One piece of advice? [/b]

[h3] CHECK YOUR TEAM COLOR BEFORE YOU ACCIDENTALLY SMACK YOUR COMPANION [/h3]

It's a legit fun game. Excellent with a group of friends especially. There's gonna definitely be a drinking game associated with this somehow! The animals are adorable, the rounds are pretty quick and always entertaining. 

When a round ends there's like a 15 second brawl before a snapshot is taken. It's gotten some of the loudest laughs from friends. Whoever put that in deserves a raise.

The Mtx concerns shouldn't put you off this game. It's for hats. Nothing else. You get a good amount of the premium currency by just playing and beating some weekly quests and or leveling. It's the same kind of skin system as Fall Guys essentially. I'd give more merit to the concerns if there was some pay to win aspect here, but there's not. It's hats. Who really gets that upset at hats.

It's the kinda game that's meant to be played online, so the offline complaints don't even register, and once in game I guarantee you don't even think of the 'issue'.

Incredibly delightful party game. Lots of options for mini games aside from the main brawl rounds, and definitely room for expansion in the future. Plus, the characters are stinking CUTE!

For those looking to compare it to Gang Beasts: I believe as a general rule that Party Animals is better for having an even skillset for everyone, with a risk for action spam from enemies (such as an opponent spamming the punch button over your head when you get knocked out - it's on occasion I'll struggle to get up because I'm not given the opportunity to fight back). In my experience, Gang Beasts is harder for new players to pick up. So Party Animals definitely seems more intuitive and easier for new or inexperienced players.
I do personally think Gang Beasts is still unmatched in the absolute chaos and screw-offery-ness that people know and love it for - but that isn't to say Party Animals doesn't have it's own charm and chaos, even if the chaos does seem a little more controlled. Beyond game mechanics, I would chalk this up to the environment in Gang Beasts being much more likely to fall apart around the players - I would not cite this as a 'pro' or 'con' over Party Animals. The games are similar but also very different so it's hard to compare on every front!
I do like the group activities better in Party Animals if you're looking for better group/team based rounds. 

Overall though, I'd say Party Animals is a great addition to your game library if you're looking for fun party based games. If you like silly physics in your games, I'd say Party Animals definitely holds its own, and neither replaces Gang Beasts, nor is it outshined by Gang Beasts. 

Plus again: CHUBBY LIL ANIMALS <3

This game is so incredibly fun. I have such an amazing time with it that I even bought a Deluxe copy for PC, despite having it on Xbox Game Pass so I can play it in 120fps, or on my Deck and use the Twitch drops.

I even activated Nvidia Shadow Play just for this game so I can record incredible looking physical moments to create HQ gifs out of them. I had so many unbelievable looking kicks and punches and falls already, it's literally "porn" for every fan of game physics. It's so fantastic. 
Some of the level ideas like the magnetic reactor, winter is coming, the bar level where you have to throw out people through the windows or doors or things like the football game work all so well with these physics, it's such a blast to see and play. Really impressed by the polishing of the graphical or physical aspects here.

I also see a lot of people with issues on the monetization and although some of the prices are just plain stupid. overall its not a big issue since the the nemo bucks, which is the ingame money that is monetized, is quite easy to gain from just leveling up. If you have functional internet on PC the negative reviews do not impact you in any way although the game description was very unclear and misleading for those who wanted to play without internet.

One thing that would make this better would be to introduce a solos mode. It is a party game but when you que with 3 friends, you are placed with a random person instead of it filtering out duos mode to play the team modes etc. Solos is available in customs so theres no much reason to add a FFA mode into quick match.

Ignore most of the negative reviews. Although peoples complaints about not having offline play are valid. The actual game is extremely fun and goofy.  The rag dolls physics and strange levels and objectives just create fun scenario's that you will be constantly laughing about. The micro-transactions? Better then most games currently out there. All cosmetic, and at least the denominations of currency they sell don't fall short of the asking price in the shop. Also there are tons of things to be unlock simply by playing the game. I've spent the base 20$ on the game and have not somehow felt FOMO or disadvantaged by the shop.

So far Im 2.4 hours in at the time of this review its basically gang beasts with a cutesy look. I find this game absolutely hysterical with friends by yourself its definitely a bit less fun as your reliant on *gasp* randoms. However if you're in it for the trolling, the nonsensical banter, the giggle fits and a whole lot of other silly moments this game is definitely worth the price in my opinion (that being said i would avoid the deluxe edition unless you're just fiending for cosmetics. The characters are fun i suppose but i didn't really see the allure for the extra 10 bucks for a gang beasts lookalike)

[h2] pros [/h2]
-Voip
-Good variety of maps 
-Loads of character models to choose from
-Game requires a bit of skill to play, however learning curve isn't bad.
-Simple control scheme works on both KB&M and gamepads
- easy to group up with steam friends, or even make new friends from games you've played.
-Haven't experienced any bugs or glitchiness.
---------------------------------
[h2] cons [/h2]
-A few of my games where super laggy and matched with people far from server causing high peer to peer Latency.
-Sometimes grabbing / throwing can feel clunky.
-Some of the weapons are very imbalanced, i.e. lolipop and shovel. Players being able to sit on your already KO'd body and swing over and over and you just get deleted is not fun.
-Report system is only available after pictures have been taken and if player leaves before then you can't report. (This should be changed and be able to report players mid game)
-No AFK detection mid game
-KO timer is not equal - This should likely be normalized.
-No indication of about to be KO'd.

I'm a 60 years and 9 months old father. My son and I have grown distant ever since his mom - My dear wife - has passed away. We weren't talking much and he got used to staying in his room and playing video games all day long. I had heard that he was very interested in this game and so I have bought it for myself. I asked him for help on how to play and soon after we were playing matches together. Although I wasn't very good at the game, and we didn't win much, we still had a very great time. Soon after, my son and I were talking more with each other and he finally snapped out of his depression and was ready to go outside of his room more. This fun but silly game has brought me and my son together once again! Thank you party animals!

Been waiting for this game to come out since it's revealed of 2020, and it did not disappoint :>
------
Pros:
-Super addictive sandbox physics gameplay, so many crazy scenarios
-Amazingly original, snappy, and most importantly responsive UI!
-Creative game modes along with many maps, each of them having unique spin of their own
-Graphics are Phenomenal, seeing the adorable creatures Fluff and all in HD as well
-Controls are quite responsive, but at the same time sloppy enough to add on the "Party" like unpredictable gameplay
-So, Soooo many cute playable characters to choose from and each one not only having different alts, but the alts even have their own different variations!
-If you crash or lag out of the game, it has a "Join in progress game" so you don't miss out with your friends in matchmaking or custom games
-Game has a custom game community browser with a TON of host options, including adding AI for some teams that seem uneven.
-Voice Chat is open(also by default) so you'll get a giggle out of the random context that players spew out lol
-Free Battle Pass that gives you tons of in-game currency as well as Nemo Bucks to buy within the shop
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
CONS:
-Apparently, the game cannot be played offline, which is always a big "No" in my book. No reason why this can't be played offline.
-Supposedly, Australia players are shit out of luck as the closet servers they can play on is within Asia, take this with a grain of salt as I couldn't find a way to confirm this since I don't reside there.
-I had 2 friends crash often here and there as we played, however they did mentioned they have been crashing with other games prior to this one recently. One of the PC crashes my friend received was an error in terms of C++ or w/e
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Controversy:
To be honest, I have always believed that battle passes and item shops can be done properly in games, the idea alone is actually good, but it really matters how it's executed. So far, no games have come close to this however(expect TF2).

I will say though I think that how monetization in this game is handled fairly well, because you can earn the currency within the game by just playing, and No.
-You don't have to grind for hours at all just for a tiny amount of Nemo Bucks or Dog Bones. As only 3-4 hours in, I was able to purchase about half or more of the skins within the store. You can simply play and earn everything in a reasonable time play I strongly believe and I think the option to pay with real money is solely there if you were just to be impatient honestly. I understand the game is $20 itself, however the game offers so much already to begin with, worthy of that $20.
Any extra content beyond that you can unlock with just earned in-game currency alone.

-From all the reviews or statements in regard of the monetization within the game, I personally believe it may be a lot of ignorance or people not fully understanding how the system actually works within the game. A lot of people only jumping the gun the moment that they would see you have the option to spend real-life money into the game, then automatically calling it bad and review bombing it.

I am heavily against monetization in game, however I'm always open minded if I feel it's done properly and I do believe this is one of them with some of my statements.

Shame about the whole "offline" thing which soured the game's launch. If you're out of the loop, a good chunk of the negative reviews are because the game said on its store page that you could play offline split screen with friends. What they apparently meant was (as they later clarified), you don't need to play with your friends over the internet because you can play local splitscreen ... but you still have to play that splitscreen online with randoms. That's a pretty bad choice of words because anyone I know would think you could play fully offline based on what they originally wrote.

Despite that whole fiasco, gave the game a shot and it's a great time. Recommend.

[h1]Uncompromising Physical Fun[/h1]

If you ever wished that Fall Guys would stop giving you obstacle course/race levels, and instead focused more on the wacky fun modes, you get more of what this game has to offer. The game has clearly had plenty of time in the oven as the physics work [i]wonderfully[/i] to provide hilariously wacky and believable scenarios without (so far) resulting in insane janky physics glitches. 

Doing this in a game that is:
[list]
[*]An online game with variable ping.
[*]Has a client-side slow-mo feature that makes it easy to notice when you've been KO'd without breaking the flow of the game for anyone. (love this <3)
[*]Has this many animals on screen, with this many joints, and the ability to punch, kick, headbutt, dodge-roll, drop kick, power punch, climb, and grab onto ANYthing.
[/list]
All make this game a real standout for me on a [i]technical[/i] [b]and[/b] [i]enjoyment[/i] level. 

A highly chaotic yet distilled party game that should go down in the books with the likes of Overcooked.

I played the playtest with my friend three years ago and immediately fell in love with the game. The easy controls, the stunning graphics, and most importantly the addicting gameplay. 

I personally give the game a 9.8 out of 10.

I have seen people dislike the game because they claimed it was going to be "Offline" and it isn't. 
It's couch co-op, but you need an internet connection to play.
For me, that doesn't bother me at all. My friends all play online together anyway, so only playing online is no a problem.
I think it's bad on the developers or at least the marketing team (If they have one) that they mislead people. They needed to be more clear.

Another thing, I have heard. Is that, there is a loot box system in the game
Now at this point, we all know what that means. 
But, I don't think that people realize the level-up system in the game. LITERALLY GIVES YOU FREE MONEY!!!!

So now looking at the loot box system, it isn't bad. 
Sure you can spend real money on the game currency. 
There is just no need.

Overall I give this game I have been waiting for 9 punches for every kick.
Honestly the micro transactions are easily avoidable I don't get why its a problem.

1998 called, they said they want their local co-op split screen back.  Oi.  Okay.  Nobody called wanting their split-screen back; I'm just venting and miffed.  And that was a terrible burn. I'm no stranger to games inspired by iconic predecessors, but "Party Animals" feels like an uninspired crasher at the party. Touted as the successor to "Gang Beasts", this game falls flatter than a deflated balloon animal.

To start with the audacity: slapping a $20 price tag on a game riddled with microtransactions is a bold move, but not one to be applauded. If I'm dishing out that much upfront, I expect an experience that feels complete, not an invitation to an endless cash grab.

And speaking of the basics, who releases a party game with no local co-op these days? Local multiplayer is the lifeblood of party games, and its omission here is akin to throwing a party without any music. Dealbreaker, indeed.

The cherry on top of this disappointment sundae is the online-only requirement. I mean, seriously? In an age where most games are offering flexibility, "Party Animals" chains its players to a perpetual online tether. Great for those moments when you want to play solo and your internet's down, right? Oh wait, you can't.

Comparing it to "Gang Beasts" might be doing a disservice to the latter. Where "Gang Beasts" gave us hours of laughter and memorable moments, "Party Animals" delivers an experience that feels more like the aftermath of a party‚Äîlittered, messy, and leaving you wondering why you came in the first place.

In short, save your money and time. This party's not worth attending.

This is a great game if you're looking for something very similar to Gang Beasts. It does require an online connection because this does have a progression/achievement system along with an aggressive micro-transaction cosmetics store. One nice feature about being online however is the Custom Lobby browser so you can create/find specific game modes. This game does seem to lean into a live-service type of game rather than a game you'd load up at a LAN party like Gang Beasts, you might consider just picking up Gang Beasts instead if that's what you're looking for but for people who wanted to play Gang Beasts online more regularly with a progression system, now there's Party Animals.

The game seems to run well and very well polished so I think it's worth the $20 price of admission. This is definitely going to be a game that will depend on a healthy player population.

Low hours on this are not representative of my actual time played, as I played more hours than I can possibly count back in the initial 2020 demo.

Everything about this game has been an incredible improvement since then: more adorable characters / costumes, some really creative and fun maps, and *shockingly* a very fair and fun unlocking / progression system for getting cosmetics and earning the shop currency.

Reminiscent of Gang Beasts combined with the wacky sports / team modes from Fall Guys. It's a great time all around.

Only real complaint (a minor one) is that there's a daily cap on how much XP you can earn from the custom lobbies. It makes sense though, since it'd be very easy to farm XP with them otherwise, but it's just a bit of a bummer when I know most of my time with this will be with a full friends-only custom lobby and less so in the public matchmaking (though I still have played in there and it's very fun).

Overall fantastic game, if you're looking for some mindless chaotic multiplayer fun that just goes on and on, I can't recommend a better game than this.

The game also does have cosmetics/in-game purchases which people don't like (even though it's optional lmao), but most of the skins are easily obtainable through the FREE currency in the game (cookies). 

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game even if you don't have a big group of friends to play with because playing with random people is still a lot of fun, especially with the voice chat. If you're into online multiplayer, this will work for you but if you're looking for a single player offline game you will be disappointed. You are able to play on the same device with someone next to you on split screen though, there's even AI in custom games so I'm not sure what the issue is with the negative reviews.

Cute and fun party games with animals in cute and fun costumes. i love the gatcha system and anyone complaining about getting dupes clearly hasn't played a proper gatcha game where you don't get different every time. Controls were easy to get used to and the levels are simple and competitive. 10/10 love this chaotic ass game so far. Can't wait to see what comes in potential updates for maps and hopeful seasonal events.

To start off, the mixed reviews have nothing to do with the gameplay. They're all concerns with offline play, and micro-transactions and lootboxes. Sure, I get the outrage.

Gameplay wise, this is the party brawler to get. The controls feel clean (admittedly a little cleaner during beta) and the action is frenetic and fun. My friends and I were playing Gang Beasts for a long time, but it was more under duress because nothing else was fitting the bill. My complaints with Gang Beasts were that the stamina bar was obfuscated, so I had no idea what state my guy was in, the controls felt unresponsive, so I was just button mashing and hoping for the best.

Both of those issues are addressed, though admittedly, the controls feel a tad more sluggish on Party Animals than it did previously. 

The levels are interesting and varied, with different objectives beyond just beating the hell out of each other. I will say that some of Gang Beasts levels are more interesting, such as the truck racing and the window washer levels.

My biggest gripe at the moment is the confusing way to add friends. We have a dedicated group of friend who all want to play together and adding a friend in the game menu just sends them a steam message with a link to the game. The only way to reliably add a friend (as of 9/20/2023) is to create a game, have them join the game, and then add them as a friend in the game lobby.

But other than that, it's been an enjoyable experience, and a welcome addition to the party brawler genre.

First off, the mention of an offline mode followed by a lacklustre "translation" excuse is a huge downside for those who were anticipating this game's release, however if you're like me and only found out about this recent controversy from the steam reviews than this is effectively a non-issue for you (That being said servers will eventually go offline, please add an offline mode at some point).

With that out of the way, Party Animals takes what gang beasts had, removes the jank and inconsistency, alongside painting everything over with an amazing art style and cute animals. The game play is far superior to that of gang beasts, with more content to boot, however the major issue the game does have, is an overly expensive in-game cosmetic store. Overall though this game is great, and I have been pushing all my buddys to pick it up!

Imagine Gang Beasts, but less fun and with incompetent developers.

So after playing for a few hours, I heard about the review bombing. And a good half of them are about the micro transactions which...seem plain dumb. One half of THOSE is people saying "Why are some skins more than the cost of the game!?" whilst the others are "This game is expensive, How dare they!" and to both parties I ask....Have you been sleeping under a rock since the 90's? Any modern AAA game is 3x the cost of Party Animals and most will have micro transactions in them as well. Call of Duty costs far more than this game AND has skins that cost more than this game. War Thunder, a 'free to play' game has vehicles in it that cost as much as a AAA game, and people suck it up like fine wine. 

The other half are a split between servers [which I can't attest to], and Offline mode. There are people upset that this game has no solo mode. A game called...PARTY Animals...has no solo mode. Colour me surprised! Why would you ever pick up a game that has always presented itself as a multiplayer brawler and think it has a solo mode. It's like people have lost their critical thinking skills. 

Onto brighter things, the game plays well. It has a simple premise and it nails it, the brawls are intense and though sometimes I am frustrated by a random lucky punch from an opponent, in the very next round I'll be crying with laughter as I knock someone into next week with a lolipop. 

If you enjoy the sort of game that has low downtime between games, can make your sides hurt with laughing and provides a real rush when you get on a spree of knockouts then I strongly recommend this game. If you think having an item shop or playing online is a sin, free up the lobby space.

As I am from South Africa, creating a custom game to simply play alone against AI or with some friends, we are limited to have to connect to a server with 200 ping.

This is unbearable as this game is physics-based and even our inputs feel delayed.

I have also read that there seems to be no intention to add local play so I doubt P2P will happen either.

The only reason I would buy this game again (which I genuinely would as it seems like tons of fun) would be if either servers in my region are added, or if we could host our own servers (P2P or dedicated).

TL;DR:
Seems like tons of fun, but I cannot recommend playing it at 200 ping.

Played the demo 3 years ago. And while that seems like a long time for this game to be in development, it was absolutely worth the wait. Seems people forget there was a global pandemic that could affect game development or something...weird. 

This game is so fun to play with friends, both locally with splitscreen and online against people AND splitscreen locally. Yes, the term "offline" seems to be a misunderstanding and they even addressed it on the game news feed. Splitscreen is a common term for gaming and came from a time where games didn't have any online functions at all. So i understand the misinterpretation on both sides. If that is truly important to you for this to have offline, you can refund the game if you have played less than 2hours on steam, no questions asked. But from what i can tell in the negative review section, seems everyone is enjoying the game and have not requested a refund. So it seems like everyone is butthurt for nothing or rather just joining in the crowd to get angry over trivial matters per usual. I am trying to wrap my head around what scenario people would need this game to be offline...you downloaded this game using internet on an internet based video game store...you are reading this review using your internet...

The legitimate concerns in the reviews I completely understand. 3-4 TOTAL game servers, zero servers for OCE people. Those are big problems that can be remedied by the devs and absolutely need to be fixed. The complaints about microtransactions, however, they are literally cosmetic only, you can earn in game currency to buy a lot of them straight up if you want, or if you want a super special specific one...you spend real money on it. If you do not want to spend real money, wait and see if it will become an in game currency item (if that is a thing, idk) or maybe don't buy it at all if it is that personal to you.

review: Best game to play with friends. The only complaint I have is the sore throat from laughing too much while playing. Ignore the bad reviews of those offline game seekers. Play this game online, either solo or with friends. And its HELLA FUN. Also the animals are ADORABLEEEE.

My overall verdict is definitely a positive one. 

Lets start with the elephant in the room: The presence of micro-transactions in a paid game feels very muddy and I frequently come back to the question "if everything has a dollar value in game, why isn't this just free to play?" and the answer to that is fairly simple. The gameplay loop isn't strong enough to support a f2p model and the ultimate goal still is a party game you play with friends in person. The game reflects this fairly strongly in that you technically can buy stuff with cash, but just playing the game will get you stuff faster than the typical f2p game. I preordered the deluxe version and don't intend to spend more money, but in doing that i had approximately 10 dollars worth of the cash currency to spend in game and have no complaints about buying the loot boxes. It was fine. In one 30min sitting i had earned through playing one loot box anyhow. So really, you can just play and it'll be fine. 

The controversy over offline mode is kinda of moot to me. As long as it plays smooth as butter when I have friends over I really don't care. 

But, now on to the good stuff. Gameplay. I have to say I really enjoy this game. Like a lot. It is not an easy game by any account and that relates entirely to the fact that it is physics based. Controls come out of the box needing a quick remap (default maps jump to Y, when every game i've ever played maps to X) but once you're set up right things start to work pretty nice. Goals vary from map to map and going solo or with a team is also tied to them. I've found games with 2 player teams are my favorite, and probably the perfect balance of chaos and strategy. At present i've only played online but I have a group of friends ocming by this weekend to see how this fairs with a 6 player couch game. The game looks quite nice on a 65in 4k TV and doesn't melt my graphics card in the process. The thing that really attracted me to this game, aside from the solid art style, was a sense that your first time sitting down at the game you don't need a high level of competency to have fun and do reasonably well. Playing in the beta and now launch confirms that. It's just a fun party game. 

There is a part of me that honestly feels like the game could use some blood/gore to balance out the intense constant cuteness. This is a change that I don't expect to see, but there is something about it that almost reminds me "happy tree friends" and I want that game. But, like I said, that isn't something I expect to happen. Your toddler can play this game and not get scared at any point. The only limiting factor is adults will struggle to control their character, so the toddler isn't going to be able to play. 

I don't know if I would go as far as to praise this into the sky and say it is worth buying just to play random strangers online. I don't feel like it crosses that boundary, but I'm sure many people will buy it explicitly for that. For me this is the kind of game that you need to be sitting next to the person to get the full experience. 

20 bucks is a fair price. I paid 30 for the deluxe and i'm good with that price since I am literally inviting half a dozen people to explicitly come over to play this. I will say though, if you see this on sale you 100% should buy. Fun game. Polished to a fine shine.

Fun game! I don't mind the whole "offline" debacle. Paid skins that can be bought with online currency can be earned by normal play, so I don't mind that either. I don't need every skin in the games i play, so having the inability to get everything isn't a problem to me.

The maps are fun, all of them have good variety and break up the gameplay in enjoyable and interesting ways. Some more interesting than others imo but still fun nonetheless.

For a $20 indie game, I feel like a lot of these "problems" should get overlooked, since in the grand scheme of things they aren't that important. But if u think the game looks fun give it a try and form your own opinion. 

If the "offline" mode or skins end up being that big of a problem. This games not for u anyways. 

These do not prevent u from playing the actual game at all. I honestly thought what was in the 2020 demo was going to be whole game basically. I.e a couple of maps and beating up your friends. 3 years later they added so much more than I could've imagined.

Bottom line, if u like the gameplay you'll enjoy it. If u like to collect everything in an online focused game probably not. Please form your own opinion and don't hop on the hate bandwagon just because of an offline mode u won't actually play.

Honest opinion with pros and cons: 

PROS:
- Super fun game where I can play with and against my friends, and play against others in online matchmaking too. 
- Not meant to be a game taken incredibly serious and is more so a fun game to joke and mess around with friends, and at the same time generate rivalry against opponents. For example, my friends and I were a 4-stack and played against another 4-stack, and we had a little series going on where we would re-queue and face each other again. It was a lighthearted rivalry and we all added each other after. 
- "Battle Pass" is free, and gives you Nemo Bucks where you can unlock skins through a randomizer or through the "shop". Definitely a bonus as long as it remains free like so. 


CONS:
- There appears to be some server issues, where I have been in a couple games that the server lags/stutters ever few seconds... almost unplayable. I also know it was not just my connection, as my whole party was experiencing the same thing.
- Sometimes the power of hits seems random, where you feel like it should've knocked someone out but they just bounce off of them... That could just be a skill issue though. 

OVERALL:
Great game and I can see my friends and I playing more. As long as the game continues to get support and gets updated and doesn't just become a cash grab. I definitely recommend, and I would also recommend using a controller over keyboard and mouse.

[h1] There Is a Three-Way War [/h1]

Right now, there is a three-way war within the audience this game is battling as of the time of writing. On one side you have those who are frustrated with no online play and who "misunderstood" the initial description of the game. On the second side, you have a mass outcry from audiences complaining about the lack of oceanic servers. Finally, the third side is the complaint that the game has a premium loot box system to get skins. 

[h1] The Bigger Picture [/h1]

Let's take a moment to ask ourselves three questions before divulging whether you want to buy this game or not.  
Do I live in Asia or surrounding countries impacted by a lack of oceanic servers?
Do I plan to play this game truly offline?
Am I going to be enticed after my 20$ purchase to buy skins or am I going to grind online play and earn them organically?

After you have answered respectively and decided to buy the game. Good for you, it's a good game. 
If you haven't decided to buy the game, Good for you, you deserve your voice to be heard.

I've been waiting for this game for YEARS was it worth the wait? Absolutely! This game is an joy to play for mindless chaos, cute animals and blunt-force trauma. Playing on my own with A.I, had me cracking up, playing with my friends? Hardest I've laughed playing a game in a long time. My personal opinion? It's like Gang Beasts, but way more appealing. It looks better, the physics are wacky as hell, the sound effects alone get me laughing and the game is just oozing with charm.
Micro-transactions, by the time I'm writing this, are JUST for skins, skins that have no effect on gameplay what so ever and they are skins that CAN BE BOUGHT with ingame currency earned from leveling up or playing online games. Gaining XP is a bit slower playing solo, but if you're not the obsessive type that NEEDS TO EARN EVERY SKIN IN A WEEK, you'll manage JUST FINE, by just ENJOYING THE GAME. So any outrage based around THAT is being blown out of the water. If this changes? Then I'll have reason to give grievances, but as the game stands right now? They make no effect to the gameplay nor are they invasive in any way. Don't let reviews talking smack about the game, using THAT as the main point of reference for the bad review, sway you from getting it. There's a decent number of maps and different game modes to play, with more coming down the line I'm sure. Some might find the price tag a little steep for the kind of game it looks like, on the outside, but if you get enough friends together, you will have a blast everytime you boot it up. I bought 4 copies MYSELF and gave 3 of them to friends before the game even went live and I do NOT regret it in the slightest.

Game is fun and toxic at the same time, the waiting to join a quick match takes longer over 1 minute.
Edit: the cause of the long waiting time to join a quick match was because there's a child process of the exe that was blocked by my firewall, the result is all of the regions have 999 ping in which causing the long waiting time. After I allow connection for the child process of the exe, the waiting time fixed and only a round 5 to 10 seconds.
I was not recommend this game because of the long waiting time but after I figure out the issue and fixed it myself, now I change it to recommend.

Great physics based brawling game with lots of slapstick humor!

+ Gameplay is fun, controls are very wobbly but that fits the goofy nature of this game
+ Cute characters, nicely animated
+ Multiplayer is fine, no lag, fast queues, even solo matchmaking is fine because you don't rely on teamplay that much
+ No pay-to-win microtransactions, only cosmetics

Edit*: The developers have fixed many of the release woes, such as mass idling, and now features a report button. Australian servers exist separate to Chinese servers, but are shared with servers hosted in Singapore.

Overall, it's a very good game and also a lot of fun to play with friends. I can't say for sure whether one should give a positive or negative review, but in the end, I've decided to go with a negative one. 

Why?

- There's in-game currency that's hard to come by, and acquiring a skin requires a lot of playtime.
- You can exchange real-money currency for in-game currency, but not the other way around.
- Skins are simply too expensive, costing far more than 10-15‚Ç¨, which, in my opinion, is too much. 5‚Ç¨ would be more reasonable for what you get.
- Whether it's offline or online, it doesn't really matter to me as long as I'm at my PC. However, on the Nintendo Switch, I'd have to subscribe to play it at home with friends, which would bother me. So, that's also a negative point.
- The camera takes some getting used to and is not always ideal in situations where you're wedged in and end up staring at a wall.
- As a pre-order bonus, I received 240 Bucks, which I appreciate, but I can't really buy anything with 240 Bucks. I'd have to buy an additional 1760 Bucks with real money just to get something, so the bonus seems to be more of an incentive for further purchases.
- The AI opponents are unpredictable. Why does an Easy Bot act so foolishly in some games but perform like a pro in others, like in Hockey? It's illogical and difficult to determine which type of bots to play against.
- In custom games, there are too few settings. I'd like to play some games for longer periods, even if I turn off HP and Knockout. After just 1 minute, the poison or ice comes into play, so you always end up dying from it. You can't just have a relaxed 10-minute brawl or deal with external forces that you can't control and can't disable or adjust.

That's why I love indie games; you can really feel the passion and dedication that goes into them, and developers are grateful for every cent. They release update after update, and it shows. Here, it's mentioned that it's a small team that takes their time with things. Unfortunately, I see a lot of profit-driven practices from studios like EA or Tencent, where the developers supposedly come from. It's all about making quick money, squeezing as much as possible out of players, and as soon as it's no longer profitable, they simply let the game die.

I don't foresee much new content for the future if the game isn't profitable for the developers. I believe that in a year, no one will be picking up the game anymore, and it'll be over with no further updates or improvements. That's why I'm skeptical about the whole concept, especially after such a long wait ‚Äì in my case, two years of anticipation.

Therefore, I can currently only advise against making a purchase recommendation. Nevertheless, I continue to play the game without investing a single cent, as the buying tactics don't resonate with me in this project.

I normally don't post reviews but I never had so much fun playing a multiplayer game in such a long time. Party Animals is like a perfect mix of Gang Beast and Mario Kart mini games. I recommend ignoring all the reviews that are complaining about offline mode and micro-transactions. The true fun of the game is playing with people online and the game is very generous with rewarding the player after every level up.

Let me start of by saying the game itself is kinda fun, maybe a little overpriced for the amount of maps available.

For the people wondering if the game runs on the Steam Deck, it does. Around 50 FPS on medium settings, with some minor frame drops here and there.

One thing I don't like about this game are the super overpriced cosmetics. Sure, you don't need them to play the game and no gameplay mechanics are locked behind a paywall (thank god) But the "clothing" in the game are more expensive than they are in real life which is pretty nuts.

If this game was free-to-play it would change my perspective, but it's ‚Ç¨18,00 and still has the same in game prices of games that are free.

So why do I not recommended this game? Well not just because of the overpriced cosmetics, more because the developers were advertising this game to be playable "offline" which is a complete lie. Now they are downplaying this statement saying it's "miscommunication" which is insane to me. How can there be developers that have a history working for EA working on this title, and have the balls to claim they do not know the difference between offline and online couch co-op.

It's absolutely a case of false advertising, and with this statement (imo) they are showing their true colors, and honestly I don't trust them to resolve further issues that may come along the way equitable.

TLDR: Fun game, expensive cosmetics, untrustworthy developer.
Buy if you like this type of game and are willing to take a risk.

So many analogies could be made about this game, its like an egg with a yolk of gold but a shell made of barbed wire, its like a phoenix trapped in an unacceptably small rusty bird cage, its like one of those gamecube demo stations you'd only find at the most run down mcdonalds back in the day. This is hands down one of the best party games I've played in years, the gameplay is pure stupid fun, the game modes are creative and unique, and the style is just such eye candy. But, encapsulating what id consider almost party game perfection, is predatory monetization practices, poor communication with the community, and lies. There is no way you've been pushing the promise of offline couch multiplayer for nearly 3 YEARS only to have it be completely absent in the final release and chalked up to a "misunderstanding" with little to no plans of implementing it even AFTER all the backlash.

I am for sure still gonna clock in a stupid amount of hours into this game laughing my ass off with friends. When it comes to local play, once you get around the inconvenient local setup and garbage split screen UI and whatnot, it still works perfectly fine as a couch multiplayer game. And despite the fa√ßade the game wore up until launch, it has still been very much worth the wait, but for those questioning the purchase I simply cannot recommend supporting it until the devs get their shit together, listen to the community, add offline play, and dumb it down with the live service microtransaction bullshit. Boycott any in-game purchases, leave negative reviews, and keep reinforcing the obvious problems, all until we get an acceptable response, or more realistically, until the already doomed from the start live service outlook puts this game in the grave within the next 2 years.

The game is fantastic, it needs some adjustments in certain modes and more settings for them, but in the original 2020 beta, there was an offline mode. I understand that they take measures to protect their intellectual property, but imposing mandatory online DRM for all modes seems nonsensical. It's a party game; it's inconceivable that you have to be connected to the internet to play locally with friends. If you ever take your laptop out or don't have internet at home, the game becomes useless. It's not good for us because one day they might decide to shut down the servers, and there goes the game. That wasn't the idea.

And I don't want the copy/paste excuse that they started putting in all the reviews about how they got confused and don't know English anymore. Look, many people waited for 3 years for the game to come out, expecting what was already there and much more, tolerating all the silence and excuses. Be honest and say that you're doing it to protect the game. Stop telling lies because you're going to continue like this for the entire life of the game. In these cases, it's better to speak from an honest perspective, as indie developers often do. Besides, if you're using this excuse, it's because you don't plan to release the offline mode, and do you really think, with the peak of players at launch and the excessive amount of sales you'll probably have, that this is necessary?

This game is really fun! Pretty much exactly what I remember from when I playtested in 2020 or however long ago it was. TLDR if you want a game you can play with friends, go for it! it's a load of fun and laughs. Can buy skins and stuff if you want (I don't personally care for this) and if you wanted to you could play with randoms, but that's not why I bought the game tbh, it has no real value to me. I bought it to play in private lobbies with my IRLs and other friends, and it fits the bill perfectly for that. Kind of like Among Us or Goose Goose Duck in some ways.

Lack of language localisations such as Japanese, incomplete sets: ie you can get an owl but its avatar doesn't exist, poorly optimised so your pc resources are put to the max even with vsync on, lack of servers. unfair ban when disconnected or game crashes, and so on.

Party Animals drop players into a mandatory short tutorial before into competitive play where players are pit against other players as very cute animals while completing objectives. Players can also customise their avatars, animals, visit the shop and the gacha game.

While I recommend this fun little game, it remains a little game that lacks many options and features. Many players will definitely become bored, very quickly, and returning now and then out of a whim or when there's new content. Throughout the developer's very long and many years of development, not much has changed since the announcement, gameplay previews, and trials. There are not enough animals and customisation options are limited; additional options are locked behind an undesirable paywall, and some through progress. The map range is very limited in quick match which is the main feature. Most maps are fixed to the genre of squad battles; 2v2v2v2 while few are team based; 5v5, the latter appears more desirable during 200 hours of matchmaking (alone and play with friends in their places).

I was originally hesitant to purchase this game because of the mixed reviews, but I am definitely pleasantly surprised.

Beautiful game and art style, really enjoyable gameplay, so much so that I spend 5 hours straight playing it since I've bought it.

I had no issues playing with my friends online in custom games and offline split-screen. (Their original wording didn't seem to represent having a single-player campaign in my opinion, so I don't understand why people are mad about that.)

Gacha isn't the only way or the primary way to get skins/outfits, and you can get plenty of spins by just playing, AND there are guaranteed odds, so if you spin 10/30 times you will get an epic/legendary skin or outfit.

Both item shop currencies are also easily earn-able by playing, you can even get enough to buy even the most expensive legendary skin by just playing.

I didn't have any queuing issues while playing either.

Overall one of my favourite releases of this year, props to the devs, hope the reviews end up being overwhelmingly positive in the future, because that's what my experience of the game has been.

I'm so disappointed by Party Animals.  I had hoped to be able to play local couch co-op last night but the implementation of this feature is an absolute afterthought at best.  I had controllers all controlling player one, with no real understanding as to why - not had this problem in other couch games, so why this?  Probably because Recreate Games' goal was to focus on a single player per game, matchmaking online model.  I didn't buy this game expecting a live service model, and the always online aspect has put me off completely.  This game sorely needs an offline only couch co-op mode, skipping the necessity for logging in to a server.  Why?  Because once this game for whatever reason dies and the servers pulled, it's completely useless like any other live service game.  I sincerely hope the developers listen to their community and the criticism they've faced and make plans to rectify it.  Until then this is categorically not a party game.

[h1] 8/10 [/h1] [h1] Great Game With Endless Hours of Fun [/h1] 
[h2] but... [/h2] [h3] I Can Already Hear the Incoming Critiques [/h3]

Since this is Recreate Game's [b] FIRST [/b] game we should cut them some slack. Giving them feedback is way better than just attacking the developers. They are listening to suggestions and feedback on Discord so you should be happy they are doing this unlike other companies who completely ignore the community. You can check their official pages for more info and get updates.

This game is [b] AMAZING! [/b] I've waited over [b] THREE YEARS [/b] for it to come out and it's just fun as I remembered. Although I think they could have released it back then and slowly added updates to it, I know there won't be the same amount of hype for it as before. Hours will fly by and each game does not feel long at ALL! Each game is different and you will always find some crazy way to win or lose. This is why I rate it a 8/10.

[b] Now for the bad. [/b]

[h3] Weapons: [/h3] Something that I've noticed many people comment on, is the balancing of the weapons. 
Some weapons are too strong or too random and this factor only frustrates players like myself. If they can make it a set amount of damage per weapon so it can be a skill issue then it will be a blessing, but I doubt this will happen anytime soon. ANY weapon should not be able to throw you SO FAR! One hit with any weapon it could be a game over for that match.

[h3] Grabbing: [/h3] This might sound stupid but why am I able to grab on to well, ANYTHING! I know this was intentional as I heard in the tutorial you can grab, pick up, and punch anything. BUT WHY! I find myself constantly grabbing on the floor, team members, and that [b] random brick [/b] on [b] "Ichiban" [/b]. They should have a feature that only allows you to grab on to certain parts of the map NEVER the floor, as well as not being able to grab and knock out your teammates even though in certain cases you need too for them to survive. I think the game will do just fine and it will get rid of those annoying cases where either you or your teammate ruin the match because one knocks the other out.

[h3] Maps: [/h3] Some maps need balancing and minor tweaks. For example, I can already tell "Beast Hockey" will have the lowest play count. It's not because it isn't fun but it's because the puck, and how heavy it is, makes it so unpredictable, anything can happen. You can't run around it on time. You can't stand in front of it or you get knocked and thrown with it. You can hardly move because it's ice...(why not on ice skates and make it faster/better control). You also can't aim properly because of the HUGE size. I've seen 4 PLAYERS leave the map all at once and then our team got kicked because there were not enough players. I can hardly imagine how other matches are going. So balancing and minor changes to some maps will make them fun and people will want to play them.


[h3] Conclusion: [/h3] There are more things people are rightfully complaining about but it's not a part of the core gameplay. Offline, Servers, Loot Eggs, Demo Rewards, Item Shop, all can be forgotten when you just want to play the game. Well except for offline but you can't expect a 1v1 or a 2v6 (AI) match to be as much fun as the 2v6 (real players) which the maps were intended for. That was an error on their part and if you bought it for offline play then just get a refund. I promise you'll keep the game and it will be much more fun playing online.
 
Well, let me know if you agree or disagree with what I mentioned and you better hope I don't come across you in a lobby. [b] "WAALLTUHHHHH"-Convict Sparky aka VeteranClashGaming [/b]

TL;DR: The gameplay is a lot of fun and it's easy to pick up, but there are better, cheaper party games that come without the over-monetisation and live-service issues. Best to wait for a sale or choose a different game altogether.
[hr][/hr]
[h1]The Good[/h1]
I played the original demo back in October 2020, along with my friends. We all loved it; it was simple and lighthearted, with easy-to-learn mechanics, cute fuzzy animals, vibrant colours, and creatively designed maps. When I got playtest access, I was excited to learn that all these highlights had survived the long development process and had even been improved upon in some respects ‚Äì new maps, new animals, new ways to customise your animal. Unfortunately, these were the only improvements over the original demo, and the only good things I have to say about the game.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
[h2]Monetisation[/h2]
At 20 USD, Party Animals is comparable in price to other party games. Unlike other party games though, the upfront cost doesn't grant access to everything. Many items need to be purchased using one of 2 currencies - Cookies or Nemo Bucks - or randomly obtained from Eggs (their cute version of lootbox / gacha mechanics). Initially, I was under the impression that all these currencies could be obtained through regular gameplay [i]or[/i] real-money purchases, and so I treated it as a progression system (I have since learned that Nemo Bucks are only available for real-money purchases). Thinking that everything was tied to these 3 currencies, I was surprised on day 1 when I opened the shop to see a bundle for a new character that didn't appear in my locker - the "Cabbage Dog". It was only available through a bundle costing real money - 5.9 USD to be exact, or a little under 1/3 the price of the game. It was incredibly insulting after paying an upfront cost to [i]immediately[/i] be presented with content that was inaccessible without paying more.
[h2]Online-Only Service[/h2]
I wasn't surprised that the time-limited playtest required an internet connection to play, but I wasn't expecting it from the full release. Unfortunately, there is [i]no[/i] offline mode. Want to look through your locker at the animals and cosmetics you‚Äôve collected? You need to be connected to the internet. Having some friends over and want to play with them on your couch? You need to be connected to the internet. Going to a party and want to bring this game along? Better hope they‚Äôll give you their internet password. Going on a road trip? Plane ride? Camping trip? Anywhere else with a lack of stable internet? Tough. You can‚Äôt play this game, even locally, until you‚Äôre reconnected.
[h2]Longevity[/h2]
Even if you're someone who is always connected to the internet, the online-only model makes me question the longevity of the game. Party games tend to be short-lived. They are the type of game you return to when you want mindless fun, not the type of game you play consistently. As such, party games tend to quickly lose their players. For a game that's online only, a consistently low playerbase is the indicator of an upcoming end-of-service. When that happens, say goodbye to your access, and any hope of playing your beloved game again.

[h1]Closing Thoughts[/h1]
Party Animals is a solid party game. Its controls and mechanics are well polished, its visuals are gorgeous, and each match is full of mindless fun. You will enjoy your time with it, especially if you have friends to play with. But enjoyment is not the same as being worth the price. The lack of an offline mode means that even your local games will be affected by high ping, and further means that you will lose access altogether if/when the servers get shut down. If you [i]really[/i] want to get it, wait for a sale... but there are plenty of party game alternatives available that can be played offline or online, and [i]they[/i] don‚Äôt charge for cosmetics.

Despite the early rating bash it received for not having offline play/couch co-op as originally advertised, this game kicks ass.
For anyone looking for reference it feels like a re-energised version of Gang Beasts but mixed with elements of Fall Guys and some area-fighter games. Good customisation, rewarding achievement system, easy to pick up controls, very satisfying knock-out and combat system, many maps and game styles, proximity and full voice chat, etc. Plus you can even still interact with the ongoing match after you've been knocked out. When you add that with quick matchmaking and rounds, you feel like you're always in the game. Would highly recommend if you are looking for a fun game to play with friends online. 5/5 for me.
