[h1] Okay, I have a lot to say about this game [/h1]


[h1] A amazing game flawed by interesting design choices [/h1]
First things first, this game is awesome, I've played about 6 hours in the closed beta, and its a fun game, but there are somethings the developers could have done and shouldn't have done that would have made this game better. My first gripe with it is that it has excessive micro transactions, It would make sense if it was a free game, but as it is now, there is no reliable way to get the premium currency after you get all the achievements, and levels (making you pay for more skins). First there is a fortnite like item shop with rotating skins in it to make you fear of not being able to get it again after the time is up or FOMO, then there is a gacha or loot box system where you get you egg coins and basically gamble for a skin, this is baffling. we already paid 20 - 30 dollars on this game and now were expected to pay more? I know they have to make money but this is way too excessive. Next is the game modes, why isn't there a queue??? Every time there is team mode, which I really don't like playing as there is no "Team" as everyone is just doing there own thing, I end up leaving the game and getting a match penalty. just add a queue for the game modes you want to play in, pretty simple. Next and this is a big one for some people, why is there no offline play? You wanna play offline split screen with some buddys? Too bad, because that isn't allowed, because how are you gonna spend money if you are offline? Speaking of split screen, it seems to me like split screen has been more of a after thought, which really disappoints me because split screen is what half of these party games are. 

[h1] TLDR: [/h1]
if you didn't want to read me ranting, basically Party Animals is a phenomenal game help back by weird design choices like not being able to queue for certain game modes, not being able to play offline, a messy split screen, and excessive micro transactions. If they got these things fixed (which I highly doubt for the micro transactions) then this game would be a ten out of ten for me, but how it is now I can't rate it higher than a six out of ten.

I have previously made a negative vote on party animals, the result is still the same, I still would give it a negative review, but, the reasoning has changed a lot. Before my biggest complains were as such: 1, no oceanic servers, 2: no solo mode, only team modes, and dependence on teammates, 3: Micro transactions. Now, after around 2 months of new patches, updates, etc, I will now say the game is in a better place than it was, but still suffering in many different categories. They have now added oceanic servers, allowing austrailians to finally play the game without being at such a massive disadvantage you may as well not even play, but, there is still expensive micro transactions, and there is still no solo mode. Again, only team modes makes it so if your teammate or teammate's are bad, or inexperianced, or AFK, etc, you will have a big disadvantage that is detrimental to the point of winning because you were the better player; it is sometimes similar to rolling dice, hoping for a good roll, hence, good teammates that will actually be good, and not throw the game. I would really like to see a solo mode, and honestly, once they do release a solo mode, I will likely come back to this review again, to change it to a probable positive review. Like I said before, the game has improved with many patches, and updates, giving new mechanics, a new map, more skins, challanges, more regions, etc, but, there is still the big problem of micro transactions and only team mode games. Micro transactions are typically seen in primarily free to play games, such as fortnite, and COD warzone, and various other free to play games. But, party animals is normally around 20$ US dollars, for the standard edition. But, the dev's still decided they needed many bullshit microtransactions that are just as much money, to buy the game, as to get 2 lame, boring legendary skins. Once both these problems are fixed, or made easier to withstand, I will still be giving this game a negative review.

Game is just as fun as it was during the 2020 demo, I've experienced no issues with the servers (East Coast USA for reference), playing offline doesn't apply to me or most people on Steam because couch co-op basically died 10 years ago. That being said, if you want to make a custom game and have everybody on the same machine, I'm sure you can absolutely do that.

Game is a blast, I'm laughing my ass off every time I start up a match (which took like 5 seconds to queue, there's no ten minute wait times that I've seen some people claim). The micro transactions (literally all cosmetics, nothing game changing) aren't really that egregious, you can earn both forms of currency by just playing the game and leveling up so you can achieve most of, if not all the content the game has to offer without spending more than the game's asking price.

This game is an absolute blast to play. I never got into Gang Beasts and when this demo came out back in 2020 I fell in love with it. Finally getting around to release and is still just as fun. I was a bit worried about the amount of content due to all the different levels in the game, but I am happily surprised by the amount of levels that have been added to the final game. They have bunches of team objective games, and last-man standing. The different gamemodes and level hazards really creates many unique interactions. And its all in a physics game which I am very fond of all the floppiness of the characters.

The cons of the game are some expensive costumes in the game. There are two separate currencies, Cookies which are earned by playing the game, and Nemo Bucks which are premium currency which are sometimes rewards for leveling up or by purchasing it in-game. Cookies can get you some nice looking costumes, but the sleek and shiny costumes are usually locked behind Nemo Bucks. The only other issue I have with the game is that it can be very easy to start being a sweaty player and KOing people in the first few seconds of the round. Leaving you to spectate for up to a few minutes depending on the map. But you can sometimes avoid this by playing defensively with rolls or running away at round-start.

Also, it is somewhat disappointing to hear that there was never a planned offline mode. Most games coming out these days that aren't Singleplayer seem to all be online only.

[h3] Really good >>Party<< Game (Up to 8 Players). [/h3]
It's like Gang Beasts with more technical oomph behind it and much better visuals, makes others in the "Ragdoll brawler" genre seem obsolete in comparison. 

I've originally played this during Steam's Game Festival in 2020 and it's exactly what I signed up and have been waiting for.
[list]
[*] More maps, 
[*] handfuls of different game-modes and 
[*] a ton of characters. 

[/list]
[h2] The item-shop [/h2] is a particularly greedy move in concept, but "Out The Box", my array of critters was pretty sizable. A selection so large I doubt anyone would reasonably be dissatisfied. 

[i] Sharks to pigs to moose to bears to cats, Look at that! [/i] [b] You begin with at least 20+ animals available to you.[/b] unfortunately though, [spoiler]similar to me while writing this review[/spoiler] 
[b] they will be naked; As God intended. [/b] 

But should you wish to adorn your animal with fashionable swag in contempt of nature, You have 3 options currently: [olist] 

[*] Level up to earn "tokens" 
[*] Complete Achievements/Challenges for Currency or 
[*] Buy currency ($1 per lootbox, $8 per two costumes in a bundle).
[b] Personally, [/b] I don't care, because the animals aren't paywalled and that's what really matters, that I didn't have to pay to become a Hammerhead shark and headbutt people off a jungle bridge.

[h3] Game has a lot of soul and flavor to it, [/h3] You can at least tell the 3 years of extended development went somewhere.
I think anyone can pick this up, find their favorite animal, discover their favorite map and have a lot of fun in it every so often. 

[h3] Things I feel they can improve on [/h3]
* Cheaper entry price ($15) & 
* Rework Safe Capture. 
Because modes that solely involve wrestling items out of a dogpile of animals with everybody stagnating, holding grab for minutes on end feels developmentally shortsighted, The novelty of it reflects poorly on the overall game when given the same spotlight as the "primary", [b] BETTER [/b] brawling modes. 

Nonetheless,
[h1] I rate this game 4/5 Fur-balls [/h1]

Pros and Cons

Pros
- Fun, hectic and cute game. It reminds me of Gang Beast.
- A lot going on in every game. One minute you could be walking and the next you're getting tasered or smacked by a lolipop
- Great game with friends
- Great game to make friends

Cons
- Gameplay can seem a little weird or choppy at first because of the movement system
- No offline mode
- Skins can cost upwards towards 30$++ dollars (Doesn't make sense for a game that isn't F2P, should be easier to get skins)

Overall I give the game a 7.5/10, Unfortunately Party Animals was a little below my expectations after my first demo playthrough a few years back. Was very excited to play this with friends but maybe the game will be better in a few months and then I can come back to it.

[h3]Very fun! Cute and charming.[/h3] Movement once you figure out feels great, aside form running you can sprint, doge roll, jump and drop kick. 
     
  The roll is especially important because it's faster than sprinting most of the time. Useful in a lot of situations, catching up, running out of danger, avoiding attacks.

  Visuals are great even at lower than high settings! And some additional touches like slow motion moments, the end match screen with the photograph alone is fun.

[h3]DOWNSIDES? [/h3]
  There are micro-transactions on release as paid title, idk if it's strictly a negative, but some of you might not like it.
Also, always online requirement to play, even local co-op. Some regions lack dedicated servers, so look it up, if you're from OCE (or maybe SA too not sure) you might want to wait.

"Party Animals" is nothing short of a divine masterpiece in the realm of video games. It is a creation that seems to have been sculpted by the hands of the gaming gods themselves, a true testament to the artistry and innovation that can be achieved in this medium. With its delightful and whimsical characters, ingenious gameplay mechanics, and a seamless blend of chaos and camaraderie, "Party Animals" stands as a shining example of what gaming can and should be. Its ability to bring joy and laughter to players of all ages is unparalleled, making it a modern gaming marvel that feels like a gift from the heavens.

Phenomenal game that's even better with friends. You can make a private lobby as well and still level up (at a slower rate than online) while doing so if you don't want to play against randoms. Some things need tweaking like being able to one hit KO someone right off the bat with a dropkick or a sprint punch, the ranged weapons feeling too inaccurate, and when in water or the air, you are absolutely helpless to get back to a platform. Other than that, everything is great. Micro-transactions are optional for skins, but you can earn both forms of in-game currency to eventually unlock what you want. The hatred over no offline play is absurd. if you want to play with just yourself and your friends at your house, just make the aforementioned private lobby and lock it so only people with a code can join. Also, the devs don't owe you a solo experience. It's a party game, if you don't like it because you can't play solo, your missing the whole point of "party" in "party game".

I've had my eye on PA for years, waiting eagerly for the release. The game for me didn't disappoint. The chaotic team based fun is exactly what I hoped for. The variety of modes and the 20 maps at release means you're always doing something different after each match.

The game is crossplay enabled between xbox and PC and supports teams of up to 4 players.

However being in a group of 3-4 players doesn't always mean you will be on the same team as some maps feature 2v2v2v2 survival gameplay which will move one or two people from your group into another team.

Some of the best fun for ¬£15 I ever had, hands down.

Gangbeasts but with a bit more concise controls.  Still tons of chaotic fun.  No wave mode atm, but tons of game modes (various sports, free for all, team, lots of maps).  You can play with AI, but it does require an online connection to play.

Some people making negative reviews have NO IDEA WHAT THEY'RE TALKING ABOUT. Let me clear some things up. Point 1) Yes the game does have a cash shop that is STRICTLY for cosmetics and nothing that actually gives you an advantage. NOTHING is forcing you to spend money on this part of the game. Point 2) You can earn premium currency by playing the game unlike what others are saying. You get certain amounts for certain level up milestones. Point 3) The no offline issue. I understand why people are upset about this and the description of the offline play was a bit misleading, but if I am correct you can still do couch co-op with your friends with on the same device through split screen. Honestly the hate this game is getting is kind of sad, to the point people are trying to find things to complain about, to the point of complaining about there being TOO MANY game modes. All in all, this is a fantastic game to play with friends or randoms in quick match and for a great price.
Its a fun party game, love the modern take.

I've been watching this game for YEARS as I always saw it as "Gang Beasts with weapons". Yes, it is extremely unfortunate about the miscommunication (or lying, whatever you desire) and I can understand why people are hating on it so hard. However, I had the intention of playing this game with friends through the party system in-game or through the Steam Remote Play. For my intentions, this game is GREAT! It was exactly what I was hoping for when I first heard about the game. However, there is a SHIT ton of micro-transactions, which is not my forte. Luckily they are just skins and not pay-to-win (for the time being). If you have access to internet and want to play this game with friends, then I'd recommend it. The negative reviews aren't about the gameplay, they're about the last minute switch up. Hopefully they eventually change this, or at least refund the people who pre-ordered assuming it was something else. But for what I intended it to be, I got exactly what I wanted.
One of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long time. Was very much worth the wait.

Great fun! If you liked Gang Beasts even just a little, then you'll love this, it's basically an improvement in every way. Local multiplayer is not present for now but that's the only drawback. There is a cash shop, but you get tons of stuff just by playing so the cash shop isn't even a big deal, and it's not heavily shoved in your face like in some games. Solid connection online with basically zero lag, playing with friends from the other corner of the country. Tons of items, maps, and game modes. The game also lets you add AI if you want to try the team games but have an odd number. If you get killed in the brawl mode, you're not just sitting and waiting like in Gang Beasts, you get to actively mess with the players still alive. It's great fun and after only a few hours my friends and I were starting to get hoarse from all the laughing.

I think everyone who is displeased about the offline play has a right to air their grievances.  All the negative reviews had me quite concerned about whether I should buy the game.  However, I'm glad I did and the game deserves a lot of credit.  It does almost everything right.  I was able to play local co-op with my daughter with no issues.  The gameplay is smooth, fun, sound and graphics are quite good and so far I've been very impressed with map variety.  AI is at least as good as Gang Beasts.  I'm glad I decided to buy, and for me the lack of offline play and the microtransactions are non issues and it does not effect my experience.  I don't plan on paying for microtransactions (unless they release a frog, then I might drop some cash).  I've only played custom games with local co-op and have had no issues with lag.    As a fan of Gang Beasts, Boomerang-fu, Stick Fight the Game, Rounds, A Gummy Life - I can recommend this game.

To be honest the game is fun, the user interface is neat, the game have a lot of map variation, the character and their costume is cute. Unfortunately, it's always online game with gacha monetization system. Yep... party game with always online system and gacha, what a great combination. 

In in game, you will shown 2 currency, Cookie and Nemo Buck. Cookie can be earn by simply playing the game, while Nemo Buck is premium currency you will get as reward of certain event in the game or in the community, but mostly through exchanging with real money to Nemo Buck. With those currency you can buy variety of costumes available in the shop and the stock of said costumes will change after a certain time.

The costumes are devided into several grade, from common to legendary. The sad part is, 1 legendary costume in the shop cost you USD$ 22.4, while other legendary costumes can be accuire through gacha along with other lesser grade costumes, with some luck of course. Fortunately, there is some safety feature in gacha like pity sistem, it's sure 1 random legendary costume at 70 pull or 8400 Nemo Buck (USD$ 63). If you still do not get the legendary costume you want, there is sure egg mechanic, which you will get after pulling 2 legendary costume. And the legendary costume will not repeat until you collect all the legendary costumes from gacha machine, while other lesser grade will repeat and exchage to cookie if you got the second time.

If you still have desire to buy the game, do tread carefully, because monetization with gacha system is known for it's notoriety making game developer and publisher become greedy and scammy.

Good game, but poorly run by the devs.

-Game advertised an offline and online mode like every other party game. Changed the game description after launch and saying that it's online only. Claims it's a "translation error", but offline means the same regardless...
-3 Year wait for a few more maps, animals and item shop. Otherwise it's basically the same as the demo in 2020 and we had to wait 3 years to play it again.
-3 Year wait had 0 communication on what they were adding to the game. Dev team always stayed silent when asked about a release date, what they're adding, what they plan to add, etc... Just ignored the playerbase.
-FFA removal. All games are either in duos or full teams.
-Pricey skins that basically just add a hat or a shirt.

One of the very few games my friends and I have been following for it to come out. We really enjoyed the demo and were eager for the full release. After years of silence, we finally get it only to be disappointed by their decisions. We predicted this would happen when they wouldn't release the demo that was already a finished game.

Overall, its a good game. Just poorly run by the devs.

Step 2: Play Ichabod or any other FFA style match a few times (Blackhole is a favorite of mine)
Step 3: Watch your friends start to all hate each other.
Step 4: Your friend group hates each other.
Step 5: ??

Just repeat these 6 simple steps good luck getting everyone to become friends again!!

very fun with friends or in solo queue. open mic voip is a great addition so if u play this please dont disable it. also the eggs (lootbox) system is good and u can get a good amount of eggs (lootboxes) just from playing. hopefully more cosmetics keep being added in future.

some people are saying in their reviews that u cant get the micro-transaction currency used to buy the lootboxes through normal play but they are completely wrong. the game rewards you with the micro-transaction currency for completing some achievements as well as for levelling up in battle pass style rewards. there is no paid battle pass, only the free level up rewards. all purchasable items are only cosmetic. in about 14 hours i've earned enough in game cash to be able to open 5 lootboxes and i wasnt specifically hunting for achievements or xp to maximise my cash

English:
For some of the negative comments
This is simply an expression of my own opinion
So far, with the time spent on previous tests
I've played the game for about 10 hours
I myself like this game
Although it still has a few minor flaws
I'd like to talk about the advantages of Party Animals first.
-
1. The simulation of the character's movement is very good.
I like the simulation of the character's movement.
And the overall style of the game is cozy and cute
There are a lot of characters in the game.
You can unlock them as long as you have a skin.
2. in terms of game map and gameplay
Some of the Survival maps have their own characteristics.
The team scoring gameplay has some different gameplay experiences.
3. There are a lot of small details in the game team that should be encouraged.
For example, in order to make the waiting process not boring.
Added some ways to interact with each other
There are also ways to interact with the game UI on the fitting side.
4. the game pass is free of charge, which may be due to the game's buyout system.
5. There are no bugs in the game so far.
There are no plug-in players.
The matching speed is also very fast
However, I'm not sure if there will be any in the future, we can still wait and see.
6. The official forum has been set up for everyone to express their opinions and give feedback.
- 
Next, I'll talk about the shortcomings that I see after the pros.
1. The game is a bit expensive at over 400 NT dollars.
But you can see the care of the production team.
I hope there will be more updates in the future.
2. You do need to wait for some time on the first day.
And that time is not according to the order of logging in.
Like I waited for about an hour and a half 
My brother logged in slower than me, but it only took 3 minutes.
3. The money in the store is very expensive.
It's like buying a deluxe pass.
I can't buy the Epic or above.
The free money in the pass is also less.
4. It's hard to add friends to the system.
5. Twister coins can't be purchased or exchanged with in-game currency.
These are the pros and cons that I can think of so far.
For your reference, there's still room for improvement.
But overall, I'd give it an 8 out of 10.
The game experience and style are very much to my liking.
As for the price, I think it might be adjusted later.
I just hope he won't be invaded by game cheaters.

Pros:

Maps. I played 2 of the three playtests and I'm back to play the final release! There are a lot of maps (about 20) which all have a unique feature about them and they are all so much fun!

Gameplay. It's a combination of rubber bandits and gang beasts, which are my favorite party games. And it's great! You can punch, kick, dropkick, headbutt, swim, and climb, plus there are plenty of weapons!

Characters. You can't deny they are awesome! I love the selection of animals and all of the different outfits, much better than most party games.

Progression. The rewards from progressing through the game are great. You are able to earn all of the currencies through leveling up which is not very common in games nowdays! Ot definitely feels rewarding to play.

Compatibility. Just wanted to mention that I appreciate the devs supporting the Stean Deck, and it runs pretty well!

Cons:

Offline play. Many people were disappointed that offline mode isn't in the game, but that wasn't my main reason to buy the game. Though, I do feel like it needs to be added as it seems essential for any party game.

Pricing. It's just too much. As mentioned earlier, you can earn currency through progression, which is good. But, if you want to get a legendary outfit out of the store, that's 3000 Nemo Bucks!! 3000 Nemo Bucks costs about $23! That's waaaaay overpriced for one outfit. At the same time though, some outfits are fine, like only 120 Nemo Bucks.

Conclusion:

I really like the game! It has a few problems, but overall I think it's great. 9/10 from me.

Sorry, but no.  The game is really fun and cute, but the monetization is scummy and evil.

Party Animals uses all the tricks in the book like FOMO (timed store), gambling addiction (loot boxes), and multiple forms of currency to maximize confusion.  The gacha mechanics are especially bad.  You can get duplicates which pay out measly amounts of the lesser in-game currency.  I've bought about 20 of these gacha items and half of them were duplicates, so the odds are stacked against you.

The forced always online DRM is purely to support these unlockables.

The game also has some unfair maps.  For example, in Trebuchet you're more likely to be thrown in the water next to the clearing.  One team's clearing is on the north and the other on the south.  Since the water only flows in one direction, one team has a chance to recover after being thrown in the water while the other team is swept away quickly.

It's a real shame.  Party Animals should have been the next Gang Beasts.

I do not understand why this game has mixed reviews, it's a fantastic game. 

Positives:

1. Plenty of maps and game modes to play.
2. Can play with friends/family privately.
3. If you do not like the pvp aspect of Party Animals, you can host a custom match and make it private, you can fight against AI on any difficulty. NOTE: Playing against AI and finishing matches barely gain you XP to level up.

Negatives:

1. In app purchases to pay real money to get new things, or in-game money you gain to get new things without paying actual money. Those 2 are separate, cookies (in-game money/not real money), and nemo bucks (real money). Cookies you use them on unlocks without paying real money and nemo bucks you pay for unlocks with actual paid money.
2. As mentioned in positive number 3 above, you only gain more XP in pvp mode to level up, not against AI.
3. No offline/LAN mode to play on, only online but to put it this way, to even play together, you need internet anyway, not sure actually, I may be wrong there.
4. A gambling system to get new unlocks if you don't want to pay real money to unlock things but it costs stuff.

Party Animals is a hilarious game and is fun as heck, get it, see if you like. I love it so much. Gives me a good laugh every time.

IMPORTANT: Read below...

For those that have friends and family to play with in private matches, you will gain more XP depending on how many players there are to level up faster. If you are playing against random players in public matches or quick matches, you gain even more XP as far as I'm concerned. 

That is all, have fun and let the hunger/fluffy games begin!

First match I ever played, I'm Machiatto on a train with my team. Some of them don't know how to play, and it shows. That's fine, the game just came out. Honestly, most are probably children coming off Gang Beasts, which uses a similar control scheme but is different enough that it requires just a little bit more practice to really get the hang of it.

The game runs smoothly. Two trains are barreling down the tracks, two teams of Red and Blue trying to stuff coal from one end of their train to the front with the engine. I'm working hard, tossing coal, when suddenly a Blue enemy jumps across the trains to board ours. He's got nunchucks, and he's a fierce little goose animal. He's whacking the dog-poop out of... I guess what literally are the doggy characters. 

I jump across like he did. I dropkick a Gorilla off the train, then I punch another Gorilla into the engine of their own train and he explodes into dust. I grab the handle next to their engine and it starts to slow them down. We end up winning, and on the final picture, I am punched in the snout and am two feet in the air when the snapshot is taken.

Good game. It's enjoyable and besides the really exorbitant prices for some of the cosmetics, which do make you look pretty cool, I'm excited to see where this game goes. Hopefully the devs listen to some of the feedback in these reviews and know that a lot of people wanna see this game SUCCEED well past its release date, like I do.

A Long Wait in Vain: My Disappointing Journey with Party Animals

As a dedicated gamer, I've eagerly anticipated the release of "Party Animals" for what felt like an eternity. With teasers and promises swirling around for three long years, my excitement knew no bounds. The premise of adorable animals duking it out in chaotic party games seemed like a recipe for endless entertainment. Sadly, after finally getting my hands on the game, my hopes came crashing down in disappointment.

The initial charm of Party Animals cannot be denied. Its cute, cuddly characters and whimsical arenas instantly put a smile on your face. From cats to dogs to bunnies, each furry contestant has its own unique appeal, and the game's colorful aesthetics are a visual treat. However, beyond the surface, the game begins to unravel.

One of the most glaring issues is the lack of content. After three years of development, one would expect a plethora of mini-games, arenas, and customization options. Instead, Party Animals offers a disappointingly small selection of mini games that grow stale far too quickly. The handful of arenas feels like a missed opportunity for diverse and exciting settings for these animal brawls. There's a stark absence of a compelling single-player experience, leaving solo players with nothing but an empty party.

Party Animals also disappoints in terms of longevity. With such a limited selection of games and lackluster mechanics, the game's replayability quickly dwindles. After a few hours of play, it's challenging to find motivation to return to the same handful of minigames.

Even more disheartening is the missed opportunity for online play. Given Party Animals' potential for raucous multiplayer fun, the omission of robust online features is a letdown. The absence of competitive modes and leaderboards leaves players with little incentive to engage with the game beyond the occasional couch co-op session with friends.

It's worth noting that Party Animals could have been a vastly different experience if the developers had taken the time to listen to player feedback during its three-year development cycle. However, it appears that the game was rushed to release without addressing these fundamental issues.

In conclusion, "Party Animals" was a game I waited three long years for, hoping for a fantastic party game experience. Sadly, it failed to live up to the lofty expectations it had set. The lack of content, uninspired gameplay, and absence of online features make it a game that quickly loses its charm. It's a reminder that hype can sometimes lead to crushing disappointment, and in the case of Party Animals, the wait was ultimately in vain.

Full review:
The game is fun and well-optimized, runs well on a Steam deck, and 20 and 40 series of RTX cards, making it an overall good experience. Demand for offline local op is a valid request, but not a negative review worthy of it. The game has one quick play mode, which allows you to play online with other players; there are  20 maps divided into a few modes; and a second custom mode, which gives you the ability to play any map with friends online. There are no major game-breaking bugs. As for micro-transactions, the game has micro-transactions, but they are purely cosmetic and provide no advantage. The game has three different currencies: cookies, Nemo bucks, and coins. Cookies are the free currency that you earn by playing the game and leveling up, which can be used to buy skins in the shop. Nemo Bucks are the premium currency that you buy with real money to buy skins. Nemo bucks can also be used to convert to cookies or gold coins.  Gold coins have so far been used in the Gacha loot box to get skins at random. You can also earn premium currency, Nemo bucks and coins, which you stop earning after reaching level 100 as of writing this review.

The game is an absolute blast but the negative reviews are trying to bring it down.

IN-GAME CURRENCY:
Yes there are microtransactions however both can be earned in-game via leveling up (playing the actual game). They are a small indie game dev and the microtransactions are just there to 1. help them grow and continue to make the game 2. if you want to grab a premium skin quicker.

GACHA LOOT SYSTEM:
The slot machine for getting other skins is there but again the premium currency used for it can be earned fairly easily. you get a minimum of 200 Nemo bucks when you level up at certain points and it costs 120 Nemo bucks to use the slot machine. During the play tests, i was able to unlock a TON of skins via achievements, slot machine, and the shop without paying extra.

MORE SERVERS:
Again its a small indie dev company and its their first game (from what I've seen at least). The probably had a smaller budget than most and wanted to get the biggest servers up and running first.

QUEUE TIMES:
This is unintentional. If you are having 10min queue times they had said that you just need to restart the game and it should be fine. Most queue times are probably 5-10 seconds.

OFFLINE PLAY:
Its unfortunate that you need wifi to play the game yes. It was promised on release and they may or may not have lied about it meaning split-screen and not offline play. I.E. (quote from discord) 

"However, it seems this statement led some players to believe that Party Animals supports an offline mode. We regret the misunderstanding and wish to clarify that the game does not have, nor do we plan to introduce an offline mode. Party Animals currently requires an online connection to play."

I hope they change their mind about not making an offline mode in the near future...

Overall the game is very fun and I got quite a few good laughs from it. The physics are just great

Negative —Å0—Åksu—Åk–µrs shall not pass!

Disclaimer: I have several more hours played during the Playtest. 

In summary, this is just a fun casual game. I won't go into the game's details because the game is so basic that watching any gameplay of this game will let you know everything the game is about. I just want to address the two primary issues about why the game is getting the reaction that it's getting, and why it's being review bombed.

[hr][/hr]
[h3]Issue #1[/h3]
The game's store page from when the game was first put up on Steam all the way up until a few hours after it's official launch, stated that you could play with your friends online or with offline split screen.  [b]However, the game is an always online game, and there is no offline functionality.[/b] They have since changed the wording of this on the store page and stated that it stemmed from miscommunication partly due to a translation issue, as English is not the studio's native language. 

You can still play split-screen mode with people locally, but you have to make a private lobby to do so. You can still invite friends online to connect to the private lobby you're playing split-screen in, but currently, playing split screen multiplayer is not available in public lobbies via online matchmaking.

[hr][/hr]
[h3]Issue #2[/h3]
There is an in-game store to unlock different animals and costumes, which has a daily and weekly rotation. There are two forms of currency: Nemo Bucks and Cookies. Some costumes cost Nemo Bucks, while some cost Cookies. Both of these can be obtained through playing the game and leveling up your "Animal Level" (i.e. Profile level). However, you get Cookies at an increased rate compared to Nemo Bucks, and once you reach the Level Cap of 100, the only reward you get is Cookies from then onwards. 

Due to this, Nemo Bucks can be considered the "Premium" currency of the game. You can pay real money to get more Nemo Bucks, and you're also able to convert Nemo Bucks into Cookies, but not vice versa. As such, you could view Party Animals as a free-to-play game masquerading as a paid game, and you already have a premium pass to gain a decent chunk of that Premium currency (provided you level up).

[hr][/hr]

At the end of the day, whether you should buy this game depends on how much you care about all of this. To reiterate though, the game at it's core is fun, and on that aspect alone, it's worth playing.

However, I couldn't help but notice that most of the game's modes that weren't present within the playtest are all very similar with only minor gimmick changes so that was pretty disappointing.

I can overlook the "translation error" on their part too, but if it really was a mistake why would you go out of your way to silence people for it? Even if it was an error, it was your error and you had months to correct it seeing as the game's steam page has been live for a good while now.

At the end of the day, the game is great, but it launched with so many red flags and greedy practices that I'm no longer interested in supporting them. There's far better games worth $20-$30 that won't make you go broke after just paying for the "full product".

developer_response:
Hi there,

Our intention with th sentence "Paw it out with your friends both online and offline." was to convey that you can play with your friends remotely (online), or together in the same location using the same device (offline) through split-screen.

We sincerely apologize for any confusion our wording caused. It was never our intention to mislead our player base about the availability of an offline mode.

The game did not feature an offline mode in the recent three rounds of playtesting either. Intentionally misleading our players while conducting playtests that clearly reveal the absence of an offline mode would be nonsensical. (We admit, however, that our description could have been more thoughtfully worded...)

For more information, please refer to the official announcement here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1260320/discussions/0/3879344463501273249/

Thank you very much for your understanding and support.

There are some valid complaints regarding offline play, but this game was always intended for online play and the game doesn't deserve to be blasted with the amount of negative reviews that it has.

It's an incredibly chaotic and fun casual game, with a lot of variety in maps and game modes. In one, two teams will be on two trains and you have to deliver coal to speed yourself up and make it to the goal before the other, while simultaneously committing sabotage on the other train by pulling the breaks. Another will have you and a buddy on a continuously breaking iceberg which you must try your best to stay on lest the ice cold waters take you.

Another nice thing is in the last stand modes (where you try to outlast everyone else amidst a crumbling stage) is that you will always have a partner so even if you get eliminated soon into the round, you still have a chance of winning. Better still when you are dead, you can still effect the match by throwing fish, bananas and bombs which helps a lot in making falling off a stage feel less bad.

The developers certainly could have done a better job with communication which they have apologised for in their recent announcement, but otherwise this is a very well made game that'll give you the experience of punching a cat in the face and watch them plummet off a bridge, which is pretty good.

Really fun game to play with friends! Controls are a bit hard to get use to at first, but after a couple of games drop kicking and punching comes second nature.

Also, not sure what people are talking about the queue times I get matches in 2 seconds.

Note #3: will edit again, but to keep it short, I've discovered custom matches only award you a quarter of what quick matches do for winning. Will reflect this proper in review. It is apparent that earning only 1 xp in custom matches on release [b]seems[/b] to have been a bug, and I appreciate the developers fixing that.

Speaking from the perspective of someone who wanted the game solely to play custom matches with friends.

Started playing second playtest, was awesome, wasn't even aware of an XP cap on custom games because it was so lenient.

Third playtest, hit the cap in less than an hour of play. Okay, a little fair, can't have people grinding premium cosmetics with bots, but still. Gave feedback requesting that it should be increased, or that we should receive a % less once the daily limit is hit, until it's reset.

Boot up the game today to see what's happened, earned exactly 1 XP for a match by myself, based on "game time". Later I would see the same thing happen when playing with a friend locally, no matter how long our match lasted. What on earth. It's possible to earn XP with one other online player in your lobby, albeit much less than we ever earned during playtests, so it's still far from ideal.

While cosmetics are not everything, to be able to earn fair progression by playing with friends is all I ever originally asked for. I tried quick matches, and it was awful; everyone was sweating for achievements and/or xp, and i suspect it will only get much, much worse now that custom matches are no longer an option (unless you want to play literal thousands of matches to progress *one* level). Not me, not my friends, not anybody should be walled off from progressing in a party game because we decide how we want to have fun with it.

The microtransactions are frankly egregious, and initially I excused it because it wouldn't be that hard to earn them with xp, even with the third playtest's crappy daily cap. Now? Money is the only way for me & others who refuse quick matches, and I'm not very inclined to spend anything further after the game's turning out on release day.

And there's the fact that the game is online-only, which is pretty silly for a party game. While the team is chalking it up to a misinterpretation due to translation, and that could very well be the truth, I'm not sure. There had to be time to make this very clear to the players, especially considering the practice of online-only games has gained infamy for its use.

Please make it so that people can actually earn XP/earn a decent amount of XP from custom games again. What took a few hours of play over the course of 2 days during Playtest #2 to get to Level 26 has already been a crawl in comparison over 3; currently just hit Level 20. 

While I understand offline mode won't come in a day, that would be great, too.

When I first played the game in 2020, I saw it as the new Gang Beasts, because said game managed to be ruined from the alpha days leading up to final release, and I thought Party Animals would be an exception. I hoped it would not become the same story, but here we are. Although I am certainly enjoying the core gameplay--it is much more fun than Gang Beasts was on retail release--I cannot recommend anyone buy this game in its current state, until, at the very least, the grievances about micros & XP gain are fixed.

Please do not let the game go out like this.

If you like to beat up your friends with cute animals, this is your game. You can play simplified sports games like soccer or football or beat the crap out of each other at an underground station. Each map is challenging and the different goals of each map are so diversified that there is no room for boredom. It takes a few minutes to complete each map, depending on its kind: the classic fighting rounds take more time, sports maps like football are rather short.  

We've played the game in a custom lobby and I highly recommend to play this game with your friends. Have fun and get on your nerves at the same time: If you are into games like Ultimate Chicken Horse, you'll like Party Animals, too.

It took 3 years, but it's finally here. The most fun I've had in a game of this type since Gang Beasts, and looks way better than it. I had a game earlier where I flying drop-kicked a kitten off of a bridge while playing as a gorilla. 10/10

Solid game played it for many hours before on the play test its the next step for the Gang beastian genre. Including a ton of maps, Items, game modes and it can be played with up to 8 players. You can punch, kick, headbutt, Jump into a drop kick, run into a heavy punch, dodge roll, or even throw items or other players the list of action and interactivity is vast far more then other party games.

There was some initial confusion with the description but anyone who played the play test knew from seeing what they were doing they were doing a live service model which I know for a fact can rub some the wrong way. But games like this benefit greatly from such a model because it lets them stream constant ebb and flow of content so the game can keep providing it.

To clarify this whole monetization system its completely optional the only thing you can get out of it is cosmetics think KF2 another popular and successful live service game its the same deal here. Except its 100% cosmetics people complain about MTXs in payed for games but if it serves a not functional purpose and is 100% optional then I kind of have to discount such a complaint. Morally dubious at worst but just a thing you can dismiss at best also even someone who is not paying can get some of these cosmetics for themselves its not 100% locked out to you as quite a lot are unlocked via free gains and achievements. So MTXs really only apply to 33 to 50% of the entire cosmetic selection yes Nemo bucks are a limited premium currency but you do gain some from leveling up and some free spins on this games loot box mechanic so you can get some of that exclusive catalog without paying.

So your money goes to actually having access to playing the full game front to back and what it has the MTXs are optional cosmetics and this being live service at least for now there is no offline for now anyways but on the flip side you have cross play so its kind of a double edged sword. So this MTX angry bus the small group I call who complain about MTXs to any capacity in games to counter them I argue while it has gotten bad in other games here this is nothing in comparison to what they could be doing.

I have most of the cosmetics I want sans like one or 2 that I dont really need and I didn't pay a cent on MTXs I will say some of the Nemo Bucks skins on the store imo are ludicrously expensive. I will give the angry bus that but you could also just not buy them because its not stopping you from playing the game you payed for.

Overall dont take the Offline only and MTX haters as proof if you played Gang Beasts and have a friend who has any of the supported platforms and a decent internet connection at least for now until the devs add a offline mode which could happen given live service guarantees long term support for the game if its done right. If we preach are wants on it loud enough I am sure it can come to fruition after all other live service games have done it so in any case yha its a 8/10 its a amazing party game if you can get past the fact its a live service with the baggage that entails.
Would be sick if they actually had offline couch co op, but either way that game is fun.

developer_response:
Hi there,

Our intention with th sentence "Paw it out with your friends both online and offline." was to convey that you can play with your friends remotely (online), or together in the same location using the same device (offline) through split-screen.

We sincerely apologize for any confusion our wording caused. It was never our intention to mislead our player base about the availability of an offline mode.

The game did not feature an offline mode in the recent three rounds of playtesting either. Intentionally misleading our players while conducting playtests that clearly reveal the absence of an offline mode would be nonsensical. (We admit, however, that our description could have been more thoughtfully worded...)

For more information, please refer to the official announcement here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1260320/discussions/0/3879344463501273249/

Thank you very much for your understanding and support.

Game is gas plain and simple I am not sure what happened with local multiplayer. And it is TOTALLY fair to complain about that. And with enough criticism I'm sure it will be added but outright boycotting the developers, and thereby preventing them from having the funds TO fix the problem isn't helping.

The game is fun, it can start and end friendships in less than 10 minutes. And if you're anything like me and found it interesting because of gang beasts,

They are not even in the same lane, more maps, more gamemodes, AND WEAPONS. The ocassional slow down on big meaty hits makes the game very satisfying. While I do wish we had the ability to control each arm individually like in gang beasts I'm glad it didn't just copy and paste its control scheme and gameplay outright.

rounds never drag on too long as most maps have stage hazards that slowly make it harder to survive.

Server issues right off the bat are almost a given in any game, but those have been mostly cleared up at least in NA servers. This games servers are NUTS. You have to have some remarkably bad internet to have enough network problems in this game to make it outright unplayable.

Its FUN, and between drops and leveling up you do NOT have to engage with its microtransactions if you do not wish too,

And again with enough criticism I'm sure they will add a way to convert cookies into Nemo bucks, or provide some way for players to continuously earn nemo bucks even after reaching level 100.

Play the game, support the developers but make sure your complaints are still heard and valid.

If you're concerned for the reviews, the game is being reviewbombed for very unfair reasons that have already been clarified by the devs over at their discord. The game initially had a description on the steam page that mentioned the ability to play offline. There is still local split screen but never was the game intended to be played fully offline (since y'know, it's a multiplayer game).

I'll leave the official note from the devs down here:
[i]
We have received feedback about some confusion regarding our game description.

Here is the original version of the game description online:

[b]Fight your friends as puppies, kittens, and other fuzzy creatures in PARTY ANIMALS! Paw it out with your friends both online and offline. Interact with the world under our realistic physics engine. Did I mention PUPPIES?[/b]

The phrase raising concerns is:

Paw it out with your friends both online and offline.

Our intention with this sentence was to convey that you can play with your friends remotely (online), or together in the same location using the same device (offline) through split-screen.
[u]However, it seems this statement led some players to believe that Party Animals supports an offline mode. We regret the misunderstanding and wish to clarify that the game does not have, nor do we plan to introduce, an offline mode. Party Animals currently requires an online connection to play.[/u][/i]

Give the game a chance, It's hella fun once you have some of your friends tap in :)

Game is super fun! I don't think the review bombs are fair, however. They stated in their Discord that the term "offline" was a poor translation, as English isn't their first language. They claim their intent was always that you could either play remotely with others or locally on the some computer, and never that the game was available offline.

It's also possible that it was a bait and switch to boost the amount of sales they could get, but I'm choosing to view it as a translation error. Once the hype settles down, we shouldn't have to worry about a queue, either.

[h1]One of the best games this Year! [/h1]

[h3]Gameplay/Design[/h3]
It feels so smooth and it‚Äôs sooo much fun! Every map, so far not even tested all, have there own style an like some specials about.
You battle for some powerful items, and knock people out with some random physics going on, which is also pretty unpredictable and fun.
In most of the Team games you have to work together, pass the ball, manipulate the enemy team, or be the goalkeeper and not rush the ball. 
The animals are cute and this game is very easy for beginners. It‚Äôs not like you need to figure out long, what to do. And from time to time you learn some new great moves or tricks which maybe improve your gameplay. 

[h3]Menu/Transactions[/h3]
The Menu is clean, not overloaded. So fits the music, well chosen. 
I don‚Äôt really understand why people hate these micro transactions. Sure you can buy some skins for like 20$, but you don‚Äôt have to. It‚Äôs not like people, that are are buying cosmetics have powerful punches or stuff. It‚Äôs just cosmetic. If you play you also get both currency during the playtime/Leveling up. So you get some cool cosmetics or can spare some and get the one expensive you want. Or you complete challenges to unlock some cosmetics. 

[h3]Servers[/h3]
I know there are no OCE Servers, but I speak here for the European. Sure, at the start were some issues. 10+ mins queue‚Äôs. But they fix this quite fast, so now you get matches in like 5-10 seconds. I haven‚Äôt got any disconnects through the matches, or anything seems laggy. So everything is fine!
[h3]Final thought[/h3]
Get it. Play it. You will have so much fun with it!üòª

developer_response:
Hi there,

Our intention with th sentence "Paw it out with your friends both online and offline." was to convey that you can play with your friends remotely (online), or together in the same location using the same device (offline) through split-screen.

We sincerely apologize for any confusion our wording caused. It was never our intention to mislead our player base about the availability of an offline mode.

The game did not feature an offline mode in the recent three rounds of playtesting either. Intentionally misleading our players while conducting playtests that clearly reveal the absence of an offline mode would be nonsensical. (We admit, however, that our description could have been more thoughtfully worded...)

For more information, please refer to the official announcement here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1260320/discussions/0/3879344463501273249/

Thank you very much for your understanding and support.

Party animal is a small improvement over the 2017‚Äôs ‚Äúgang beast‚Äù formula
While I really like the gameplay and have fun smashing random cute animals and giggle like a school girl when I see my favorite animal in a cute costume, my review has to be objective and negative for now, simply because reviews is the only thing developers might listen to.

So, what‚Äôs the problem?
Well for starters the game went back on a core promise they made 3 years ago. Unlike gang beast that released in 2017, there is no local coop, no couch coop, no lobby creation, just singleplayer matchmaking.
Why is that a problem? Well a few hours ago AFTER RELEASE AND PLAYTEST, they changed the steam description of the game from "Paw it out with your friends both online and offline" to not include the word offline anymore. This is a similar behavior to what unity did a couple days ago changing their contract and removing their database to hide their change in decision. (Check steamdb if you don‚Äôt believe me)

This is a problem for me, this is marketed as a party game that is unplayable as a party game :
->I wanted to play the game on split screen with my friends, now this is not possible.
->I can‚Äôt play the game offline on holydays or in the car/train/bus with friends because this is online and singleplayer only.
This problem is even exacerbated because choosing your prefered server is bugged and you're stuck on whatever server above 120 ms they chose for you so enjoy having a 1-2 second lag on everything you do.

Now, what could be the reason of such a decision?
That‚Äôs right, it‚Äôs money, it‚Äôs always money.

- Above the fact that you then need to buy multiple copies (and screens) to be able to use this game as a party game, the game includes a always online status to promote a predatory gacha system similar to what gacha games like Genshin offers, in fact the odds are very similar: You like that legendary skin on the corgi? Well though luck mate, you‚Äôre gonna have to use the gacha egg system and count on a 1.5% chance of obtaining it (1 chance out of ~700 pulls), to guarantee a legendary a post calculated that you need to invest 250‚Ç¨ into it and even then you could get a different legendary that you can‚Äôt or don‚Äôt want to use. (Source : https://steamcommunity.com/app/1260320/discussions/2/5291222404442799257/ )

- There is also a rotating shop promoting fomo that puts most skins as ‚Äúunavailable‚Äù to incentivise you to log in every day/week for the privilege of buying it or really make you feel like you should be buying this other cute skin before it goes away.
->This is bad because this is like that for 70% of skins
->This is bad because it‚Äôs a 17,99‚Ç¨ pay to play game 
->This is bad because this is marketed at kids and kids and even some adults are very well manipulated by gambling practices that maybe they won‚Äôt find horrible because they were born after things like that became the norm and this shouldn‚Äôt be the norm.
->This is bad because it weaponizes our love and bias for adorable animals for corporate profit.

Again, the game is fine and is good mindless fun just like gang beast was in 2017 but in the current state I don‚Äôt feel like you should support it, I don‚Äôt know why they needed 3 years to finish development when the game feels like the exact same it was on the October 2019 playtest that I participated in (making the perfect system to squeeze as much money from their customers as possible perhaps) but whatever really, fix your predatory monetisation, keep promises you made years ago and I will change my review for a positive one. I know I‚Äôm gonna receive hate from people that are just blind to those problems because they enjoy the cuteness of the game, I choose to be objective and speak up to promote a gaming economy that don‚Äôt use psychology tricks to make a ton of money on your vulnerabilities and affection for cute animals

Monetization side? Idk, there's things you can buy with in game currency, there's also premium one that you can buy more "rare" costumes and what not.
Didn't really look into the pricing as I don't care for mtx stuff as long as it's not p2w.

I'll give the devs the benefit of the doubt and give them time to address the issues in the coming patches

Been waiting for this game for yeaaarrs. I'm so excited it's finally out.
[h3] PLEASE DON'T LET THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS SWAY YOU. [/h3]
It is the first day of launch they are having server issues. It happens. It will be fixed.
[b]While there are valid complaints (which I will mention below) it is good to note that this game [i]is[/i] being review bombed by chinese users (I am not completely savvy to the reason). If you filter reviews by your language you will see a change in average go from mixed to very positive. [h3] 85% positive at time of writing. [/h3] [i]Less than one third[/i] of reviews are in English, that's a huge discrepancy[/b]

[h2] Real Talk [/h2]
As for the cons that hold more water I want to address them so interested people won't be deterred by them at surface level the way the neg reviews present them.

[b]Offline mode: [/b]  valid. if they said it would have it, it should. However, it's not something that can't be added/fixed.  I hope they will. 

[i][b]Update on Offline Mode:[/b] They devs clarified that offline mentioned in their description was meant to mean locally and not offline.  It's unfortunate that those who wanted a internetless way to play aren't able to, however, I think a lot of disgruntled commenters are confusing offline mode with couch-co-op.  You can still play on the same screen together and make it so its a private party of just you guys without matchmaking, or for a better term "local" play, which is common in games nowadays. 

It is rare to find party games outside of nintendo that still support offline play and not just local play in 2023 and I can only think of a handful of situations where someone would be wanting to play this without access to the internet. That's not to say there isnt or there aren't people who don't have valid cause to be disappointed, I just don't think its as widespread as the issues with it tend to be. [/i]

[b]Servers:[/b] first day servers are always a bit rough, I trust they will stabilize, but I do feel for countries that do not have a local server causing them to have higher latency connections. However, I trust this is temporary and more will be added.

[b]Micro transactions:[/b]  cosmetic only.  while its not a ftp game for it to include a store like others, the micro transactions are very optional. I do think the prices are steep for a ftp game but you get points for level ups and can earn both the regular and premium currency through playing. Unfortunately right now the means to accrue premium currency via leveling is finite as it caps at lvl 99. Hopefully they add more ways in the future. It's good to note you can also convert one currency into the other for added flexibility [strike](though i do not know if this goes both ways)[/strike]
[i]*see edit below[/i]  

[b][h3]Bottom line is,[/h3] it is a great fun game, and all the potential drawbacks are easily fixable or preference based.  [/b]

[i](also note, I'm not affiliated with the devs, nor did I receive this game for free. I just am very happy to finally have this game and want to clear the air of fear mongering)[/i]

[h3]EDIT:[/h3]
It has been clarified that you can not exchange currency both ways which is unfortunate. I think this would be a good feature to implement as it would take the pressure off some of the more heavy handed microtransactions, because I agree, for a not ftp game, some of these items are expensive.

[b]I also edited the above to reflect their recent statement on the matter[/b]

[i]To the commenters: like I said in the post, they are all valid concerns, i never dismissed that. but they are not ones that are completely gamebreaky to the point of the mass spam of negative reviews that are happening. I support calling devs out and asking for change in features, thats how games grow and improve. But its also good to keep it in perspective as well.[/i]

Game is hella fun: I've been waiting for it for years and honestly I don't feel like giving a negative review because you have to be online. 
I can see why some people might be unhappy about it because the original description by the devs (now edited) was different and misleading.

The most fun I had in the game for years was such a cute and hilarious experience. There were a lot of situations where my friends and I couldn't stop laughing. Maps, modes, animals, and skins are all so well made. The graphics are very well aligned with the theme of the game, and the soundtrack is awesome.
In addition to positive things, I would also mention some negative ones. The game has a lot of microtransactions, and with the two currencies in the game, it's so hard to catch up on how and where you can get specific skin since some of them are only available in surprise eggs (lootboxes), some of them you can buy in the shop with different currencies, or you can get them as a reward for achievements. There is also a lack of challenges; you get four weekly challenges that don't feel rewarding enough.
Overall, the game is very well made, and I hope for its bright future.

I've played all available demos of this game and in truth have about 25-30 hours in the game, just recently. It's a really fun party game, but here are some concerns that can possibly affect you:
-[strike] No LATAM, or OCE servers at the time of this review [/strike]
-Regular servers are having connection issues, and xbox play pass users have reported issues
-There are microtransactions in this game, however it does not affect gameplay at all as these are skins and completely optional. I'll also add that you can get almost all the animals with the free to earn currency through level ups and achievements, as well as some skins.
-People are talking about an offline mode and I think there was generally some miscommunication here, but I understand the complaints. There is no offline, only online co-op and online couch co-op at the time of this review
So, if these things affect you, especially server concerns, wait a few days for an update on stability.

EDIT/UPDATE: They made a statement on the steam forums about the offline stuff. They are working on the ping issue for SA and OCE, as well. Apparently the servers couldn't find enough people for 8 players, and shifted players in queue to other servers. SA and OCE players should try playing during peak times, but I believe the overall issue has been solved in general

This game is incredibly fun. Most of the negatives talk about no offline mode, which is a valid criticism, but the game as a whole is still excellent.

There are a lot of unique maps and modes, and I've legitimate enjoyed each one I've played so far. The game is great for playing with friends, so if you have a group that's interested, I'd say give it a shot. For the price, you get a lot of content. 

The devs also have shown themselves to care a lot about making this game better. I'm hopeful that the dev team will take the major criticisms seriously and fix those. Though again, I must point out that the only major criticisms I see are queue times - for an online-only, day 1 release with a ton of people on simultaneously - and the lack of an offline mode - which I agree should be added in. 

Also note, my hours in this game are misleading. Gotta add another 20 or so in there based on playtest and demo time. This review is based partially on those experiences as well, and on how I've seen this game develop over time. 

As a whole, this game is great and a lot of fun. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a fun party game.

[h1][b]Mixed or Negative Reviews? Not about gameplay; Review Bomb from Chinese players[/b][/h1]
The gameplay is unanimously enjoyed, but crazy amounts of review bombing from where the Developers are from. If you were to check the reviews for your own languages, you'll notice that the game rating showcases itself as "Very Positive" - as shown here: [url=https://i.imgur.com/OVHa3XC.png][/url] If you're wondering what they're complaining about, it's primarily about the pricing in their currency, the time it took to finish development on the game, apparent lies to the Chinese playerbase, and the so called "lack of content." Some of these points I cannot attest, but the lack of content, I disagree. Since the content offered is varied and unique. 20 Unique maps, for a similarly priced game to Gang Beasts, which this game takes heavy inspiration to. If the pricing is unfair for the Chinese, then regional pricing does need to be adjusted.[h2]Anyways, what [i]does [/i]the gameplay offer?[/h2]A simple party game beat-em-up, that you knock out your friends or opponents online. Toss them off the edge, or play objective based modes inspired by real sports, or mini-games to work together towards. The maps are all varied and unique in their own right. Unique gimmicks and hazards that gives each maps personality. The controls are easy to pick-up, but may take a couple games to get a hang of. Strong wind-ups of running punches, small jabs, jump kicks, slight kicks, or headbutts that while your character moves like a wobbly drunkard. Not too good at unarmed combat? There are plenty of physical weapons to harness, from ranged to melee: Tasers, crossbows, ice-guns, shovels, lollipops, and more. It's a super casual, extremely satisfying, fun arcade-y fighter. Play with some buds and you will guarantee a blast of laughter and fun.
[h1]Modes of play:[/h1][list][*][h3]Standoff: (1-life 2v2v2v2, FFA, or 4v4)[/h3][/list][quote=author]9 maps: The primary goal is to knock people off. Maps here provide hazards like a creeping gas, a chilling blizzard, a shaky bridge, a submerging submarine, a strong wind tunnel, chilly waters on a breaking glacier, fear of heights on a Fighter Jet, a gravity defying black hole, or an intensifying wavy floating bridge. All with the general premise of knocking out, and throwing off opponents. Each one gets more and more intense over time, becoming more difficult to recover onto the map. If you do get thrown off fully, don't fret, you can still influence the outcome of the match with some objects to throw at players while spectating.[/quote][list][*][h3]Team score: (4v4 Objective modes)[/h3][/list][quote=author]9 maps: American Football, Soccer, Air Hockey, Candy Collection, Arcade Machine Fighting, Trebuchet Launching, Electrical-Ball Scoring, and Rail-Train Racing, or balloon safe-extraction. All with their little gimmicks, and the main premise of beating the hell out of each other. These have respawns if hazards do end you.[/quote][list][*][h3]Arcade: 10-life (4v4 mode)[/h3][/list][quote=author]2 maps: A pool of respawns/lives for each team. Knock players out of a cabin into a blizzard, or throw players onto the tracks of an incoming train.[/quote][h1]Comparison to the competition[/h1]In comparison to Gang Beasts, the movement mechanics are much more streamlined and simplified. For example, Climbing is just a combination of two buttons. Grab + Jump while moving in the direction you want to climb towards. Whereas in Gang Beasts, you had to raise your arms, alternating both hands while grabbing, all while holding jump. You basically have to play QWOP in Gang Beasts just to recover after being thrown off. It would be a lot more difficult to master, which seems wrong for a Party Game. In map-design, this game is much more physics-influenced, varied, with accompanying toys/weaponry to play around with. More unique modes, and more ways to play than the alternative. It seems that Party Animals is just an upgrade in every single way.
[h1][b]My qualms[/b][/h1]With the positive, there are always some complaints. They are not enough to deter me into a negative review, but I believe they should be addressed. For the Australian players, there should be provided OCE servers. Offline functionality should be a feature as promised, as this game should not always be online. P2P-Fallback would be nice, if the servers ever did get shut down. The price of cosmetics seem a bit expensive during these hard times, & should be lowered. Also, a gacha system in a paid-game seems odd, and misplaced. In total, you can earn quite a few of the gacha rolls for free, but it is limited. You will only be guaranteed one legendary, [i]IF [/i]you do fully progress and obtain all of the free currency and surprise eggs. That may feel a bit tedious, or long to endure. If it was possible to just earn egg-coins perpetually, with no limit, I would find it quite fair.

 [i]It would seem that most of the negative reviews are not about its gameplay. [/i]Despite any of these problems, I believe the pros heavily outweigh the cons. The game is well enough fun for its price, and has provided me the most amount of joy and laughter that no other party game has come close to. I [b][i]extremely recommend [/i][/b]the game for all the positive reasons above. The negative review's complaints are valid, but I don't think it should drag the game into obscurity. It's too fun for that, and it truly doesn't deserve it.

BUYERS BEWARE 

If you get banned, even temporarily, for whatever reason, you will NOT be able to access the game, not even to play with bots. 

That's what you get with an "always online" party game.

---------------------------------------------------


It's a fun game. It can be addictive at times, especially if you don't want to bother playing other games. 

However, the controls are not that good. The hits don't register properly, everyone is flopping around.

There is no way to recover after being knocked down, regardless of your stamina bar. You can mash all the buttons on your keyboard, but it really depends. It becomes frustrating to deal with these mechanics at some point.

Some of the maps are also too small and badly designed (Gator Valley, Typhoon). Quick deaths are happening, without there being a very clear reason why, especially on maps with various elements (Ichiban, Ice Breaker). Two players fall down, at the same time, but somehow one freezes, or drowns or gets poisoned faster. Last remaining players all die, but there is no draw, one player manages to win in some way.

The camera is not properly angled, and you cannot really change it.

The force quit punish is nonsensical.

Two player splitscreen looks terrible.

The worst of it all, a Gacha type system in a children's game, on top of all the micro-transactions. It's awful. 


On the plus side, it's a cute game that's best played with friends!

I understand that it's asking for online connection. However, I have only been playing this online.

It has been great to play with my friends and I haven't laughed in a multiplayer game like this in so long. Great and easy modes and the learning curve is minimal. Within 5 minutes of downloading this game and playing, I had a good time. I played the playtest so my hours are skewed, but as of 8 hours in the game I've put in, it's definitely worth the price.

even bought it for friends! would recommend

[strike]Great party game but false advertising on the offline play. They've now updated the Steam description to say real life and not offline. People don't want a constant connection to be able to play the game.

I'll update my review to positive once the devs address these issues.[/strike]

The devs have made a statement about the false advertisement, being a case of miscommunication. I've changed my review as a result, but do keep in mind the game does not support offline play or P2P connections. So if the servers go down, you can't play the game anymore.
developer_response:
Hi there,

Our intention with th sentence "Paw it out with your friends both online and offline." was to convey that you can play with your friends remotely (online), or together in the same location using the same device (offline) through split-screen.

We sincerely apologize for any confusion our wording caused. It was never our intention to mislead our player base about the availability of an offline mode.

The game did not feature an offline mode in the recent three rounds of playtesting either. Intentionally misleading our players while conducting playtests that clearly reveal the absence of an offline mode would be nonsensical. (We admit, however, that our description could have been more thoughtfully worded...)

For more information, please refer to the official announcement here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1260320/discussions/0/3879344463501273249/

Thank you very much for your understanding and support.

developer_response:
Hi there,

Our intention with th sentence "Paw it out with your friends both online and offline." was to convey that you can play with your friends remotely (online), or together in the same location using the same device (offline) through split-screen.

We sincerely apologize for any confusion our wording caused. It was never our intention to mislead our player base about the availability of an offline mode.

The game did not feature an offline mode in the recent three rounds of playtesting either. Intentionally misleading our players while conducting playtests that clearly reveal the absence of an offline mode would be nonsensical. (We admit, however, that our description could have been more thoughtfully worded...)

For more information, please refer to the official announcement here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1260320/discussions/0/3879344463501273249/

Thank you very much for your understanding and support.
